<p>CHAPTER 4</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="general-principles-in-the-assessment-and-management-of-the-ill-child">General Principles in the Assessment and Management of the Ill Child<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#general-principles-in-the-assessment-and-management-of-the-ill-child" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Katie Barnes</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>It is estimated that during the first 2 years of life, children will have 2–4 acute illnesses per year. Although the number of episodic illnesses will decrease as a child gets older, it is very likely that nurse practitioners (NPs) in most settings will be assessing and managing ill children.</li>
<li>A large percentage of paediatric episodic illnesses are relatively benign, easily managed, of viral aetiology and almost always resolve completely. However, the implications of a missed diagnosis in cases which do not meet these criteria can be devastating and even life-threatening.</li>
<li>Regardless of the illness, the basic information required for assessment and management of an ill child is, for the most part, the same for all children (adolescents excepted).</li>
<li>A solid understanding of growth and development is the foundation upon which the history, physical examination, list of differential diagnoses and management plan are based. In addition, the assessment and management of ill children occurs within the family context (see Ch. 1).</li>
<li>The primary objectives of the episodic paediatric consultation include identification of those conditions that are easily managed by the NP; accurate diagnosis and management; avoidance of missed pathology; appropriate and timely referral (if necessary); and delivery of health care within a context that is age and/or developmentally appropriate.</li>
<li>Remember that paediatric illnesses often have a developmental component (e.g. pathogenic organisms, peak ages of incidence, likelihood of sequelae, risk of complications, etc.) and that a child’s age has important implications for her care.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology">PATHOPHYSIOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Illness-specific, but it is important to place the pathophysiological processes within a developmental context as there are many physiological processes that are developmentally influenced (e.g. infants with a greatly decreased capacity to fight infection and, as such, at a greater risk for sepsis): see Chapter 2.</li>
<li>It is very important to use age-appropriate values for vital signs and laboratory values.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="history">HISTORY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Parents/carers are often the historians (especially with younger children); however, do not exclude older children (and certainly not adolescents) from the information-gathering process. Remember to solicit information directly from them if developmentally appropriate.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Precipitating factors, events or triggers.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Location: often helpful to ask an older child to use ‘one finger’ to point to where it hurts most.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Character/quality: assessment of pain can be difficult (see Sec. 13.3).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Quantity/severity: number of episodes and degree to which the symptoms are affecting daily activities. Note that symptoms that awaken a child from a sound sleep are more worrying.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Associated symptoms: request information regarding additional symptomatology (including presence or absence of fever); use a review of systems to organise the history to ensure no potential complaints are overlooked.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Timing: onset, duration and frequency of symptoms. Include questioning about the order in which they appeared and the timing of any associated complaints: e.g. child had upper respiratory tract infection (URTI) symptoms for 3 days and was otherwise well but subsequently spiked a fever to 39°C and started vomiting.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Setting: symptoms on Saturdays? Only in the mornings? Recent travel?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Aggravating/relieving factors?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Parent’s (and child’s) perception of illness?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Treatments tried so far with results: home remedies, complementary therapies, prescription and over-the-counter (OTC) medications?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Anyone else ill with same symptoms and/or exposures: siblings, nursery, school, play group?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>How is the family coping with the illness?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Is the child eating, drinking, playing, urinating and to what degree are these affected by the illness?</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>4 General principles in the assessment and management of the ill child</p>
<ul>
<li>Note: above points assume that the past medical history is known (allergies, immunisations, major illnesses, medications, etc.). If past medical history is unknown, this additional information must be obtained.</li>
<li>It is important to compliment parents on some aspect of their management and/or recognition of their child's illness. A sick child is anxiety-provoking for all parents, but especially those who are young, inexperienced, isolated or lacking support; thus, it is important to contribute to their development as competent parents. This can be as simple or basic as reassuring an anxious parent that she has done the correct thing in seeking care for the child.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physical-examination">PHYSICAL EXAMINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A developmental approach to the physical examination is important (see Ch. 1) and, as such, keep parents in the picture (a potential exception is the physical examination of the adolescent).</li>
<li>Careful observation is key: a sick kid looks sick.</li>
<li>Examination of all systems from head to abdomen is mandatory.</li>
<li>Repeat observations/examinations after fever relief.</li>
<li>Special note should be taken of several areas:</li>
<li>General appearance: note the child's overall appearance (ill, well, alert, lethargic, altered consciousness, etc.), including their ease of movement, cry and colour. To assess nuchal rigidity in infants or small children, drop or move a brightly coloured object around and see if she watches or looks for it. Alternatively, ask the parents to move away and see if the child follows them (i.e. both manoeuvres are to get the child to move his neck). Ask older children to 'kiss' their knees while prone with knees flexed.</li>
<li>Engagability: the child's degree of interaction with the environment (i.e. smile, ability to turn head, consolability, activity, etc.).</li>
<li>Respiratory effort: the breath sounds of children with significant upper respiratory tract congestion are difficult to assess as upper airway 'noise' is transmitted to the chest. Listening with a stethoscope at the nose before listening to the lung fields allows aural accommodation to the upper airway sounds, hopefully making assessment of the lower airway easier (e.g. listening 'under' the noise). In addition, loud crying, while often obliterating the expiratory breath sounds, allows for assessment of air exchange/inspiratory effort when the child breathes in (the stronger the cry, the larger the inspiratory breath). However, it is important to be quick and focus on the inspiratory phase. Beware the silent chest as this implies there is no air exchange and is a medical emergency.</li>
<li>Hydration: check for skin turgor/ tenting on abdomen. Palpate the oral mucosa in order to feel its texture: i.e. when rubbing the inside of the cheek, it should feel slippery.</li>
<li>Temperature: accurate measurement is very important, especially with younger children.</li>
<li>Vital signs (including weight): be sure to use age-appropriate normal values and it is very important to obtain the child's weight at the time of the episodic visit (if there is a return visit, the values will need to be compared). Note that a fever will increase the age-appropriate heart rate by approximately 10 beats/min for each 0.5°C elevation above normal core temperature.</li>
<li>Skin: carefully check for rashes all over the body, including the mucous membranes: i.e. check for rashes both inside and out.</li>
<li>Perfusion: note colour, texture and capillary refill (&lt;2 s).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="differential-diagnoses">DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differential-diagnoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Numerous, so think very broadly.</li>
<li>Consider age-specific pathogens and aetiologies.</li>
<li>Consider the epidemiological features of different illnesses in your thinking (e.g. seasonality of some infections, likelihood of exposure, incubation periods, community outbreaks, etc.).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Specific management of the ill child is aetiology-dependent, but the following are some basic principles to be considered.</p>
<ul>
<li>Additional diagnostics: availability of diagnostic testing is often dependent on setting. However, if available, both a full blood count (FBC) and urine dipstick (with leucocyte esterase and nitrites) are initial diagnostics that provide useful information for clinical decision making (see Sec. 14.1). This is especially true in young, febrile infants (see Sec. 15.1). Note that a butterfly needle is the easiest way to draw an FBC.</li>
<li>Pharmacotherapeutics: usually not necessary. However, it is important to consider issues such as medication administration, refrigeration, scheduling, length of treatment and TASTE.</li>
<li>Behavioural interventions: consider nutritional management and supportive care (including fever control). Give older children 'homework' or a 'special job to help themselves get better'. For example, explain to a 5 year old that their 'job' is to drink an extra glass of 'special water' each time they have diarrhoea. Use every consultation as an opportunity to promote appropriate interventions for self-care and healthy choices.</li>
<li>Patient education: always review behavioural interventions related to the illness in addition to explaining to parents (and children) the aetiology of the illness; infection control instructions and 'expected' course of illness (including when to return to school or nursery); when to return/phone for 'unexpected' events during the course of the illness; and any follow-up instructions. Lastly, it is important to provide reassurance and praise where appropriate for the parent or carer's management.</li>
</ul>
<p>Bibliography</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="medical-consult-specialist-referral">MEDICAL CONSULT/SPECIALIST REFERRAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-consult-specialist-referral" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Any child in whom presentation or history fall outside the NP's comfort level, expertise or scope of practice.</li>
<li>Any child in whom there is a gravely ill appearance or whose clinical condition has deteriorated.</li>
<li>Any child requiring specialist intervention or expertise.</li>
<li>Young, febrile infants and neonates are at much greater risk of serious infection and as such, will likely require referral.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="paediatric-pearls">PAEDIATRIC PEARLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paediatric-pearls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>General appearance and engagability are important indicators; sick kids look sick—trust your instincts.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>You are not just treating the child, it is the whole family.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The child's age and developmental level are the springboard from which the history, physical examination, differential list and management plan are launched; do not overlook these important considerations.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Get some good paediatric reference books—keep them handy.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Use age-appropriate vital signs and laboratory values.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Develop good relationships with the paediatric professionals (registrars, consultants or NPs): they can be an important resource for paediatric-related questions and referrals.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Don't overlook the urine as a potential source of infection.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A head-to-abdomen physical examination is imperative in paediatric episodic illness.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Don't forget to look 'inside' and 'outside' for rashes and always check perfusion and hydration status.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Respiratory effort is a vital observation; listen 'underneath' the noise.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bibliography">BIBLIOGRAPHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bibliography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<p>CHAPTER 5</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pharmacology-in-paediatrics">Pharmacology in Paediatrics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pharmacology-in-paediatrics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Katie Barnes and Sara Higginson</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Adults and children respond to drugs differently. Disparities include the absorption, distribution, metabolism and elimination of the drug by the body as well as differences in formulation, dosage and administration.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The field of paediatric pharmacology is relatively new and tremendous progress has been made in expanding paediatric pharmacology from an adult therapeutics ‘add-on’ into a recognised specialty. However, the development of a pharmacological evidence base in children has been hampered by the difficulties of conducting drug trials in paediatrics.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Medications that are used commonly in paediatric practice do have well-articulated details such as age/weight dosing, implications for breast-feeding and important information related to drug absorption, distribution, elimination and adverse events. It is imperative that the clinician caring for children utilises this information to maximise the benefits of pharmacological agents.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is important to recognise that the nature, duration of effect and intensity of a drug’s action are related not only to the intrinsic properties of the drug itself but also to the drug’s interaction with the patient to whom it has been administered. Therefore, effective and safe drug therapy in neonates, infants, children and adolescents requires an understanding of the differences in drug action, metabolism and disposition that are determined developmentally.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Nearly all pharmacokinetic parameters change with age and as a result, paediatric drug dosages must be adjusted accordingly. Likewise, issues such as medication administration and formulation have concordance implications in paediatrics.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Although an in-depth analysis of paediatric pharmacology is beyond the scope of this book, important pharmacotherapeutic considerations are outlined.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="drug-absorption">DRUG ABSORPTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drug-absorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Among neonates and young infants, decreased intestinal motility and delayed gastric emptying time can result in a greater lag time between drug administration and a plasma concentration that is equivalent to that of an older child or adult. This is likewise true among older children with gastrointestinal problems (e.g. coeliac disease or cystic fibrosis). However, controversy exists as to the clinical significance of these factors outside of the neonatal and early infancy periods, as factors such as liquid administration, decreased gastric acid production and a relatively greater small gut surface area in young children contribute to potentially enhanced drug absorption.</li>
<li>Reflux of gastric contents is very common during the first year of life: excessive reflux of medications can result in a variable and unpredictable loss of an orally administered dose.</li>
<li>Rectal drug administration in paediatrics can be a useful alternative when conditions such as nausea,</li>
</ul>
<p>vomiting and status epilepticus preclude oral administration. Drugs administered rectally are absorbed directly into the haemorrhoidal vein (part of the systemic rather than portal system) and therefore, do not make a ‘first pass’ through the liver where a large fraction of the absorbed drug may be removed. However, rectal administration of drugs in suppository form is typically erratic, with the presence of stool and/or expulsion of the dose potentially affecting drug absorption through decreased bioavailability. Nevertheless, medications can be successfully administered rectally if in solution (e.g. diazepam and rectal corticosteroids). Note that rectal absorption of paracetamol can be variable, but that it is adequately absorbed, albeit more slowly than oral administration.</p>
<ul>
<li>The rate and extent of absorption from intramuscular and subcutaneous injection is influenced by characteristics of the patient—e.g. blood flow to the injection site, muscle mass, quantity of adipose tissue and muscle activity—as well as properties of the drug, such as solubility of the drug at the extracellular pH, ease of diffusion across capillary membranes and the surface area over which the injection volume spreads. In general, parenteral administration via injection is not an optimal route in hypoperfusion syndromes, dehydration, vasomotor instability or starvation, as absorption will be impeded. However for many drugs, including most aminoglycoside and penicillin antibiotics, intramuscular administration results in plasma</li>
</ul>
<p>Drug choice, dosage, frequency, administration route and formulation</p>
<p>concentrations equivalent to those achieved with intravenous administration. Drugs for which intramuscular administration is not appropriate include those with an unacceptable degree of tissue reaction (e.g. erythromycin, some cephalosporins, digoxin) and those that are highly hydrophobic (diazepam and phenytoin). It is important to remember that intramuscular injection can be painful (especially relevant for children) and it can be unsuitable when a rapid response is needed as absorption can be slow and incomplete.</p>
<ul>
<li>It is important to recognise that absorption of topical medications is greater among infants and small children because of their (1) thinner stratum corneum, (2) greater total body surface area (TBSA) to weight ratio and (3) increased skin hydration. Amongst young children, the use of plastic-coated nappies can increase drug absorption in the nappy area (related to the occlusiveness of the plastic coating). All of these considerations have implications for the amount of drug absorbed transcutaneously and therefore, care needs to be taken with the use of high-potency medications (i.e. use of strong topical steroids in infants with severe eczema).</li>
<li>The issue of drug absorption with regard to meals is also of importance in paediatrics. In order to facilitate ease of administration (and subsequent concordance) most orally administered drugs (isoniazid and narrow-spectrum penicillins excepted) should be given with meals.</li>
<li>Sustained-release oral preparations are problematic in young children, as absorption may be unpredictable, incomplete and result in treatment failures. Dosing schedules may need to be adjusted depending on the rate of drug clearance and the effect of increased gastrointestinal transit time in infants and young children.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="drug-distribution">DRUG DISTRIBUTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drug-distribution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Once absorbed, the distribution of a drug is related to host factors such as body compartment size and composition; protein-binding capacity (both plasma and protein); and blood-brain barrier permeability. Characteristics of the drug include its molecular weight and its degree of ionisation once absorbed. As a general rule, the volume of distribution of drugs tends to be greater among infants, with a subsequent decrease as the child matures into childhood (i.e. closer to adult values). However, there are many exceptions, including drugs such as theophylline and phenobarbital.</li>
<li>Note that young children (especially infants) have a greater percentage of total body water and extracellular fluid for their size. Consequently, there may be increased distribution and dilution of water-soluble drugs (e.g. aminoglycosides) as the resultant concentration of the drug at the receptor site is reduced. This is the rationale behind increased milligrams of drug per kilograms of body weight (mg/kg) dosing of many medications (as compared to adult dosages).</li>
<li>Reduced protein binding of drugs can be important in the neonatal period. The reduced albumin and displacement of drugs by bilirubin results in higher concentrations of the free drug, which is pharmacologically active. For example, ceftriaxone should be avoided in neonates with jaundice, hypoalbuminaemia, acidosis or impaired bilirubin binding.</li>
<li>Among neonates, the blood-brain barrier is functionally incomplete so there may be an enhanced effect of some medications. In older children, relatively tighter junctions in the endothelial capillaries of the brain combined with the close proximity of the glial connective tissue to the capillary endothelium results in limited distribution of drugs to the brain tissue. However, with inflamed meninges (e.g. in meningitis), higher concentrations of a drug are attained in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) as a function of an increased vascular permeability and partial inhibition of the organic acid transport mechanism.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="drug-elimination-metabolism-and-excretion">DRUG ELIMINATION: METABOLISM AND EXCRETION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drug-elimination-metabolism-and-excretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Differences in drug metabolism, which occurs primarily in the liver, are most acute in the immediate neonatal period, particularly in premature infants. They are related to the decreased ability of the liver and its microsomal enzyme system to metabolise a number of drug substrates. During the subsequent 3 months of life, the capacity of the liver to metabolise drugs increases rapidly. In the pre-school child, hepatic clearance actually exceeds adult levels, whereas in adolescence the metabolic capacity of the liver normalises to adult levels.</li>
<li>In the kidney (the primary site of drug excretion) glomerular filtration and tubular function are less efficient in early infancy. However, creatinine clearance increases rapidly during the first year of life so that by 12 months of age, creatinine clearance—when adjusted for body surface area—equals adult clearance levels. In addition, there is some evidence that the average clearance in school-age children actually exceeds adult levels. Tubular function matures later than glomerular function but is essentially mature by 1 year of age. Clinical implications of decreased renal function are most pronounced in pre-term infants and among children with pre-existing renal pathology. Therefore, dose adjustment would be necessary for these groups when drugs dependent on renal excretion for cessation of their activity—e.g. penicillins, aminoglycosides, digoxin and thiazide diuretics—are administered. In brief, the half-life of a drug is prolonged among newborns, decreased during infancy and shortest in the school-age child.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="drug-choice-dosage-frequency-administration-route-and-formulation">DRUG CHOICE, DOSAGE, FREQUENCY, ADMINISTRATION ROUTE AND FORMULATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drug-choice-dosage-frequency-administration-route-and-formulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>While many paediatric illnesses are self-limiting, if medication is required it is important that the drug choice is</li>
</ul>
<p>5 Pharmacology in paediatrics</p>
<p>dictated by the pathophysiology of the illness and the most likely match between the causative agent/process and the pharmacological activity of the drug (e.g. penicillin V for treatment of streptococcal pharyngitis). Drug choice is also influenced by issues such as medication cost, safety of use in paediatrics and drug effectiveness.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Drug dosages in paediatrics are most accurately calculated on a mg/kg basis (drugs calculated by total body surface area excepted). This is especially true for children &lt;20 kg and for those medications with a narrow therapeutic range. However, the available concentration of a specific preparation will impact the clinician's ability to request a specific mg/kg dose. The commonly accepted method of paediatric dosing is to calculate the optimal mg/kg dose and subsequently adjust it to a practical dose and available preparation. Note that this is unlikely to be necessary when dosing older children and adolescents for whom standard formulations often apply.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>With regard to dose frequency, as a general rule the lowest number of daily doses of a drug is preferable. For example, once daily steroid dosing (orally) is associated with less toxicity and improved adherence than smaller, more frequently administered doses. Likewise, thrice (or twice) daily dosing of an antibiotic is preferable to one that is administered four times a day (assuming there is no decrease in drug effectiveness). This is especially relevant for school-age children who may be able to receive doses of medicine while at school.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Oral administration is by far the most common route of paediatric drug administration. Topical preparations are largely reserved for dermatological conditions. Occasionally, there is an option of rectal or parenteral administration of a drug. Careful consideration of these routes is required as they are potentially more traumatic to the child (especially older children).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Drug formulation can impact medication concordance. If the child is able to manage tablets or capsules,</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>they are often more easily stored, there is greater accuracy of dosing (compared to liquid preparations) and often a longer expiry date. If a child cannot manage solid preparations, then an oral preparation is often a better choice than 'crushing' tablets (although with unpalatable liquids, crushed medication may be more easily disguised). Sustained-release medication should never be crushed or chewed and likewise, medication should not be mixed into large quantities of food or drink (e.g. never put medication into a baby's bottle as there is no way to be assured that the complete dose has been administered). Useful foods for disguising medications include small quantities of yogurt, blackcurrant cordial, chocolate mousse and bananas (mixed immediately before administration).</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>If a medication comes in two different strengths, a specific dosage may be maintained in a smaller volume of medication; this is especially helpful with uncooperative toddlers or pre-schoolers. In addition, many medications (especially liquid preparations) contain dyes, colouring agents and sucrose which children may be sensitive to (although the number who react is probably small).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In paediatric asthma management it is vital that the drug delivery device and drug formulation are matched. In addition, it is important that the device and its mechanics of use are developmentally appropriate for the child (e.g. infants should not be using a spin inhaler).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Many drugs used in paediatrics do not have a product licence for use in children. First choice should be a drug licensed for the age of the child being treated. However, as this is not always possible, it is inevitable that drugs will be used 'off label' (i.e. outside the product licence). In these cases, it is the prescriber's responsibility to select a drug where sound information is available (e.g. paediatric formularies). Use of unlicensed drugs can also present problems with supply and provision of the parent/patient information sheets (PILs).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="concordance-and-patient-education">CONCORDANCE AND PATIENT EDUCATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#concordance-and-patient-education" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Difficulties with a particular medication regimen arise from uncooperative children, inaccurate measurement techniques, omission of doses and conflicts such as nursery or school attendance. The ideal medication is one that is: palatable, with the fewest number of doses, no special storage requirements, and available in an appropriate strength that is cheap, safe and effective.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Parent and child education should include an understanding of (1) why a certain medication has been recommended, (2) what the medication should do (and what it shouldn't do), (3) for how long (and how many times a day) it should be administered, and (4) the importance of continuing the medication for the recommended length of time (even though symptoms may subside). In addition it is important to remind parents that all medications should be stored safely out of reach of children.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Parents may need advice on administration techniques and equipment to ensure accurate measurement (a teaspoon is not a teaspoon is not a teaspoon). An oral syringe ensures accurate measurement and may be preferred in some patients.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Administration of oral medication to infants requires (1) the head to be slightly elevated, (2) the correct dose measured in a dropper or oral syringe, and (3) placement of the drug in the back of the mouth on either side of the tongue. A gentle puff of breath onto the baby's face often elicits a swallowing reflex, which completes the process. Warn parents that if the infant starts to choke or cough, stop giving the medicine, sit him/her up and resume administration when the infant has settled.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Positive reinforcement (stickers, praise, etc.) can be used in older children. It is often helpful to encourage a sense of autonomy with their medication: e.g. letting a child 'squirt' the medicine into their mouth or 'help' to measure. Children should be approached firmly with clear instructions on what is</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Bibliography</p>
<p>expected of them. If the medication has an unpleasant taste, use of a straw while simultaneously holding the nose is often helpful.</p>
<ul>
<li>Medications should not be put into juices or bottles, as there is no way to be assured that the complete dose has been administered.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="paediatric-pearls">PAEDIATRIC PEARLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paediatric-pearls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Developmental changes in body composition, body proportions and relative mass of the liver and kidneys affect pharmacokinetics of a drug among different ages (e.g. neonates, infants, children and adolescents).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The capacity for drug metabolism and elimination is the greatest between the first and second years of life when the size of the kidney and liver (relative to body weight) are at their maximum.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Remember that body surface area (relative to body mass) is greatest in the infant and young child (as compared to the older child and adult) and thus, consideration must be given to potential systemic absorption of topically applied drugs.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The loading dose of a drug is primarily related to its volume of distribution, whereas the maintenance dose is a function of drug clearance.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Clearance of most drugs is primarily dependent on hepatic metabolism, with the excretion of drug and metabolites completed by the kidneys (and to a lesser extent, the liver).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In general, between 1 year of age and puberty, hepatic and renal function is not only equal to, but may exceed, normal adult levels of functioning.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Children of the same age come in many different sizes. Always calculate drug dosages in mg/kg (especially among children less than 20 kg) and adjust the dose to the available preparations.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In asthma management it is imperative to match the correct medication with the appropriate drug delivery device and the child's development.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The ideal medication is one that tastes good, is only given once a day, does not require refrigeration, comes in the right strength and is cheap, safe in kids and highly effective. Unfortunately, this combination does not exist; choose the closest option.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bibliography">BIBLIOGRAPHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bibliography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Hein K. Drug therapeutics in the adolescent. In: Yaffe S, Aranda J, eds, Pediatric pharmacology. Philadelphia: WB Saunders; 1992: 220-230.
Kaufman RE. Drug therapeutics in the infant and child. In: Yaffe S, Aranda J, eds, Pediatric pharmacology. Philadelphia: WB Saunders; 1992: 212-219.
Loebstein R, Koren G. Clinical pharmacology and therapeutic drug monitoring in neonates and children. Pediatr Rev 1998; 19(12):423-428.

Niederhausen VP. Prescribing for children: issues in pediatric pharmacology. Nurse Pract 1997; 22(3):16-30.
Rylance GW. Prescribing for infants and children. BMJ 1988; 296:984-986.
Walson PD. 1997 Paediatric clinical pharmacology and therapeutics. In: Speight TM, Holford M, Nicholas HG, eds, Avery's drug treatment, 4th edn. London: Blackwell Science; 1997: 127-165.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="internet-resources-for-the-nurse-practitioner">Internet Resources for the Nurse Practitioner<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#internet-resources-for-the-nurse-practitioner" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>As information technology continues to offer greater promise in the delivery of health care, the computer may be the practitioner’s best ally to enhance patient care. Through new emerging information systems, practitioners are accessing clinical information more efficiently, tapping into online repositories of medical information, communicating electronically with peers and finding new ways to simplify their work.</li>
<li>This list of web sites is intended for use by advanced practice nurses and is for education and information purposes only. Accuracy of the information contained in individual web sites should always be verified through other sources before being applied to patient care. Browsing via the Internet to find up-to-date information is the wave of the future.</li>
<li>To access the information on the Internet, it is assumed the reader can connect to online services. Each site was evaluated for current information, paediatric focus in the clinical practice areas, search features, international interest and parent/child resources.</li>
<li>Individual sites are organised around broad subject headings: <em>Alternative and Complementary Medicine</em>; <em>Bioterrorism</em>; <em>Clinical Practice</em>; <em>Clinical Tools</em>; <em>Journals and Reference Tools</em>; <em>Literature Search Tools</em>; <em>Patient Information</em>; <em>Pharmacology</em>; <em>Practice Guidelines</em>; <em>Professional Organisations</em>; <em>Sports Medicine</em>; and <em>Travel Medicine</em>.</li>
<li>All the links are available on <a href="http://www.geocities.com/paediatric" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.geocities.com/paediatric</a>.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="alternative-and-complementary-medicine">ALTERNATIVE AND COMPLEMENTARY MEDICINE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#alternative-and-complementary-medicine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><a href="http://www.mcp.edu/herbal/default.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.mcp.edu/herbal/default.htm</a> The Longwood Herbal Task Force was organised in the autumn of 1998 to learn more about and teach other clinicians about herbs and dietary supplements. The group began with systematic reviews of the six most common supplements used by oncology patients. Work rapidly expanded to include approximately 85 herbs and dietary supplements. The site has in-depth monographs, clinician information summaries, patient fact sheets, toxicity and interactions, and resources.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.altmedicine.com/Alternative" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.altmedicine.com/Alternative</a> Health News Online offers a search engine, health news bulletins, diet &amp; nutrition, mind/body control, alternative medical systems, manual healing and many links to alternative and complementary medicine.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bioterrorism">BIOTERRORISM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bioterrorism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-practice">CLINICAL PRACTICE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-practice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>Behavioural paediatrics:</strong>
<a href="http://www.aap.org/policy/ac0002.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.aap.org/policy/ac0002.html</a> Practice guideline from the American Academy of Pediatrics on the ‘diagnosis and evaluation of the child with attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder’.

<li>
<p><strong>Diabetes:</strong>
<a href="http://www.childrenwithdiabetes.com/index_cwd.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.childrenwithdiabetes.com/index_cwd.htm</a> Information for children, adults and professionals.</p>

<a href="http://www.ds-health.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.ds-health.com/</a> Health issues on Down’s syndrome for parents and professionals.</p>

<p>Journals and reference tools</p>
<ul>
<li>Gastrointestinal:
<a href="http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/CID/journal/issues/v32n3/001387/001387.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/CID/journal/issues/v32n3/001387/001387.html</a> Practice guidelines for the management of infectious diarrhea published by the Infectious Disease Society of America.</li>

<p><a href="http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5002a1.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5002a1.htm</a> Diagnosis and management of foodborne illness: a primer for physicians, published by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), is available for download.</p>

<a href="http://www.omni.ac.uk/subject-listing/WS100.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.omni.ac.uk/subject-listing/WS100.html</a> The UK's gateway to pediatric Internet resources.</li>

<p><a href="http://www.peds.umn.edu/divisions/pccm/teaching/acpcp.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.peds.umn.edu/divisions/pccm/teaching/acpcp.html</a> Acute paediatric primary care for the practitioner. A lecture series from the Pediatric Department at the University of Minnesota.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.pedinfo.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.pedinfo.org/</a> An index of the paediatric Internet. It has its own search function. Many categories and topics are listed.</p>
<p><a href="http://pedsccm.wustl.edu/All-Net/main.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://pedsccm.wustl.edu/All-Net/main.html</a> Paediatric critical care topics.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.vh.org/pediatric/index.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.vh.org/pediatric/index.html</a> Virtual Children's Hospital at the University of Iowa. Information on common paediatric problems, multimedia textbooks, teaching files, virtual patients, journals, grand rounds, practice guidelines and clinical references.</p>
<ul>
<li>Immunisations:
<a href="http://www.health.state.mn.us/divs/dpc/adps/forgnvac1.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.health.state.mn.us/divs/dpc/adps/forgnvac1.pdf</a> Do you have difficulty understanding your patients' foreign vaccination records? If so, Vaccines and biologics used in U.S. and foreign markets can help you make sense of them. This is an 11-page guide to vaccine products that lists vaccines and biologics by their trade name as well as the manufacturer and country of manufacture. (Adobe® Acrobat® Reader™ is free software that lets you view and print Adobe Portable Document Format (PDF) files: <a href="http://www.adobe.com/products/acrobat/readstep2.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.adobe.com/products/acrobat/readstep2.html</a>)</li>

<p><a href="http://home.vicnet.net.au/~nmaa/index.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://home.vicnet.net.au/~nmaa/index.html</a> Comprehensive link to the most up-to-date, expert immunisation resources available via the Internet. Use this site as the jumping-off point for the best in vaccine and antibody information.</p>

<li>Infectious disease—AIDS:

This site also has a collection of published guidelines for prevention and management of HIV/AIDS and related conditions.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.adolescentaids.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.adolescentaids.org</a> Staff at the Adolescent AIDS Program at Montefiore Medical Center have developed the first comprehensive Gay and Lesbian Adolescent Health Resource Center.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="clinical-tools">CLINICAL TOOLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-tools" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><a href="http://isabel.org.uk" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://isabel.org.uk</a> Clinical decision support software for paediatrics. Requires registration, but access is free and site is owned, updated and developed by the Isabel Medical Charity. Very valuable site for access to up-to-date, detailed information on paediatric signs, symptoms, differential diagnosis and management.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.intmed.mcw.edu/clinicalc.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.intmed.mcw.edu/clinicalc.html</a> Clinical calculators from the Medical College of Wisconsin.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.toledo-bend.com/colorblind/Ishihara.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.toledo-bend.com/colorblind/Ishihara.html</a> The Ishihara test for colour blindness.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.wilkes.med.ucla.edu/intro.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.wilkes.med.ucla.edu/intro.html</a> The Auscultation Assistant provides heart sounds, heart murmurs and breath sounds in order to help students and others improve their physical diagnosis skills.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="journals-and-reference-tools">JOURNALS AND REFERENCE TOOLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#journals-and-reference-tools" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><a href="http://www.thelancet.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.thelancet.com/</a> The Lancet site has free access to selected full-text articles, unlimited search facilities, Electronic Research Archive (ERA) and full-text global news.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.bmj.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.bmj.com/</a> The British Medical Journal has free selected articles and editorials for non-subscribers. Table of contents for the journal can be viewed.</p>
<p><a href="http://omni.ac.uk/subject-listing/WS100.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://omni.ac.uk/subject-listing/WS100.html</a> OMNI (Organising Medical Networked Information) is a gateway to evaluated Internet resources in health and medicine. It is updated regularly and has a great search function. OMNI is created by a core team of information specialists and subject experts based at the University of Nottingham Greenfield Medical Library. This web address is for the paediatric section.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.nice.org.uk/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.nice.org.uk/</a> The National Institute for Clinical Excellence was set up as a Special Health Authority for England and Wales in 1999. It is part of the National Health Service, and its role is to provide patients, health professionals and the public with</p>
<p>6 Internet resources for the nurse practitioner</p>
<p>authoritative, robust and reliable guidance on current 'best practice'. This site includes Clinical Guidelines and information on the clinical management of specific conditions.</p>
<p><a href="http://idinchildren.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://idinchildren.com/</a> Infectious Diseases in Children—free access to current and past issues.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.priory.com/fam.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.priory.com/fam.htm</a> Family Medical Practice On-Line have full-text articles. Only a few pertain to paediatrics.</p>
<p><a href="http://content.nejm.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://content.nejm.org/</a> The New England Journal of Medicine has free registration access to full-text articles that have been published over 6 months ago. Abstracts are available for all current articles.</p>
<p><a href="http://intl.pediatrics.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://intl.pediatrics.org/</a> The American Academy of Pediatrics publishes the Pediatrics Electronic Page articles that are free and full-text. Free abstracts are available on all current articles in the printed journal.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.nelh.nhs.uk/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.nelh.nhs.uk/</a> National Electronic Library for Health in the UK.</p>
<p><a href="http://pediatrics.medscape.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://pediatrics.medscape.com</a> Medscape is a leading company for online medical information. Free registration is necessary for weekly medical news delivery via e-mail. Some full-text journal articles are online. MEDLINE abstracts, searches, guidelines, patient information and continuing education are available.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.pedinfo.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.pedinfo.org/</a> PEDINFO: An Index of the Pediatric Internet. Dedicated to the dissemination of online information for paediatric health care providers and others interested in child health. MEDLINE searches, drug information, current health news and many more areas are available. Excellent site to search for specific health topics.</p>
<p><a href="http://ww2.med.jhu.edu/peds/neonatology/poi.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://ww2.med.jhu.edu/peds/neonatology/poi.html</a> The Harriet Lane Links provide an edited collection of paediatric resources (5475 links) on the World Wide Web. Maintained and edited by physicians at the Johns Hopkins University, this site attempts to catalogue, review and score existing links to paediatric information on the Internet.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.freemedicaljournals.com/MedicalJournals.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.freemedicaljournals.com/MedicalJournals.com</a> Free full-text journals.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.contemporarypediatrics.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.contemporarypediatrics.com</a> Contemporary Pediatrics journal online.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.emedicine.com/emerg/index.shtml" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.emedicine.com/emerg/index.shtml</a> Full-text of Emergency Medicine textbook. Topics are listed alphabetically in the contents section.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.merck.com/pubs/mmanual/sections.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.merck.com/pubs/mmanual/sections.htm</a> The Merck Manual of Diagnosis and Therapy is online with a search function.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.docguide.com/dgc.nsf/ge/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.docguide.com/dgc.nsf/ge/</a> Doctor's Guide, global edition, scans 1500 peer-reviewed journals. Register to receive weekly medial news via e-mail. Numerous topics and specific disease information listed.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.bartleby.com/107/Gray's" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.bartleby.com/107/Gray's</a> Anatomy of the Human Body.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/index.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/index.htm</a> National Heart Lung Blood Institute site, including articles, guidelines, and current clinical trials.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.dynamicmedical.com/DynaMed" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.dynamicmedical.com/DynaMed</a> (Dynamic Medical Information System) is an interactive, real-time medical information system designed for use at the point of care. It consists mainly of a vast clinically organised reference covering basic information and is updated daily from developments in the literature. DynaMed is also designed to allow for user input and discussions. DynaMed is designed to provide quick and easy access to medical information and is a useful resource in clinical, educational and research settings. It contains basic information on over 2000 diseases, and provides an organised structure for finding disease-based information, including both standard medical knowledge and current developments.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.ti.ubc.ca/pages/letter.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.ti.ubc.ca/pages/letter.html</a> Full-text articles from the Therapeutics Letter.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.ortho-u.net" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.ortho-u.net</a> Wheeless' Textbook of Orthopaedics is an excellent online reference with many radiological views.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.ornl.gov/hgmis/medicine/medicine.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.ornl.gov/hgmis/medicine/medicine.html</a> Latest news about medical genetics. The site has a large collection of articles and information on the Human Genome Project.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="literature-search-tools">LITERATURE SEARCH TOOLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#literature-search-tools" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><a href="http://gateway.nlm.nih.gov/gw/Cmd" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://gateway.nlm.nih.gov/gw/Cmd</a> The NLM Gateway allows users to search in multiple retrieval systems at the US National Library of Medicine (NLM). The current Gateway searches MEDLINE/PubMed, OLDMEDLINE, LOCATORplus, MEDLINEplus and DIRLINE.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.tripdatabase.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.tripdatabase.com</a> The TRIP Database searches across 58 sites of high-quality medical information. The TRIP Database gives you direct, hyperlinked access to the largest collection of 'evidence-based' material on the web as well as articles from premier online journals such as the British Medical Journal, Journal of the American Medical Association and the New England Journal of Medicine.</p>
<p><a href="http://nhscrd.york.ac.uk/darehp.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://nhscrd.york.ac.uk/darehp.htm</a> Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effectiveness (DARE). Supported by the University of York.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.bmj.com/cgi/content/full/315/7101/180" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.bmj.com/cgi/content/full/315/7101/180</a> A full text article in the British Medical Journal: 'How to read a paper: the Medline database'. It's a how-to article on searching the MEDLINE database.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.cochrane.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.cochrane.org</a> The Cochrane Collaboration is an international not-for-profit organisation. Its aim is to make up-to-date, accurate information about the effects of health care readily available worldwide. The Cochrane library can be accessed via a server in the UK, US or Germany.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="patient-information">PATIENT INFORMATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#patient-information" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><a href="http://www.nhsdirect.nhs.uk/about/NHS" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.nhsdirect.nhs.uk/about/NHS</a> Direct is a 24-hour nurse-led helpline providing confidential health care advice and information on what to do if you're feeling ill; health concerns; local health services; and self-help and</p>
<p>Professional organisations</p>
<p>support organisations. Its main purpose is to improve access to health information for patients and the public.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.jr2.ox.ac.uk/bandolier/Bandolier" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.jr2.ox.ac.uk/bandolier/Bandolier</a> is evidence-based health care articles published on many topics, including a few on paediatrics.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.patient.co.uk/PatientUK" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.patient.co.uk/PatientUK</a> is a directory of UK health, disease and related websites. It is edited by two general practitioners. Topics include child health, teenagers, student health, self-help groups and medicines.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.chas.org.uk/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.chas.org.uk/</a> Children's Hospice Association Scotland is a charity committed to the provision of children's hospice services in Scotland, working exclusively with children with life-limiting conditions and their families.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.ich.ucl.ac.uk/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.ich.ucl.ac.uk/</a> The Great Ormond Street Hospital and the Institute of Child Health together form the largest paediatric training and research centre in the UK. The two institutions work in partnership to improve the health of children everywhere. The Hospital offers the widest range of paediatric specialties in the country. The Institute aims to define the scientific, epidemiological and clinical basis of childhood diseases and to promote child health across the country and internationally.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.healthatoz.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.healthatoz.com/</a> Health A to Z 'search the web' feature that can search over 50,000 professionally reviewed health and medical Internet resources. Free registration for weekly personalised information on conditions or topics of interest. There is also online family health records organiser and free e-mail reminders about immunisations, checkups and appointments.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.healthfinder.gov/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.healthfinder.gov/</a> Guide to reliable health information sponsored by the US Department of Health and Human Services. There is a section for children—art contest, games, safe surfing and many health topics presented as cartoons and learning games.</p>
<p><a href="http://kidshealth.org/index.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://kidshealth.org/index.html</a> KidsHealth provides doctor-approved health information about children from birth through adolescence. KidsHealth has separate areas for kids, teens and parents—each with its own design and age-appropriate content.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.mayohealth.org/home?id=3.1.6" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.mayohealth.org/home?id=3.1.6</a> The children's page from the Mayo Clinic web site. Great resource for parents. Lists for specific conditions, medications, safety and first-aid.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/childandteenhealth.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/childandteenhealth.html</a> National Library of Medicine, MEDLINE Plus site on child and teen health topics.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pharmacology">PHARMACOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pharmacology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><a href="http://www.nppg.demon.co.uk/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.nppg.demon.co.uk/</a> Neonatal and Paediatric Pharmacists Group web site. Health professionals need to register to enter the electronic Medicines Compendium section.</p>
<p><a href="http://cp.gsm.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://cp.gsm.com/</a> Clinical Pharmacology 2000 provides up-to-date, peer-reviewed, clinically relevant information on all US drugs, as well as off-label uses and dosages, herbal supplements, nutritional products, new and investigational drugs, and can identify potential interactions. Nurse practitioners have free registration. Printouts are available for each product.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="practice-guidelines">PRACTICE GUIDELINES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#practice-guidelines" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><a href="http://www.guideline.gov/index.asp" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.guideline.gov/index.asp</a> The National Guideline Clearinghouse™ (NGC) is a public resource for evidence-based clinical practice guidelines. NGC is sponsored by the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) in partnership with the American Medical Association and the American Association of Health Plans. The site is searchable by keywords.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.aap.org/policy/pprgtoc.cfm" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.aap.org/policy/pprgtoc.cfm</a> Current American Academy of Pediatrics policy statements through April 2001.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.aap.org/policy/paramtoc.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.aap.org/policy/paramtoc.html</a> Current American Academy of Pediatrics clinical practice guidelines.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.med.umich.edu/pediatric/ebm" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.med.umich.edu/pediatric/ebm</a> Evidence-based paediatric web site at the University of Michigan.</p>
<p><a href="http://cebm.jr2.ox.ac.uk/index.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://cebm.jr2.ox.ac.uk/index.html</a> The UK Centre for Evidence-based Medicine.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.showscot.nhs.uk/sign/guidelines/index.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.showscot.nhs.uk/sign/guidelines/index.html</a> The Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network has full text and supporting material for many practice guidelines. Only a few pertain to paediatrics.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.york.ac.uk/inst/crd/welcome.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.york.ac.uk/inst/crd/welcome.htm</a> NHS Centre for Reviews &amp; Dissemination. The purpose is to promote the use of research-based knowledge in health care.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="professional-organisations">PROFESSIONAL ORGANISATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#professional-organisations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><a href="http://www.rcpch.ac.uk/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.rcpch.ac.uk/</a> The Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health site can be searched. Available are downloadable newsletters, growth references and paediatric news.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.nursepractitioner.org.uk" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.nursepractitioner.org.uk</a> A website for and about NPs in the UK. Membership of the group is free. Excellent resource for access to a large listserv of NPs in the UK and around the world.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.nmc-uk.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.nmc-uk.org</a> Nursing and Midwifery Council.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.ukcc.org.uk/cms/content/home/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.ukcc.org.uk/cms/content/home/</a> United Kingdom Central Council.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.soft.net.uk/nursinguk/index.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.soft.net.uk/nursinguk/index.html</a> UK Nursing Forum is a place where UK nurses can exchange comments, ideas, give support to each other and maintain direction. Specific areas include the UK Nurses Discussion Group, archives, a message board and links to other nursing sites.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.nursingtimes.net/Nursing" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.nursingtimes.net/Nursing</a> Times on the Net—information for UK nurses.</p>
