<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sports-medicine">SPORTS MEDICINE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sports-medicine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><a href="http://www.physportsmed.com/children.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.physportsmed.com/children.htm</a> The Physician and Sportsmedicine Online has full-text clinical and personal health articles. One section is Guidelines for Parents of Children in Sports with related articles. The site has links to other sites in the sports medicine community.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.worldortho.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.worldortho.com/</a> Full text. Electronic version of A simple guide to orthopaedics and A simple guide to trauma are available. Other orthopaedic resources are also online.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.rad.washington.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.rad.washington.edu/</a> University of Washington online teaching materials in radiology.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.medscape.com/Medscape/features/ResourceCenter/olympics/public/RC-index-olympics.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.medscape.com/Medscape/features/ResourceCenter/olympics/public/RC-index-olympics.html</a></p>
<p>Medscape’s Sports Medicine Resource Center is a collection of the latest news and information on the surgical and non-surgical treatment of musculoskeletal conditions affecting athletes—from ‘weekend warriors’ to elite competitors. This resource includes news, conference summaries, articles, MEDLINE abstracts, links to government and professional organisations, practice guidelines and practical clinical tools.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="travel-medicine">TRAVEL MEDICINE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#travel-medicine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><a href="http://www.cdc/travel" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.cdc/travel</a> This is the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) traveller’s health site. The CDC sets the standard of practice for travel health information and vaccination recommendations. All other sites obtain the majority of their information and recommendations from the CDC. Information and recommendations can be obtained by region, by disease and by travel risk or problem. Special information and articles are also featured.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.medicineplanet.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.medicineplanet.com/</a> Medicine Planet is devoted to travellers’ health for international and adventure travellers.</p>
<p>There are sections with specific information for travel of children, women, seniors, etc. One can enter an itinerary and some demographic information and receive a list of recommended immunisations and preventative measures to avoid health risks for which there is no immunisation. There are also many timely articles on travel health topics, as well as news articles with commentary on the current political situation, infectious diseases and natural disasters. The entire site can be searched.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.travmed.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.travmed.com/</a> Travel Medicine Inc. web site provides online full text of the book Travel health guide by Stuart Rose MD. Chapters cover all major health risks, including environmental problems, food and waterborne problems and infectious diseases. The last chapter, ‘World Medical Guide’, provides a country-by-country disease risk profile.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.istm.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.istm.org</a> The web site of the International Society for Travel Medicine is primarily for practitioners, but has a list of the travel clinics of their worldwide professional members. The full text of the Journal of Travel Medicine can be accessed online, but at this time cannot be searched by topic.</p>
<p>CHAPTER 7</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="paediatric-telephone-advice-and-management-for-the-nurse-practitioner">Paediatric Telephone Advice and Management for the Nurse Practitioner<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paediatric-telephone-advice-and-management-for-the-nurse-practitioner" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Lynn Hunt</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Telephone advice is increasingly being used as a tool to better manage service demand within primary care, NHS walk-in centres (WICs) and Accident and Emergency (A&amp;E) departments. In addition, the potential efficiency of telephone advice has triggered the launch of NHS Direct. As such, the telephone is an important resource for nurse practitioners (NPs) to use in a variety of patient care settings.</li>
<li>Parents/carers will phone the NP for a variety of reasons: for advice on how to manage a problem; to confirm that they are doing the right things; for reassurance generally and sometimes, to satisfy themselves that they are worrying unnecessarily.</li>
<li>Common paediatric queries include abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhoea, constipation, fever, rashes, dental queries, lacerations, insect/animal bites, respiratory system queries and questions regarding medications or ingestions.</li>
<li>The goals of paediatric telephone advice and management are summarised in Box 7.1. In order to achieve these goals, it is important that the NP establishes a good rapport; avoids jumping to conclusions; excludes irrelevant detail; keeps the telephone call manageable (in terms of time and effort expenditure); and ensures documentation is thorough but concise.</li>
<li>Two basic tenets of communication—body language and eye contact—are</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="box-7-1-goals-of-paediatric-telephone-advice-and-management">Box 7.1 Goals of paediatric telephone advice and management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#box-7-1-goals-of-paediatric-telephone-advice-and-management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>To identify all significant pathology</li>
<li>To encourage good health practices in parents/carers [including management of the child's illness and healthy preventative behaviours]</li>
<li>To relieve the child's distress/discomfort and calm anxious parents</li>
<li>To limit or decrease unnecessary health care visits</li>
<li>To contribute to efficient administration (prescription renewals, laboratory results, scheduling, follow-up, etc.)</li>
<li>To contribute to good patient relations and quality of care</li>
</ul>
<p>denied the NP managing a problem by telephone. In addition, there is no opportunity for physical examination or laboratory diagnostics to confirm clinical suspicions. Therefore, assessment, decision making and management are dependent on the NP's skills of listening and telephone data collection.</p>
<ul>
<li>Telephone rapport is very important for a successful telephone consultation. It can be conceptualised as the 4 R's, which are summarised in Table 7.1. A good rapport will help in establishing important details, increasing trust</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>Rapport characteristic</th><th>Comments</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>• Receptiveness to the caller's concerns</td><td>• Most paediatric calls come from worried and/or inexperienced parents that need acceptance and reassurance in order to increase their confidence in managing their child's illness</td></tr><tr><td>• Reassurance regarding the illness/problem</td><td>• Parents call because they are worried</td></tr><tr><td>• If the illness/problem has a name or diagnosis, explain this to the parent. Even if there is no definitive diagnosis possible (e.g. the illness is most likely due to a virus) avoid saying 'it's just a virus' as this implies a lack of understanding of the parent's and child's distress</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Reassurance regarding parenting skills</td><td>• Compliment rather than criticise (even if their only attempt at treatment has been to call the NP for advice)</td></tr><tr><td>• All reasonable attempts to care for the child should be praised</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Less than ideal home management can be corrected by suggesting 'it is probably a better idea to...'</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Reassurance regarding the availability of additional support</td><td>• Remind the parents that if the situation does not improve or if they have further questions or concerns they can call back</td></tr><tr><td>• It is also helpful to reassure parents that there is a back-up plan if the telephone advice is not sufficient (i.e. 'it is not a problem for your child to be examined, but first I need some information about his/her illness' or 'I would like you to try ___ and then give me a ring back in...'</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>7 Paediatric telephone advice and management for the nurse practitioner</p>
<p>and it may help to reveal hidden agendas (calls concerning trivial problems that conceal an underlying issue).</p>
<ul>
<li>The discussion outlined below pertains to common paediatric complaints that are not of a life-threatening nature. If the NP receives a call that is a medical emergency, the emergency services should be dispatched immediately. In these situations, the NP should use a second telephone line to alert the ambulance, while keeping the parent (and hopefully someone else to help out) on the line in order to instruct them in the ABC's (Airway, Breathing and Circulation).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="history-telephone-data-collection">HISTORY (TELEPHONE DATA COLLECTION)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history-telephone-data-collection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>If the caller is not known to the NP, it is important to identify yourself (i.e. your name), your role as a nurse practitioner (not a physician), and the organisation you are working for. Concluding the introduction with a direct query as to the problem (i.e. How can I help? or What seems to be the problem?) provides the parent/carer with the opportunity to state the presenting complaint.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Child's name, age/date of birth and gender.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Caller's name, phone number and relationship to the child.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Information related to the illness/problem:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>duration of the problem: 'When did it start?' or 'How long has it been going on for?'</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>location of the problem (including whether it is radiating or changing)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>quality: intensity, duration, sharp, dull constant, intermittent</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>quantity: the degree to which the problem is interfering with sleep, play, appetite, behaviour and intake of food and fluids</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>temporality: gradual onset versus sudden onset or a recurrent complaint; 'What started the problem?'</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>triggers: 'What started the problem and does anyone at home, school, nursery have the same symptoms?'</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>exacerbating/alleviating behaviours: e.g. 'Has any medication helped or does a certain position provide relief?'</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Determine the parent's/carer's perception of the problem, as individual understanding of symptoms and conditions vary widely. The degree to which parents are confident and knowledgeable about their child's illness will influence anxiety levels. Ask: 'What do you think is causing the problem?'.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Ask important questions first and try to cluster symptoms together (e.g. presence of nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Obtain information regarding the general state of the child: 'What has she been doing for the last hour?' (e.g. lying listlessly on the sofa, playing happily with toys, quietly watching television, etc.). Another useful question is to compare this episode of illness with previous episodes: 'Does she look sicker than the last time she had a fever?'.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Screen the parent's anxiety level, noting their tone and response during the history: 'Are you frightened by the way she looks?'.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If the parent is describing varied and unrelated symptoms, clarify what is most problematic to the parent/child at present: 'I need to know what is bothering her the most now?' or 'What are you the most worried about?'.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Determine how the parent has treated the problem so far: 'What have you done at home to manage the ...?'.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Keep questions simple without medical jargon. Parents may have trouble assessing problems such as a stiff neck or breathing difficulties. Ask instead: 'Are her lips pink?' or 'Does she move her head to follow you around the room?' or 'Can she kiss her knees or nod her head?'.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If the patient is unknown to the NP, a brief medical and family history are necessary: chronic diseases, recent illnesses, operations, hospitalisation, medication use, allergies, and usual source of care; family history of asthma, diabetes, etc.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="differential-diagnoses-telephone-decision-making">DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES (TELEPHONE DECISION MAKING)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differential-diagnoses-telephone-decision-making" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>By this point, the NP should have an understanding of the general state of the child, his symptoms, home management and parental anxiety level.</li>
<li>In addition to deciding what the child's illness or problem is likely to be, the NP needs to determine if (or when) the child needs to be examined.</li>
<li>Table 7.2 outlines these possibilities. As a general rule, approximately 3% of calls will require rapid evaluation (life-threatening, dangerous or semi-emergent complaints); 47% of calls will require the child to be evaluated (same day, next day or later in week) and the majority of calls can be managed at home (50%).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Establish a presumptive diagnosis. Given the absence of a face-to-face consultation and physical examination, it is often helpful to qualify the presumptive diagnosis by reminding the parent that it is likely that the child has a particular illness: 'I can't be sure without examining her, but it sounds like your daughter has ...'. Give the parent a diagnosis if there is one: to tell a parent that 'it is just a virus' implies a lack of sensitivity with regard to the family's distress.</li>
<li>Compliment the parent's home management of the illness and supplement/correct it (if appropriate). Occasionally, the only accurate compliment of the parent's home management might be her decision to seek advice: 'You've done the right thing calling for advice, let's chat about some things you can do at home to treat the ...'.</li>
<li>Discuss the likely/expected course of the illness with specific management: 'Sometimes children with a cold also have some loose stool, if this happens ...'</li>
<li>Review unexpected events in the illness (i.e. things to call back for). This includes (1) persistence of the symptoms; (2) a change in the child's condition or new symptoms; (3) worsening of symptoms or the child's</li>
</ul>
<p>Documentation</p>
<p>Table 7.2 Telephone Decision Making</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Decision</th><th>Examples</th><th>NP action</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>EMERGENCY SITUATION</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(approx. 3% of calls)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Life-threatening problem, emergency intervention required (care within 15 min)</td><td>• Anaphylaxis, choking, arrest, severe respiratory distress, etc.</td><td>• Organise emergency services</td></tr><tr><td>• Keep parent on the line to talk them through Heimlich manoeuvre, CPR^{a} or other applicable procedure</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Potentially dangerous situation (care within 30–60 min)</td><td>• Significant wheezing, seizures, suspicious ingestions, suspected meningitis</td><td>• Emergency services may be required</td></tr><tr><td>• Discuss recovery position, safety in the surroundings and advise on any additional procedures</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Semi-emergent problem, urgent intervention required (care within 1–2 hours)</td><td>• Possible fractures, lacerations (that are deep, profusely bleeding or over joints), fever in a young infant</td><td>• Stress urgency of situation and importance of obtaining care</td></tr><tr><td>APPOINTMENT NEEDED</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(approx. 47% of calls)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Appointment required (same day)</td><td>• Young child with a significant fever</td><td>• Remind parent of the importance of bringing child in to be seen</td></tr><tr><td>Appointment required (next day)</td><td>• Mild conjunctivitis</td><td>• Advise on actions to be taken at home until child is examined</td></tr><tr><td>Appointment required (1–2 weeks)</td><td>• Weight check</td><td>• Review management plan with family and rationale behind later appointment date</td></tr><tr><td>HOME MANAGEMENT</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(approx. 50% of calls)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Home management should be sufficient</td><td>• Chickenpox, colds, flu, nappy rash</td><td>• Discuss home management with parent</td></tr><tr><td>• See Management section</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>a CPR, cardiopulmonary resuscitation.</p>
<p>condition; (4) anxiety on the part of the parent; and/or (5) other symptoms specific to the illness that would be considered worrying (e.g. lesions on the eyes in chickenpox).</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Suggest a time frame for the advice to take effect, i.e. negotiate a reasonable time frame for a subsequent follow-up call: 'I would like you to telephone me back if there is no improvement in his activity level an hour after the paracetamol.' In emergency situations, it is likewise important to address the time frame parents should be working to: 'It is extremely important to get your child to A&amp;E within 60 minutes.' Obtain immediate feedback on the telephone advice (i.e. ask the parent to repeat the instructions back to you); if the parent is anxious, it may be helpful to have her write the important parts down and read them back. Check that the parent understands the management instructions.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Check that the parent is happy with the management plan as discussed and provide reassurance that she is able to call back if necessary.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="follow-up">FOLLOW-UP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#follow-up" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The need for continued telephone advice/management or a subsequent consultation is dependent on the parent, condition and judgement of the NP.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="medical-consult-specialist-referral">MEDICAL CONSULT/SPECIALIST REFERRAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-consult-specialist-referral" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Any child with a medical emergency.</li>
<li>Any child who appears gravely ill.</li>
<li>Any child with an unreliable or extremely anxious carer/parent.</li>
<li>Any child that is considered at risk in the opinion of the NP.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="documentation">DOCUMENTATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#documentation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Documentation is an important component of telephone advice and management as it contributes to consistency in patient care; allows for appropriate follow-up and review; and is important for liability/legal reasons. Therefore, it is vital that the documentation related to telephone</li>
</ul>
<p>advice and management is easily stored, easily accessed and provides a clear 'picture' of the call.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Many documentation formats are available (audio-taping, computer-assisted, pre-printed forms, multiple copy forms); the actual choice of documentation style/format is specific to the NPs using it.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The content to be included:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>date and time of call</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>patient's name and age (or date of birth)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>caller's name and number</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>chief complaint/reason for the call</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>historical information obtained by NP</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>advice given or telephone protocol used</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>call-back instructions negotiated with the caller</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>referrals given to caller (if appropriate) with specific time frames (e.g. 'Tour child's illness is very serious, it is important that you get her to A&amp;E within 2 hours').</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>any warnings given (if appropriate).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>CLINICAL ISSUES IN PAEDIATRICS</p>
<p>29</p>
<p>7 Paediatric telephone advice and management for the nurse practitioner</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="paediatric-pearls">PAEDIATRIC PEARLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paediatric-pearls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Telephone triage is not telephone management.</li>
<li>Most calls are not life-threatening emergencies; however, the NP must be prepared for emergency calls.</li>
<li>Telephone management skills need to be learned, practiced and reviewed (regularly). It is often helpful to have regular audits/case conferences to discuss the consultation in a group with NPs learning from each other.</li>
<li>Beware of asking too many questions, as the caller may feel criticised or interrogated. Sensitive questions need to be delayed to resist appearing intrusive. Also avoid leading questions; the caller may feel compelled to give an answer you expect, rather than one which is related to the problem. Ultimately this will not help in the decision-making process.</li>
<li>Limit management to short-term objectives: 'Let's chat about things you can do tonight and we'll see how she is in the morning.'</li>
<li>If you have any doubts or fears regarding parental understanding or reliability, or if parent/carer anxiety levels are high, the child should be seen.</li>
<li>Do not overlook the importance of documentation and frequent updating of telephone skills.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bibliography">BIBLIOGRAPHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bibliography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<p>CHAPTER 8</p>
<p>1</p>
<p>CLINICAL ISSUES IN PAEDIATRICS</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="transcultural-nursing-care">Transcultural Nursing Care<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transcultural-nursing-care" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Diane Norton and Sigrid Watt</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>In order to recognise and respect the uniqueness and dignity of every patient in our care, consideration needs to be given to their ethnicity, culture and religion; delivery of appropriate health care requires sensitivity to cultural diversity.</li>
<li>Culture has four basic characteristics: (1) it is learned from birth through the process of language acquisition and socialisation; (2) it is shared by all members of the same cultural group; (3) it is adapted to specific conditions related to environmental and technical factors and the availability of resources; and (4) it is dynamic and ever-changing.</li>
<li>Culture and illness are intrinsically linked; cultural heritage influences how we behave when well or sick and our expectations of health care. When children and their families require care, they will act and react within the context of their particular family, community and societal culture.</li>
<li>Nurse practitioners (NPs) and other health care professionals are likely to encounter children, their parents and their wider family when they are at their most vulnerable. Therefore, an awareness of various cultural practices is essential. Health care providers need to ensure they are equipped with the insight and appropriate knowledge to reduce the stress associated with illness and, thus, able to carry out culturally appropriate care.</li>
<li>Ignorance with regard to health care delivery will lead to assumptions, stereotyping and discrimination. Being</li>
</ul>
<p>misinformed, or relying upon information that is now considered out of date is also dangerous. Culture is never static, but constantly changing and evolving, and often involves the assimilation of aspects of two or more cultures.</p>
<ul>
<li>Consider the following points when gaining knowledge of a family's culture: (1) an understanding of the concept of culture; (2) an appreciation of the NP's own culture; (3) a desire to facilitate effective communication; and (4) an appreciation of the varying perceptions of health, illness and treatment across cultures.</li>
<li>An extensive knowledge of the culture and customs of all patients accessing health care is neither possible nor desirable as it may reinforce stereotypes. The following good practice points are given to encourage the consideration and delivery of individualised care.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="history">HISTORY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A good practice point for obtaining the history is always to use open-ended questions that enhance a full response.</li>
<li>Box 8.1 is a guide to the cultural assessment of the child and family within their community.</li>
<li>Box 8.2 outlines important questions to elicit a family's perception of their child's illness: In some instances (e.g. when utilising an interpreter or translator and/or when advocating for the family) it may be necessary to use close-ended questions in order to ensure clarity of feedback and to</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="box-8-1-cultural-assessment-of-the-child-and-family">Box 8.1 Cultural assessment of the child and family<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#box-8-1-cultural-assessment-of-the-child-and-family" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Structure of the family, family roles and the dynamics within the family. Communication patterns and decision making</li>
<li>Health beliefs and practices related to the cause of the disease. Treatment of altered health and the use of alternative therapies both within the home to treat the illness and/or within the community</li>
<li>Patterns of daily living, including work and leisure activities</li>
<li>Social networks, friends and neighbours. Does it influence health and altered health?</li>
<li>National, ethnic identity of family and language used</li>
<li>Nutritional practices and how they relate to cultural factors and health</li>
<li>Religious preferences, health maintenance and the impact religion might have on daily living and influence health status or care</li>
<li>Culturally appropriate behaviour styles, including what is manifested during anger. Also relationships with health professionals, between genders and relationships with groups in the community</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="box-8-2-assessment-of-illness-perception">Box 8.2 Assessment of illness perception<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#box-8-2-assessment-of-illness-perception" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>What do you think caused the problem?</li>
<li>Why do you think it started when it did?</li>
<li>What do you think your child's illness does to him?</li>
<li>How severe is your child's illness? Will it have a short or a long course?</li>
<li>What kind of treatment do you think your child should receive?</li>
<li>What results do you hope to receive from this treatment?</li>
<li>What are the major problems that your child's illness has caused for you?</li>
<li>What do you fear most about your child's illness?</li>
</ul>
<p>8 Transcultural nursing care</p>
<p>maintain privacy (both of which are important).</p>
<ul>
<li>The NP should have an awareness of the complementary healing practices that are used within the community. Although it is dangerous to assume that all complementary/alternative/ traditional approaches to healing are innocuous, the majority of practices are quite harmless (whether or not they are effective cures).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physical-examination">PHYSICAL EXAMINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Sensitivity with regard to privacy during the physical examination is important for all patients. However, there can be cultural considerations that necessitate even greater attention to privacy and/or the possibility of same gender examination. If this is potentially an issue for an individual child or family, discuss with them how they would like the physical examination to proceed.</li>
<li>Clear explanations of procedures and/or techniques used in the physical examination are good practice with all patients. However, families from other countries may or may not be familiar with medical and nursing practice as carried out in the United Kingdom. As such, care must be taken to ensure patients understand what will happen as part of the physical examination (and management plan). This is especially important for families who have a limited knowledge of English. In these instances, use of a translator is very important.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Nurse practitioners need to develop partnerships with families and acknowledge that family members provide care. There are three stages of interaction when working in partnership with a child and family: (1) family members should be encouraged to state the needs for caring as they see them; (2) the patient and carer, in conjunction with the NP, should identify the types and patterns of caring that are desired in relation to the child's needs; and (3) the patient, carer and NP should participate</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="box-8-3-cultural-considerations-regarding-hospital-admission">Box 8.3 Cultural considerations regarding hospital admission<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#box-8-3-cultural-considerations-regarding-hospital-admission" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>There may be difficulty in comprehending the rules and regulations of life on a ward, either because these have not been explained, or the routines are implicit rather than explicit (so staff do not realise they need to be explained)</li>
<li>Many cultures value the support of family and friends at a time of crisis and this is demonstrated by being at the patient's bedside. This can lead to tension around visiting times due to the number of visitors allowed at any one time</li>
<li>Some women in the Asian, and particularly Bangladeshi, community may observe purdah and find it difficult to visit or stay with their child on the ward</li>
<li>Sharing accommodation with other parents, observing prayer times, washing and eating an acceptable diet can all be difficult if resident in the hospital</li>
<li>If treatment regimens are not adhered to, this can be interpreted as non-compliance or disinterest on the part of the parents, but may be due to lack of understanding of what is required or lack of support. For the parent of a minority ethnic group, this can be compounded by lack of information about their child's illness in their own language, either in written form or from health care professionals such as the nurse specialist</li>
<li>There is a shortage of multilingual therapists in areas such as speech and language, occupational therapy, physiotherapy and social work. This can make it difficult for the family of a child requiring long-term care to get the support they need from the multidisciplinary team</li>
</ul>
<p>in devising and agreeing upon a plan of care.</p>
<ul>
<li>After a symptom is identified, the first effort at treatment is often self-care. Home management is attractive for its accessibility, potential mobilisation of the child/family's social support network and provision of a caring environment in which to convalesce. It is important, therefore, to negotiate the family's preferences with regard to home care management (and follow-up).</li>
<li>In negotiating a management plan, it is useful to consider the different communication styles displayed by the families: more specifically, the way they display fear, anxiety, concern and disagreement. In addition, it is important to appreciate the family's style with regard to responsibility and decision making.</li>
<li>There will be specific values shared by the culture that need to be appreciated when formulating the management plan. For example, the emphasis on independence found in Western culture or the conformist qualities of Asian culture which include obedience and gender-appropriate behaviour.</li>
<li>In addition, the NP must be sensitive to the difficulty some families will have in expressing their needs. This may be related to the intimidation parents feel in the strange health care environment or it may be due to the barriers created by health care jargon and/or the</li>
</ul>
<p>reluctance of many parents to discuss their culture.</p>
<ul>
<li>The importance of translators cannot be overemphasised. If English is not spoken or understood, there is likely to be difficulty in understanding the care that is being given and the reason for it.</li>
<li>Hospital admission presents special cultural considerations; these are outlined in Box 8.3.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="follow-up">FOLLOW-UP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#follow-up" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Follow-up needs to be negotiated with the same considerations used in formulating a management plan.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="paediatric-pearls">PAEDIATRIC PEARLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paediatric-pearls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Try to know and understand what support is needed. It is helpful to have information available, for children and families, explaining the terminology used by NPs and others. It is helpful if this is available in other languages.</li>
<li>Accommodate differences willingly and competently. Do not be afraid to ask the child or family if they require any particular help or care. You cannot know everything and most people are grateful to be asked.</li>
<li>Show respect by being approachable and accessible. Coping with illness can be a frightening and confusing experience for the child and family. They may express anger, fear and</li>
</ul>
<p>Bibliography</p>
<p>resentment or have many questions. Do not try to avoid them and their distress.</p>
<ul>
<li>Plan ahead to prepare for the care that may be required. Have access to contact numbers of local religious and spiritual leaders, or other members of the community whose support the family may desire.</li>
<li>Do not take over roles or impose your own beliefs or agendas. Every family is unique and, although you may have cared for someone of that faith or cultural background before, it may not follow that they require identical care.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bibliography">BIBLIOGRAPHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bibliography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<p>This page intentionally left blank</p>
<p>CHAPTER 9</p>
<p>Dermatological Problems</p>
<p>9.1 'MY CHILD HAS A RASH'</p>
<p>Jill Peters and Rosemary Turnbull</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Ill children often present with more than one symptom and one of the most common is a rash.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Because children have a developing immune system, they can develop non-specific rashes to many things. Although most rashes are benign, self-limiting and resolve completely, it is important to identify additional clinical symptomatology and rule out serious pathology. As such, this may require a follow-up visit within 24 hours.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Rashes can occur after an acute viral or bacterial infection, thus demonstrating that an infection has been present. For example, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-haemolytic streptococcal throat infection can trigger guttate psoriasis or a localised infection site can result in staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (a serious infection with a mortality rate of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">3\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">3%</span></span></span></span></span> in children).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Rashes can also occur as the main symptom of an infection—e.g. meningococcaemia, varicella (chickenpox), impetigo, etc. Some of these illness may be potentially life threatening and cannot be misdiagnosed.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In addition, rashes can be an early indication of a developing dermatoses (e.g. a follicular keratotic rash that is subsequently diagnosed as psoriasis). These children frequently require re-evaluation, as the early presentation is unclear and it is not until the rash is more florid than a definitive diagnosis can be made.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Once children enter nursery or school they will often pick up infections from their peers: e.g. chickenpox, impetigo, tinea capitis, etc.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Older children may complain of rashes that are similar to adults in presentation: e.g. urticaria, pompholyx, prurigo and erythema multiforme.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Management of skin diseases will require extra consultation time to: (1) explain the problem to the parent/carer and child; (2) outline the dermatoses; (3) discuss how the therapies will work; and (4) describe the progression to resolution/ improvement. Anxiety runs high because scratching can distress the child and disturb the whole family. Support from other professionals may be required as the skin care needs of the child may be labour intensive and, as such, the implications of this for the family will need to be considered within their individual dynamic.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Inflammatory dermatoses can occur within hours but take days to weeks to resolve. This can be extra distressing to the parent/carer as well as the older child if the face and hands are affected. Parents/carers want 'a cure' and do not want to hear about a skin condition that can develop into a chronic disease.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Skin diseases in ethnic patients can present a diagnostic challenge because of variations in clinical appearance that may be attributable to racial characteristics and/or inflammatory disease. In addition, certain disorders can be unique to some populations. Examples include traction alopecia (the tight pleating of hair putting so much tension onto the hair that it breaks); or FACE, Facial Afro-Caribbean Childhood Eruption (monomorphic, flesh-coloured or hypopigmented papules which occur around the mouth, eyelids and ears, persist for several months and then resolve without scarring).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pathophysiology">PATHOPHYSIOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The newborn dermis is less mature. As such, there is less organisation of vascular and nerve structures and decreased collagen and elastic fibres. It is not until 2 years of age that the dermis has an adult-like form.</li>
<li>A child's skin needs to be treated carefully, as many external factors make the skin vulnerable: e.g. soaps containing detergents, sunlight/heat and antigens in the environment like the house dust mite.</li>
<li>The child's rash could be a manifestation of systemic illness.</li>
<li>Skin changes occur in adolescence with the onset of puberty. The skin becomes greasier as the hormone androgen stimulates sebum production and the hair likewise becomes lankier and greasier.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="history">HISTORY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The subjective assessment of the patient should include the components</li>
</ul>
<p>9 Dermatological problems</p>
<p>of an episodic history, as outlined previously (see Ch. 4).</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Note that the family and child (if appropriate) should describe the skin condition in their own words and the history should include an assessment of the family's expectation of the consultation. The agenda that parents/carers have may be broader than solely the management of the rash. This is especially true when social issues are involved.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Problem to be addressed in the consultation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>How and when did the rash start?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>What did it look like at first, compared to now?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>What time lapse has occurred since the onset of the rash: hours, days or months?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>How long was the lesion present on the skin? e.g. hours as in urticaria or weeks as in eczema.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Site of initial lesion (target lesion) and subsequent course of the rash (e.g. from where did the rash spread and in what kind of distribution). An example is pityriasis rosea, which has a herald patch (2–5 cm) occurring several days prior to the appearance of the main rash.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Symptoms experienced: itch, dryness, redness, pain, and/or warmth. An analogue scoring mechanism can be useful with older children to assist in determining severity.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Treatment tried at home (with results).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Has this ever occurred previously and what was the outcome?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Anything that happened prior to the development of the rash that could be considered a 'trigger' or precursor (e.g. tingling, pruritus, tenderness, trauma, localised increase in temperature, etc.).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Accompanying systemic symptoms (fever, joint soreness, sore throat, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, etc.).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Does the rash improve at the weekends or when on holiday?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Recent travel, either abroad or outside of their normal environment (e.g. school trip to a forest).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>New activity or hobby.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Activities that can no longer be done.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Animals in the house.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>New medication or anything bought over the counter (including herbal or homeopathic remedies).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Use of recreational drugs.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sun exposure: have they lived abroad, sun protection factor (SPF) used, influence of the sun on the skin condition in any way.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any family history of atopy, psoriasis or skin cancer.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any other members of the family with the same symptoms? Any classmates off ill?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>What initiated skin enquiry and any fears or anxieties regarding it?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Changes in fluid or dietary intake?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Recent and significant weight loss?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any lesions in the mouth?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Is the sleep pattern disturbed, less attentive at school?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Alcohol intake?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Smoking?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any aggravating/relieving factors?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>What do they think is wrong with the child (or themselves) and expected outcomes (including any other agenda of the parent/carer).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physical-examination">PHYSICAL EXAMINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A full skin examination should be carried out in a warm and private room with good natural lighting or artificial lighting that will not change the natural colour of the skin. A good magnified lamp is useful when assessing lesions as it allows for use of perpendicular lighting when looking for subtle skin changes. If the consultation takes place in the patient's home, use natural lighting where possible; otherwise, take a small portable light with a magnifying lens.</li>
<li>If the rash is a symptom of a systemic illness, a complete physical examination will be required.</li>
<li>Observe the child's overall appearance including physical bearing, posture and dress, as these may indicate unhappiness, loss of self-esteem or confidence, anger or embarrassment (adolescence). The skin is a window into the patient's inner feelings and is often reflected through their facial expression before any words are spoken. For example, an unhappy child who is distressed, irritated and appears</li>
</ul>
<p>unwell is manifesting systemic effects of an inflammatory disease process (e.g. a child with acute atopic eczema is visually distressed whereas a child with seborrhoeic dermatitis is not).</p>
<ul>
<li>It is essential to examine all the skin from head to toe (including skin folds). Thus, undressing children down to their underclothes will likely require some explanation, especially if the lesion is on the face. It is often helpful to inform the child and family that affected skin needs to be compared with unaffected skin and that no lesion/rash should be looked at in isolation. In addition, parents often do not relate a rash on one part of the body to another part and/or there is a possibility that additional lesions may be identified (the chance of detecting a melanoma is 6.4 times greater with a complete skin examination than with a partial examination of just exposed skin). Note that there will need to be an awareness/sensitivity to cultural or religious differences as well as potential embarrassment.</li>
<li>Use the fingertips to lightly run over the surface of the skin in order to appreciate subtle differences in texture and the changes that occur with pressure. Note that skin is more sensitive when inflamed and streptococcus infection is more painful than staphylococcus infection.</li>
<li>Palpate around the edge of the lesion in order to identify infiltration, texture (i.e. hard, soft or encapsulated) and lesion depth.</li>
<li>Flex the skin between finger and thumb to check for scale (tinea) or to induce scale in lesions where it is not readily apparent (e.g. pityriasis versicolor). Look for scaling in the skin creases of palms and soles as a possible indicator of fungal infection.</li>
<li>Use a light source that is perpendicular to the lesions in order to highlight the lesion elevation and any epidermal changes.</li>
<li>Look for signs of excoriation, as patients often do not admit to scratching.</li>
<li>Note that the distribution of the lesions may assist in diagnosis (e.g. unilateral rash along a dermatome is likely to be herpes zoster).</li>
<li>Examine the mucosa with good light.</li>
</ul>
<p>9.1 'My child has a rash'</p>
<ul>
<li>Check through the hair (parting it on a continuous basis all over the scalp) and look behind the ears (i.e. psoriasis and/or seborrhoeic dermatitis). Also press firmly on the scalp for texture. If it is boggy, think infection (depending on what you see on the scalp, either bacterial or fungal).</li>
<li>Document findings on a body chart that can indicate the severity and distribution of the presenting rash. In the case of pigmented lesions or wounds, measurements should be taken. Record any analogue scores for comparison on future visits.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="differential-diagnoses">DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differential-diagnoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The differential list is broad but it is helpful to organise commonly encountered rashes by their aetiological category (Table 9.1).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Specific management is aetiology-dependent. Basic principles are outlined below.</p>
<ul>
<li>Additional diagnostics: consider bacterial or viral swabs, fungal skin scrapings, nail clippings and hair debris. A rash that is possibly related to a systemic illness may require blood work, urinalysis or other diagnostics.</li>
<li>Pharmacotherapeutics: depending on the diagnosis, medications can be topical or systemic. Note that it is important to be correct in your diagnosis if systemic therapies are to be used. Irrespective of route, a full discussion of the medication dose, technique of application (if topical), frequency and length of course is required. If antihistamines are used for itching, especially if scratching results in sleep loss and reduced concentration levels, the impact of potential drowsiness requires consideration, such as effect on school attendance. Likewise, the choice and preference of the parent/carer/child needs to be considered with regard to the emollient prescribed. In addition,</li>
</ul>
<p>it is important that careful thought is given to the impact of the child's care on the family unit.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Behavioural interventions:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Encourage frequent applications of topical emollients if the skin is hot, itchy or very scaly. Emollients in tubes or decanted (careful with infection control, small amounts, clean technique) would enable children to take them to school. Emollient application before and after swimming allows the child to safely participate in the activity and reduce exclusion by peers.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Psychological support for the family is important. A skin disease or cutaneous change due to systemic illness can be very distressing by its visual appearance and its perception by others. Lower self-esteem, embarrassment and feelings of social isolation can exacerbate or maintain a dermatoses and lead to poor concordance with topical therapies. Support may be required for the carer/parent who has to deliver the daily care; be sure to assess their needs as well as those of the child.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If the rash is not a self-limiting and benign condition, the expertise of other professionals may be required. For example, the school nurse may need to educate teachers/pupils and provide help with contact tracing and/or surveillance in an outbreak situation. Likewise, the paediatric community team may be required to support home care, assess the home environment and support the family.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Patient education:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Discuss with the child and family the cause of the rash and the rationale for its management. Understanding the cause relieves guilt and feelings of shame with regard to the skin condition. Children with skin conditions can be targeted by bullies; health promotion to empower the child will disempower the bully.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Review with families the disease process, possible triggers (and strategies to deal with them) and the use of topical therapies to reduce discomfort and minimise the appearance of the rash.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Remind families that they need to complete the full course of treatment rather than stopping as soon as things are starting to look better.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Complete the family-held Child Health Record in order to assist in the continuity of care. (All children under 5 years of age should have one.)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Provide written information to complement verbal instructions (essential).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="follow-up">FOLLOW-UP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#follow-up" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Follow-up is aetiology-dependent with referral if the diagnosis is not clear. Some families will welcome a follow-up phone call if anxiety levels are running high. This is also true for children whose rash is associated with a systemic illness that may require monitoring.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="medical-consult-specialist-referral">MEDICAL CONSULT/ SPECIALIST REFERRAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-consult-specialist-referral" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Any child in whom the diagnosis is unclear.</li>
<li>Any child with a gravely ill appearance.</li>
<li>Any child who presents with a dermatological emergency, e.g. eczema herpeticum.</li>
<li>Any child requiring specialist intervention or expertise.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="paediatric-pearls">PAEDIATRIC PEARLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paediatric-pearls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Dermatology is very visual: do not diagnose over the telephone as not everybody has the same skill for description.</li>
<li>Always examine all of the skin; do not forget the hair, nails and mouth.</li>
<li>Touch is a powerful tool.</li>
<li>Purchase a good colour picture dermatology book and keep it handy as a reference.</li>
<li>Develop a close link with your local paediatric dermatology nurse specialist; he/she is an invaluable resource.</li>
</ul>
<p>9 Dermatological problems</p>

Located on trunk and precedes development of macular, papular, scaly rash of discrete lesions of varying sizes.
