<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="9-2-acne">9.2 ACNE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#9-2-acne" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Julie Carr</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Acne is a term derived from the Greek word ‘acme’ meaning prime of life. It is almost universal in teenagers, with an estimated 85% of people experiencing some degree of acne during their teenage years.</li>
<li>It comes at a time when body image is of great importance and any deviation from being ‘less than perfect’ can provoke anxiety. Acne patients are often described as being self-conscious and having a low self-esteem. Consequently, they may also become dissatisfied with other aspects of their body image such as their weight or shape (dysmorphophobia).</li>
<li>Acne can persist into adulthood and, left untreated, may cause physical and psychological scarring. Fortunately, modern treatment is effective, and teenagers with acne are no longer dismissed or told they will ‘grow out of it’. Treated appropriately and quickly, acne can be controlled or even cured with good cosmetic results.</li>
<li>Health care professionals have an important role in recognising the psychological impact of acne on a young person. Optimising management through good communication and support before, during and following therapies is essential.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="pathophysiology">PATHOPHYSIOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Acne is a disease of the sebaceous follicle which occurs predominantly on the face, chest and upper torso. The normal pilosebaceous unit consists of sebaceous glands, a rudimentary hair and a wide follicular duct lined with stratified squamous epithelial cells (Fig. 9.1).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>During normal epidermal desquamation (shedding), epithelial cells are transported via the follicular duct by sebum secreted from the sebaceous glands. The glands require androgens to stimulate sebum secretion and there is a significant increase of androgenic hormone during puberty.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251224-a53d691e.jpeg" alt="img-1.jpeg">
Figure 9.1 Anatomy of the skin.</p>
<p>9.2 Acne</p>
<ul>
<li>With acne, there is hyperproliferation of the cells lining the follicular duct. The cells adhere to the duct walls and, combine with sebum and bacteria, which results in a partial obstruction of the follicular duct. This process is visible on the skin surface as a comedone, which has either a black (open) or white (closed) head; and is commonly referred to as a 'blackhead' or a 'whitehead'. The black colour of the plugs is due to pigment (not dirt), as comedones are the precursors of both non-inflamed and inflamed acne lesions.</li>
<li>In addition, the obstructed ducts become colonised by propionobacterium (Propionibacterium acnes). This dilates the ducts further, due to the release of inflammatory mediators such as cytokines. The ducts will continue to dilate until the rupturing process discharges the contents into the surrounding tissues. These foreign bodies are an irritant and contribute to the inflammatory response seen in most forms of acne.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="history">HISTORY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Age of onset (commonly appears during Tanner stage II).</li>
<li>Areas affected.</li>
<li>Current skin care regimens and previously tried regimens with outcomes (including results of prescriptions and over-the-counter products used).</li>
<li>Presence of androgen-related symptoms (amenorrhoea, hirsutism, obesity) and age at menarche (females).</li>
<li>Perceived triggers: cosmetics and/or occupational exposures (note that chocolate, nuts, sweets, shellfish and fatty foods have not been shown to have an effect on acne severity).</li>
<li>Medications: oral contraceptives, phenytoin or steroids.</li>
<li>Family history of acne.</li>
<li>Degree of emotional upset or effect that the acne has on the individual (including interpersonal relationships, employment/school, self-image/ self-esteem and general body image).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="physical-examination">PHYSICAL EXAMINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>General observation: dress, interpersonal communication, eye contact, etc., may give indication of self-esteem issues.</li>
<li>Skin: inspection of affected areas (face, neck, chest, back, etc.) to determine the degree of skin greasiness; types of lesions present (open/closed comedones, papules, pustules and cysts); number of each type, distribution and intensity of inflammation. Examine for presence of scarring, keloid formation or hyperpigmentation (post-inflammatory changes). Note that there can be involvement of thighs, buttocks and upper arms.</li>
<li>Assess adolescent females with severe acne for potential androgenic disorder (e.g. polycystic ovary syndrome): evaluate for obesity, hirsutism and alopecia.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="differential-diagnoses">DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differential-diagnoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The diagnosis of acne vulgaris in adolescents is usually clear-cut; however, consider the possibility of obstructed sebaceous follicles caused by cosmetics (this is called cosmetic acne, when moisturising creams or oil-containing hair products cause acne); occupational exposures (mineral oil, petroleum, coal tar and pitch are triggers); and medications (androgens, steroids, lithium, phenytoin, isoniazid, rifampin and some combined oral contraceptives that contain an androgenic progesterone component, e.g. norethisterone).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In addition there are numerous acne variants:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Acne excoriée is an acne variant usually associated with young female patients who relentlessly pick at their skin; it requires psychological input as it can be obsessional and/or destructive in nature.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Infantile acne is quite common in early infancy and is probably related to transplacental stimulation of sebaceous glands; it resolves spontaneously.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Nodulocytic acne (acne conglobata) is a severe type of acne more commonly affecting males. This form is characterised by nodules, sinuses and abscesses; it is more prone to scarring and requires oral retinoids.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Acne fulminans (rare) is largely seen in males who have extensive truncated lesions (that may be an immune reaction to P. acnes). Patients can be unwell with malaise, fever and general systemic upset; this form of acne requires oral retinoids.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="management">MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Management decisions are guided by the type of acne lesions present (Table 9.2) in addition to the extent/number of each type, intensity of inflammation and degree of scarring and/or pigment changes. However, although this approach is helpful in clinical decision making, it does not necessarily reflect the amount of emotional upset the adolescent may be suffering. Treatment regimens need to balance the extent of the acne with the effect it is having on the adolescent's quality of life, self-image and self-esteem.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Type</th><th>Characteristics</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Papule</td><td>• Inflammatory lesion (&lt;5 mm) that occurs (usually superficially) within the follicle; can present as a 'bump' under the skin surface</td></tr><tr><td>Comedone</td><td>• Blocked follicular duct; can be open (blackhead) or closed (whitehead)</td></tr><tr><td>Pustule</td><td>• Inflammation and exudate around the comedo; lesion has a visible central core of purulent material</td></tr><tr><td>Nodule</td><td>• Inflammatory lesion (&gt;5 mm) occurring with deeper inflammation within the follicle; more likely to scar</td></tr><tr><td>Cyst</td><td>• A sac containing pus or other products from deep inflammation of the follicle; more likely to scar</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>44</p>

<p>45</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="systemic-treatments">Systemic treatments<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#systemic-treatments" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>|  Oral antibiotics | • Moderate to severe | • Decreases population of <em>P. acnes</em> | • Less expensive | • Side-effects include: gastrointestinal upset and candidal infections
• Resistance can develop
• Interactions with other medications (including oral contraceptives) can occur | • Not indicated for non-inflammatory comedonal acne
• Oxytetracycline: absorption affected by food, milk, etc.; give 30 min before or 4 hours after last meal; contraindicated in children &lt;8 years of age or pregnancy
• Minocycline: use if-resistant to tetracycline
• Use over 4–6 month period and if effective continue for longer
• Reduce dose of antibiotics after 6–8 weeks to lowest dose that maintains clear skin  |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
|  Oral retinoids | • Severe, nodulocytic acne | • Reduce inflammation by 90% in 1 month | • Useful when self-esteem and self-image issues are affecting quality of life | • Only available under consultant dermatologist supervision and after all other treatments have failed | • If relapse occurs, another course can be attempted or a retry of other treatments
• Side-effects to be discussed include teratogenicity, mucous membrane dryness, increased liver enzymes and cholesterol levels, blurred vision, headaches, photosensitivity, pruritus and worsening of eczema, possibility of mood swings and depression (rare)
• Requires regular growth monitoring if younger adolescent
• Requires regular full blood test (FBC), fasting lipids and liver function test (LFT) prior to commencing treatment and then monthly
• Females require counselling with regard to effective contraception  |
|  Isotretinoin (Roaccutane) | • Acne resistant to other therapies | • Reduce backerial colonisation by 90% in 1 month
• Reduce sebum production by 90% in 1 month | • Useful with cystic acne or if scarring is problematic
• Single 16-week course gives 75% cure rate | • Numerous side-effects which require in-depth discussion with adolescent and parents
• Highly teratogenic |   |
|  Hormonal therapy | • Acne related to endocrine disorder (polycystic ovaries) | • Blocks androgen receptors
• Provides contraception | • Especially effective with adolescents with polycystic ovaries and mild hirsutism | • Can only be used with females | • Careful consideration required when treating young women with acne
• Provides simultaneous contraception  |</p>
<p>*BNF = British National Formulary, published by British Medical Association and Royal Pharmaceutical Society of Great Britain.</p>
<p>COMMON PAEDIATRIC PROBLEMS</p>
<p>9 Dermatological problems</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Additional diagnostics: none generally required. Consider evaluating adolescent girls with severe acne (with or without evidence of hirsutism) for an androgenic disorder (polycystic ovaries, adrenal hyperplasia). Evaluation includes luteinising hormone (LH), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), free and total testosterone and dehydroepiandosterone (DHEA).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pharmacotherapeutics: See Table 9.3; note that numerous preparations are available, with new generations released frequently.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Behavioural interventions:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Skin should be washed a maximum of twice a day with a mild soap or non-astringent cleanser. The areas should not be scrubbed with abrasive cleansers or pads. Likewise avoid alcohol, astringents and oil-based cosmetics and/or moisturisers.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Strict adherence to treatment regimen is vital.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Do not pick, squeeze or scratch at lesions and try to keep hair off the face/forehead.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Patient education:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Reassure adolescents that acne is treatable, even curable, but that it takes work and strict adherence to treatment regimens. Let them know that sometimes things get slightly worse before getting better, but they can usually expect improvement after 3–6 weeks.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Review treatment instructions and behavioural interventions; provide written information for reinforcement and a contact phone number for future questions/concerns.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Discuss acne ‘myths’ (such as chocolate, fats, sugar or poor hygiene causing acne). Additional support can be gained from the acne support group (tel: 0208-561-6868 or <a href="http://www.stopspots.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.stopspots.org</a>).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Remind adolescents to return immediately for additional help if they feel their acne is interfering with their ability to ‘enjoy life’ or they are unhappy with how their treatment is progressing.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="follow-up">FOLLOW-UP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#follow-up" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The adolescent will probably require follow-up contact, support and encouragement throughout his treatment. In addition, subsequent visits allow for potential side-effects to be assessed; fine-tuning of skin care regimes; and monitoring of the psychological impact that acne can have on adolescents.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="medical-consult-specialist-referral">MEDICAL CONSULT/SPECIALIST REFERRAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-consult-specialist-referral" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Any adolescent with moderate to severe acne, which is non-responsive to topical treatments and/or courses of antibiotics taken for at least 6 months.</li>
<li>Any adolescent with nodulocystic acne (acne conglobata).</li>
<li>Any adolescent who presents with scarring.</li>
<li>Any adolescent who presents with psychological problems related to their acne.</li>
<li>Any adolescent female whose acne may be related to an ovarian or endocrine abnormality such as polycystic ovary syndrome.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="paediatric-pearls">PAEDIATRIC PEARLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paediatric-pearls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Acne is a very treatable skin disorder that should always be taken seriously and never trivialised. Early referral to a GP or dermatologist is essential to prevent scarring and psychological problems; the short- and long-term consequences to an adolescent’s psychological and emotional well-being should not be underestimated.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Patient compliance with all acne treatments is vital and should be monitored and discussed on a regular basis.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Frequent, vigorous washing or excessive scrubbing of the face with abrasives is unnecessary and may lead to dermatitis.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Although astringents and alcohols make the skin’s surface less oily, they have minimal effect on acne and may irritate the skin and/or stimulate oil production.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The combination of benzyl peroxide in the morning and topical retinoid at night may be beneficial when either agent alone has been unsuccessful.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Both soap and previous applications of topical medicines must be thoroughly washed off the skin before any further topical applications.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stress has a reciprocal effect on acne: it seems to make it worse, which further heightens the adolescent’s anxiety, decreases self-esteem and creates more stress.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bibliography">BIBLIOGRAPHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bibliography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Boston M. Treating patients with acne vulgaris. Pract Nurs 1997; 8(15):27–29.
Buxton PK. ABC of dermatology, 3rd edn. London: BMJ Publishing; 1998:47–51.
Chu T, Munn S, Basarab T. Acne. In: Maxim M, ed., Current issues in dermatology, 2nd edn. London: Imperial College of Science, Technology and Medicine; 1998:19.
Cooley S, Atkinson P, Parks D, et al. Management of acne vulgaris. J Pediatr Health Care 1998; 12(1):38–40.

Gupta MA, Gupta AK, Schork NJ, et al. Psychiatric aspects of the treatment of mild to moderate facial acne: some preliminary observations. Int J Dermatol 1990; 29:719–721.

<p>9.3 Atopic eczema</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="9-3-atopic-eczema">9.3 ATOPIC ECZEMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#9-3-atopic-eczema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Jean Robinson</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Atopic eczema is a chronic pruritic inflammation of the epidermis and dermis with a strong genetic aetiological component that is associated with other atopic conditions (asthma, rhinitis and seasonal allergies).</li>
<li>Also known as atopic dermatitis (synonymous term often used interchangeably with atopic eczema) it affects all ethnic groups and current estimates suggest that somewhere between 5 and 20% of children in developed countries will develop eczema. The prevalence appears to be increasing, probably due to a combination of genetic and environmental factors.</li>
<li>The main types of eczema seen in childhood are atopic and seborrhoeic eczema. Other inflammatory skin conditions (irritant eczema, contact dermatitis and pompholyx) are seen less commonly (see Sec. 9.10).</li>
<li>Atopic eczema usually starts in the first year of life (often on the face) before spreading to the limbs; up to 90% of these children will grow out of it by the time they reach their teens. The prognosis is less optimistic for those who develop it after the age of 1 year.</li>
<li>The condition is chronic and may be exacerbated by infection (bacterial and/or viral) as well as by irritants. Atopic eczema can have tremendous physical, psychological and social effects on children and their families; these should not be underestimated.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diagnosis">DIAGNOSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>There is no specific laboratory test available, so diagnosis is made on clinical grounds. For a diagnosis to be made, the child must have pruritus, plus three or more of the following. Note that itching is such a prominent feature of eczema that if it is not present, another diagnosis should be considered (see list of differential diagnoses).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>History of itchiness in the skin creases such as folds of the elbows, behind the knees, fronts of the ankles and/or around the neck, the cheeks and behind the ears (in children under 4 years of age).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>History of asthma or hay fever or history of atopic disease in a first-degree relative of a child less than 4 years old.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>General dry skin in past year.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Visible flexural eczema or eczema involving the cheeks or forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years. Note that Asian, Black African or Afro-Caribbean children sometimes show a reverse pattern of extensor eczema and are also more likely to produce lichenification, papular or follicular eczema and marked areas of hypo- or hyperpigmented, post-inflammatory pigment changes.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Onset of symptoms in the first 2 years of life (not always diagnostic in children under 4 years of age).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology">PATHOPHYSIOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The aetiology of eczema is multifactorial, with genetic, environmental, physiological and immunological factors all playing a role. The skin is chronically dry with decreased pliability, most likely related to changes in lipid content (which allow increased epidermal water loss). The resultant skin barrier becomes less effective, with a greater risk of irritant penetration.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Inflammation of the epidermis (with associated oedema) leads to the formation of intraepidermal blisters, which can rupture and give rise to exudation and crusting (acute phase). In addition, concomitant pruritus (the aetiology of which is poorly understood) results in an itch-rub-scratch cycle which causes increased epidermal regeneration and thickening (subacute and chronic phases).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Meanwhile, the upper dermis becomes flooded with white blood cells (that leak out of the vessels and pass up into the epidermis), thus exacerbating the inflammation. It is thought these T cells drive the epidermal inflammatory process, although many patients also have elevated levels of immunoglobulin E (IgE).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="history">HISTORY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Age of onset, distribution and characteristics of the eczema.</li>
<li>Family history of atopic-associated conditions (asthma, allergies, hay fever and/or others with eczema) or history of these in patient.</li>
<li>General growth and development.</li>
<li>Sleep patterns (especially whether itching awakens at night).</li>
<li>Diet history, including whether any particular food(s) seems to trigger a flare-up.</li>
<li>Bathing history/habits, including frequency and use of soaps, moisturisers, bubble bath, etc.</li>
<li>Details of previous treatments and their effectiveness.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physical-examination">PHYSICAL EXAMINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Systematic head-to-toe examination of the skin with inspection of all areas of the body. Note:</p>
<ul>
<li>Distribution and pattern of dryness and lesions (often age-related, see Diagnosis).</li>
<li>Detailed examination of lesions, noting the presence of erythema, scaling, crusting, exudate and excoriation. In addition, examine lesions for blisters, pustules, papules and lichenification. Compare lesions for differences and note size.</li>
<li>Other associated findings include pityriasis alba (scattered, dry white patches), infraorbital darkening, facial</li>
</ul>
<p>9 Dermatological problems</p>
<p>Table 9.4 Differential Diagnoses of Atopic Eczema</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Consider</th><th>Distinguishing features</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Allergic/contact eczema (dermatitis)</td><td>• Erythema, oozing and vesicles as in atopic eczema but distribution is usually limited</td></tr><tr><td>• History provides clue to trigger</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Elimination of irritant usually initiates resolution</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Histiocytic disorders (rare)</td><td>• Reddish papules may appear purpuric (in groins, neck and axillae)</td></tr><tr><td>• Signs of systemic illness</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Lymphadenopathy</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Nummular (discoid) eczema</td><td>• Characterised by well-defined, coin-shaped lesions that may be dry and scaly or oozing and crusted</td></tr><tr><td>• Usually on limbs, rarely on face</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Psoriasis</td><td>• Silvery scales prominent feature in well demarcated, thickened areas (see psoriasis)</td></tr><tr><td>Scabies</td><td>• Extremely pruritic papules (may be increased at bedtime)</td></tr><tr><td>• Commonly found in interdigital spaces, palms of hands, soles of feet and penis</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Scrapings may reveal mites, eggs and/or faeces</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Symptoms often present in other family members and of fairly recent onset</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Seborrhoeic dermatitis</td><td>• Itching is not prominent or may be absent; greasy yellow scales</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>pallor and keratosis pilaris (dry rough hair follicles on extensor surfaces of upper arms and thighs), hyperlinear palms and ichthyosis vulgaris (marked scaling in the absence of inflammation).</p>
<p><strong>DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>See Table 9.4.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>MANAGEMENT</strong></p>
<p>It is vital that health care providers work in partnership with parents/carers, as management is not curative but rather aims to achieve symptom control. Atopic eczema is characterised by periods of flare-up and remission, both of which require interventions tailored to the severity of the symptoms. A triple therapy approach is suitable for most children: (1) bath oils and soap substitutes for cleansing; (2) regular and liberal use of moisturisers and (3) intermittent use of the least-potent steroid preparation.</p>
<ul>
<li>Additional diagnostics: no tests are diagnostic for atopic eczema. Skin biopsy can be used to rule out other</li>
</ul>
<p>papulosquamous disease (e.g. psoriasis). Consider cultures (viral, Tzanck smear and/or bacterial) if lesions appeared infected. Patch testing can help to differentiate atopic eczema from allergic or contact eczema. Blood results often reveal elevated levels of IgE, especially in cases of severe eczema. Full blood count (FBC) may show eosinophilia.</p>
<p><strong>Pharmacotherapeutics:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Bath oils include products such as Oilatum, Hydromol Emollient and Balneum Plus.</li>
<li>Soap substitutes for bathing include aqueous cream and/or emulsifying ointment.</li>
<li>Moisturisers/emollients include: Diprobase, Oily cream and white soft paraffin/liquid paraffin (50% WSP: 50% LP).</li>
<li>Topical steroids are used to control flare-ups (Table 9.5), with higher potency preparations used in the acute phase and tapering to lower potency when control is achieved. Once the skin has cleared, judicious emollient use may be all that is needed.</li>
<li>Antihistamines are used for their sedative effect. They don't control</li>
</ul>
<p>the itch as it is not histamine-mediated. They can be successfully used 1 hour before bedtime. While not addictive, use should be monitored and administered only when necessary (Table 9.6).</p>
<ul>
<li>Systemic steroids are rarely indicated and generally reserved for when control of the eruption is very difficult (and then for short-duration use only).</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Behavioural interventions:</strong></p>
<p>compliance/adherence to treatments is a mainstay of daily control; it is vital that parents understand their role and the importance of the following:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Cleansing routines:</strong> daily bath in warm (not hot) water with added oil and use of a soap substitute to cleanse the skin of dry scales and crusts. Avoid all soaps and bath additives as they can irritate the skin. These will make the bath slippery so children need to be supervised. After soaking in the water the child should be patted, not rubbed dry.</li>
<li><strong>Moisturisers:</strong> should be applied as often as needed in order to stop the skin drying out. This may need to be up to 5 or 6 times daily. They should be applied in a thin layer with sweeping motions (in the direction of hair growth) and allowed to soak in. In general, the more occlusive the topical product, the more effective it is at sealing in moisture; thus, the best moisturiser is the greasiest the child and family will tolerate and use. However, older children may find lighter moisturisers more aesthetically acceptable to use. Children may need up to 500 g, every 1–2 weeks. Occlusive moisturisers (applied after the skin is hydrated in the bath) seal water in and are very important. Lotions are the least helpful of moisturisers as they often contain more water, alcohol, preservatives and fragrance.</li>
<li><strong>Occlusive bandages:</strong> applied over topical steroids, they increase steroid absorption to improve effectiveness; provide a barrier to scratching; and maintain a constant environment for the skin (which reduces pruritus). They are helpful in treating areas of</li>
</ul>
<p>9.3 Atopic eczema</p>
<p>2</p>
<p>COMMON PAEDIATRIC PROBLEMS</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="table-9-5-topical-steroids">Table 9.5 Topical Steroids<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#table-9-5-topical-steroids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>General considerations of use</p>
<ul>
<li>Use as second-line intervention (after hydration and moisturising) and to control flare-ups.</li>
<li>Use only on red, itchy inflamed areas and lowest potency possible.</li>
<li>Do not use more than twice daily; some newer steroids are designed for once daily use.</li>
<li>Apply sparingly: e.g. 'only enough to make the skin look shiny'.</li>
<li>Use ointment formulations in preference to creams as they are greasier; the exception is wet or weepy eczema (use creams).</li>
<li>Apply steroid 20–30 min after applying moisturiser to prevent dilution of steroid effect.</li>
<li>Topical steroids are classified by potency; in older children mild or moderate potency steroids may be used on the body; use only mild steroids on the face and nappy area.</li>
<li>Long-term use can lead to skin atrophy, telangiectasia and, occasionally, interference with growth; this is not a concern with mild or moderate potency steroids.</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>Group potency</th><th>Chemical name</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Mild</td><td>• 0.5% hydrocortisone</td></tr><tr><td>• 1% hydrocortisone</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Moderate</td><td>• 0.05% clobetasone butyrate (Eumovate)</td></tr><tr><td>• 0.025% betamethasone valerate (Betnovate-RD)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Potent</td><td>• 0.1% betamethasone valerate (Betnovate)</td></tr><tr><td>• 0.1% mometasone furoate (Elocon)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Very potent</td><td>• 0.05% clobetasol propionate (Dermovate)</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="table-9-6-antihistamines">Table 9.6 Antihistamines<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#table-9-6-antihistamines" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Name</th><th>Dosage</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Hydroxyzine</td><td>• 6 months to 6 years: 5–15 mg once at night (maximum dose = 50 mg)</td></tr><tr><td>• 7–12 years: 15–25 mg once at night (maximum dose = 50–100 mg)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• 12–18 years: 25 mg once at night (maximum dose = 100 mg)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Note: increase dose as necessary (in 3–4 divided doses). Do not exceed maximum daily dosages</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Promethazine</td><td>• 1–12 months of age: 5–10 mg at bedtime</td></tr><tr><td>• 1–5 years: 10–20 mg at bedtime</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• 6–10 years: 20–25 mg at bedtime</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• 10 years: 25–50 mg at bedtime</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Usually needs to be given 2 hours before desired onset of effect</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Cautious use in infants &lt;1 year of age due to a possible association with sudden infant death syndrome</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Trimeprazine</td><td>• &gt;6 months of age: 1 mg/kg/day in 3–4 divided doses</td></tr><tr><td>• In chronic eczema an increased dosage may be needed (1.5–3 mg/kg/day) but omit daytime doses</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>lichenification on limbs (they cannot be used on the trunk) and, as such, are not a first-line treatment. Children requiring this level of intervention need medical referral. Impregnated paste bandages (e.g. Ichthopaste or Viscopaste PB7) are applied in a pleating fashion over an application of topical steroid. The pleating allows for shrinkage and drying of the bandage, which otherwise could cause constriction of the limb and blood supply. A second outer bandage of Coban is applied to keep the paste bandage in</p>
<p>place. The bandages can be left in place for up to 3 days. Close supervision (and support) are needed with treatment and there is some risk of steroid absorption.</p>
<ul>
<li>Wet wrap: can be used to treat all of the skin, including the face. It is a very time-consuming procedure and is generally used in hospital to treat children with erythrodermic eczema (a large area of the child’s body is abnormally red, flaking and thickened). It involves the application of a double layer of tubular gauze bandage (cut to fit the</li>
</ul>
<p>child’s legs, arms, trunk and in some cases, face) applied over a topical steroid cream (either applied to the skin or the inner layer of bandage). The inner layer is wet in warm water and then applied; the outer layer is dry. The whole process is repeated every 12 hours and the bandages have to be kept wet in between.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="patient-education">Patient education:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#patient-education" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Discuss the rationale and importance of all skin care routines with parents and children. Practical demonstration is vital, as is the use of interpreters if the first language is not English. All information should be reinforced with printed materials as appropriate.</li>
<li>Stress the importance of frequent moisturising and include the significance of skin hydration (by sealing water in with emollients) as dry skin will itch more. Reinforce with parents that moisturising is the fundamental therapy for eczema and should occur 3–4 times per day (minimum).</li>
<li>Review the lack of a ‘cure’ for eczema, stressing that it is a chronic disease controlled through good skin care (although a large percentage of children will ‘outgrow’ their eczema after the age of 6 years).</li>
<li>Outline the instructions for steroid use (e.g. apply 20–30 min after emollients, use sparingly only on affected areas, with a frequency as directed). Include information on any other medications (e.g. antihistamines) that may be part of the child’s regimen.</li>
<li>Discuss the controversy that exists with regard to dietary management of eczema and explain there is little evidence that dietary changes in children over 1 year of age are of any benefit. Even in those children less than 1 year old, dietary restriction is rarely recommended and would require supervision by a dietician: therefore, it is not considered a first-line treatment.</li>
<li>Complementary treatments (reflexology, hypnotherapy, homeopathy, herbalists and Chinese herbal treatments) have been used</li>
</ul>
<p>9 Dermatological problems</p>
<p>for the management of atopic eczema and many parents wish to discuss them. For the most part, the evidence base is largely anecdotal and while some children may benefit from these therapies, their families should be advised to think carefully before embarking on them. Some oral Chinese herbal treatments can damage the liver and kidneys, so regular blood tests are needed.</p>
<ul>
<li>Additional measures that are important to review include use of non-biological washing powder; avoidance of fabric conditioners; keeping nails short; avoidance of synthetic fibres, wool and pets with fur, hair or feathers; keeping house dust down; and maintaining a cool temperature in the home.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="follow-up">FOLLOW-UP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#follow-up" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>None required if symptoms settle with supportive care.</li>
<li>For children with significant involvement (that requires time-consuming and complicated treatments), both the child and family will require consistent support, reinforcement of knowledge and encouragement.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="medical-consult-specialist-referral">MEDICAL CONSULT/ SPECIALIST REFERRAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-consult-specialist-referral" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>If doubt exists regarding the diagnosis.</li>
<li>Any child who is erythrodermic (a large area of the child’s body is abnormally red, flaking and thickened) needs immediate referral.</li>
<li>Suspected bacterial infection (weeping, crusted eczema often yellow/honey-coloured).</li>
<li>Suspected eczema herpeticum (rare but serious complication due to herpes simplex virus). Consider if sudden, dramatic eczema flare, an unwell/ pyrexia child, and a ‘punched out’ appearance to the lesions (especially around the eyes).</li>
<li>Any child where first-line treatment fails despite adequate explanation, demonstration and adherence.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="paediatric-pearls">PAEDIATRIC PEARLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paediatric-pearls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Symptoms can only be controlled if families understand how (and when) to use treatments and if they keep using them; always provide written information (if appropriate) to accompany verbal instruction and practical demonstrations.</li>
<li>The importance of emollients/ moisturisers cannot be overemphasised.</li>
<li>A triple therapy approach is suitable for most children (bath oils and soap substitutes for cleansing; regular and liberal use of moisturisers; and intermittent use of the least-potent steroid preparation).</li>
<li>Support, encourage and educate; support, encourage and educate; support, encourage and educate ...</li>
<li>Eczema has social and emotional implications and can seriously affect interpersonal relationships.</li>
</ul>
<p>Consequently, children can experience alienation from peers as a result of the disfigurement and may fall behind in school because of absences; the disease can be especially devastating for adolescents. Provide families with information on support groups and consider referral for psychological services if significant pathology is presenting.</p>

</ul>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="9-4-birthmarks">9.4 BIRTHMARKS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#9-4-birthmarks" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Jane C. Linward</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The term ‘birthmark’ refers to a wide variety of conditions, some more common than others.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For the most part, birthmarks that are seen commonly in paediatric practice can be divided into vascular or pigmented lesions.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The incidence of the individual lesions varies, with some considered almost a normal variant (e.g. mongolian spots which can affect more than 80% of newborns).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Likewise, the management and prognosis of the lesion may vary from a transient phenomenon of minimal significance (e.g. stork marks) to a permanent cutaneous abnormality that may be associated with significant systemic complications (port-wine stains).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Commonly encountered birthmarks included in this section are summarised in Table 9.7.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>9.4 Birthmarks</p>
<p>COMMON PAEDIATRIC PROBLEMS</p>

may initially be attributed to birth trauma or port-wine stain</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Nape lesions often persist (while others usually resolve within 2 years)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Haemangioma</td><td>• Classified according to clinical appearance (i.e. superficial, deep, or mixed)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Superficial lesions appear births</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Initially thought to be related to birth trauma and/or the use of tape for intravenous lines (but lesions persist)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• If lesion involves eyelids there is an increased risk of glaucoma</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Port-wine stains on the scalp may have brain involvement, resulting in convulsions and/or motor <p>9 Dermatological problems</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology">PATHOPHYSIOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Vascular birthmarks can be grouped into vascular malformations (capillaries, veins, lymphatics or arteries that have undergone errors of morphogenesis) or vascular tumours (benign tumours that demonstrate endothelial hyperplasia, the most common being haemangiomas).</li>
<li>Vascular malformations are present at birth and are (usually) classified according to vascular flow characteristics and predominant vessel type (i.e. capillary, venous, lymphatic, arterial or mixed), although there is controversy with regard to the classification of vascular lesions. Common capillary malformations encountered in paediatric practice include stork marks (which are caused by distended dermal capillaries) and port-wine stains (which are the result of thin-walled capillary to venular-sized channels located in the papillary and upper reticular dermis).</li>
<li>Haemangiomas may be present at birth, although more commonly they develop over the first 2–3 weeks of life. These benign tumours involve endothelial tissue that grows rapidly with a high expression of proliferating cell nuclear antigen. The lesions undergo a rapid proliferative phase (usually 3–9 months, rarely beyond 18 months) in which they increase rapidly in size and colour. This is followed by a spontaneous, slow involution (that typically lasts from 2–9 years). Approximately 30% of haemangiomas have spontaneously involuted by 3 years of age, 50% by 5 years, 70% by 7 years and 90% by 9–12 years of age.</li>
<li>Hyperpigmented birthmarks may be macular, papular, plaque-like, evenly coloured, speckled or spotty. Often a morphological approach is used for classification, description and diagnosis.</li>
<li>Mongolian spots, a frequently encountered hyperpigmented birthmark, are thought to result from interrupted embryonic migration of melanocytes from the neural crest to the epidermis. It is not well understood why the lesions typically appear in the same places (most commonly the lower back and sacrum). The characteristic bluish hue of the lesions is a result of the Tyndall effect; more specifically, the optical scattering of light as it passes through a turbid medium (i.e. the dermis).</li>
<li>Café au lait macules (CALMs) are regularly seen in paediatric practice. They result from epidermal collection of heavily pigmented melanocytes that are of neural crest origin. CALMs can occur anywhere on the body (and are often located on the buttocks of newborns). Multiple CALMs (6 or more that are &gt;0.5 cm in diameter) and/or inguinal/axillary freckling are associated with neurofibromatosis type 1. Infants and children meeting these criteria will require further investigation.</li>
<li>Congenital melanocytic naevi (CMNs) are uncommon birthmarks that have important implications for later life. They result from collections of melanocytes that are present at birth or develop within the first year. CMNs are clinically significant because of their association with childhood malignant melanoma (especially intermediate or large CMNs). Typically, the lesions grow proportionately with the child and are usually classified according to their size. The majority of CMNs are unsightly and may or may not have hair growth.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="history">HISTORY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Antenatal and birth history.</li>
<li>When the lesion(s) was first noticed and whether it has changed or grown in size.</li>
<li>Any other systemic symptoms?</li>
<li>History of skin lesions in the family.</li>
<li>Treatment and advice received elsewhere.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physical-examination">PHYSICAL EXAMINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Head-to-toe examination of all skin. It is imperative to note size, colour, distribution and extent of any lesion(s).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Texture of lesion and whether it is easily compressed, blanched and/or is emptied of blood.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Complete physical examination of the remaining systems (e.g. cardiovascular, pulmonary, gastrointestinal, neurological and musculoskeletal) in order to rule out any additional findings.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="differential-diagnoses">DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differential-diagnoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Be sure to rule out other aetiologies for the lesion(s): more specifically, acute infections, trauma, child protection issues, soft tissue tumours, etc.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Additional diagnostics: see Table 9.8.</li>
<li>Pharmacotherapeutics: see Table 9.8.</li>
<li>Behavioural interventions: see Table 9.8.</li>
<li>Patient education: Lesion-specific information is outlined in Table 9.8. However, in general, it is important to address the following broad categories:</li>
<li>Review cause of the birthmark.</li>
<li>Discuss the likely course (i.e. what will happen to the lesion as the child grows and when it will go away). Include the importance of watching for changes.</li>
<li>Inform parents of the potential association of the birthmark with other problems (if applicable).</li>
<li>Outline what to do and what will happen if the lesion is touched, scratched or cut.</li>
<li>Discuss with parents the possibility of other children having this birthmark.</li>
<li>Outline the skin care necessary for the lesion.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="follow-up">FOLLOW-UP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#follow-up" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Lesion specific: see Table 9.9.</li>
</ul>

<p>COMMON PAEDIATRIC PROBLEMS</p>
<p>9 Dermatological problems</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Lesion</th><th>Follow-up</th><th>Referral/consult</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Mongolian spots</td><td>• None usually required</td><td>• Any child with an atypical and/or persistent lesion(s)</td></tr><tr><td>Café au lait macules (CALMs)</td><td>• If isolated and singular lesion, none required</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Lesions with cosmetic significance may benefit from laser therapy</td><td>• Any neonate with multiple CALMs</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Any child with &gt;6 CALMs of 0.5 cm or larger</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Any infant or young child with inguinal and axillary freckling</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Congenital melanocytic naevi (CMNs)</td><td>• Yearly monitoring for development of childhood malignant melanoma</td><td>• Any neonate with a significant lesion (refer in first weeks of life)</td></tr><tr><td>• Any child in whom a lesion has changed in appearance</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Stork marks</td><td>• None required unless redness persists for more than 2 years</td><td>• Any child with redness persisting after 2 years (rule out part-wine element)</td></tr><tr><td>Haemangioma</td><td>• If oral steroids are used as part of the treatment regimen, there needs to be regular monitoring of blood pressure and weight</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Due to immune suppression among children treated with oral steroids, live vaccines (oral polio) should not be used (substitute inactivated vaccine) and exposure to varicella will require varicella zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG) to be given</td><td>• Any neonate with numerous lesions (rule out internal lesions).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>This includes ophthalmology assessment with orbital ultrasound (rule out orbital involvement); ENT assessment if auditory or respiratory involvement; and ECG and abdominal ultrasound if &gt;3 lesions. Beware thrombocytopenia and cardiac failure with large internal lesion(s)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Any child with lesions on the eyelids, nostrils, throat or around the ears as these need careful monitoring</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Any child with significant lesions (treatment needs to be started early, before rapid growth occurs)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Any child with a lesion around the eye as there is a risk of amblyopia</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Part-wine stain</td><td>• Annual eye checks for children with eyelid stains</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Yearly reevaluation of lesions treated with lasers (check for repigmentation)</td><td>• Any child with a part-wine stain should be evaluated for possible intervention</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Any child with a part-wine stain on the eyelid will require ophthalmology referral (rule out glaucoma) and yearly rechecks</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Any child with a part-wine stain of the scalp will require neurology referral (rule out brain involvement, seizures or other problem)</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="paediatric-pearls">PAEDIATRIC PEARLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paediatric-pearls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Advice on skin care always available from specialist units.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>An area of skin (anywhere) on the body of a neonate that becomes red or raised during the first few weeks of life should flag up the possibility of a proliferating haemangioma. Likewise, if there were any treatments that involved the use of tape, the skin may have developed red areas. If normal skin cleansing and moisturisers do not clear (or if ulcerations occur) haemangioma should be considered.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Nappy rash can sometimes be confused with telangiectatic haemangiomas (bilateral, flat, red/pink areas without a clearly defined edge). Cleansing and barrier cream should clear if nappy rash.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Occasionally, deep haemangiomas that are not identified as such and are subsequently confused with malignancies (and referred to an oncologist). This is probably related to the significant swelling and mass-like consistency of deep haemangiomas.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Port-wine stains that occur in conspicuous places can cause great distress to parents and relatives. Significant support and correct advice on treatments is imperative from diagnosis (i.e. birth). Likewise, put parents in contact with support groups (see below).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Birthmark Support Group (PO Box 3932, Weymouth, DT4 9YG, e-mail: <a href="mailto:birthmarksupportgroup@btinternet.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birthmarksupportgroup@btinternet.com</a>) will always give names and numbers of a specialist nurse either to a parent or health care professional. In addition, the Birthmark Support Group has parents who will always be happy to talk to other parents.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cosmetic camouflage is available from some specialist units or the Red Cross. It may be requested after completion of treatments or for special occasions.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bibliography">BIBLIOGRAPHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bibliography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Dohil M, Baugh W, Eichenfield L. Vascular and pigmented birthmarks. Pediatr Clin North Am 2000; 47(4):783-808.</p>
<p>Dover JS. Pulsed dye treatment of port wine stains. J Am Acad Dermatol 1995; 32:237-240.</p>
<p>Lacour M. Role of pulsed dye laser in the management of ulcerated haemangiomas. Arch Dis Child 1996; 74(2):161-163.</p>
<p>Lanigna SW. Treatment of vascular naevi in children. Hosp Med 2001; 62(3):144-147.</p>
<p>Rasmussen J. Vascular birthmarks in children. Dermatol Nurs 1998; 10(3):169-230.</p>
