<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="9-12-pediculosis-humanus-capitus-head-lice">9.12 PEDICULOSIS HUMANUS CAPITUS (HEAD LICE)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#9-12-pediculosis-humanus-capitus-head-lice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Jan Mitcheson</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Head lice is a common problem amongst school-age children and although infestation rarely affects general health, it is often the cause of much anxiety for parents and carers.</li>
<li>Transmission occurs through head-to-head contact, in addition to spread through infected fomites (hats, hair slides, combs, hairbrushes, etc.).</li>
<li>Lice infection is usually asymptomatic, although approximately one-third of patients experience itching.</li>
<li>Diagnosis is confirmed by detection of the living louse and treatment consists of insecticide application.</li>
<li>Parent education and support is of paramount importance in the identification, treatment and control of head lice.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pathophysiology">PATHOPHYSIOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Head lice are spread when there is sustained, direct, head-to-head contact which allows movement of the lice from one head to another.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Head lice cannot jump, fly, crawl or swim. However, they can be spread via direct contact with infected combs, brushes, hats, bedding and upholstery as lice can live for 1–2 days off their human host (although most lice on inanimate objects are dead or dying).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The life cycle of the head louse is approximately 17–20 days; they survive by clinging to hair and sucking blood from the host scalp. In early infection, the lice are usually concentrated around the parietal and occipital regions (i.e. behind the ears and back of the head). Head lice cling to the hair shaft via a chitinous ring (cement-like substance) and release noxious saliva that can cause pruritus, irritation and dermatitis.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The female louse lays about six to eight eggs per day (close to the scalp), which take from 7 to 10 days to hatch, leaving a shell (nit) on the hair shaft. Given that hair grows roughly <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{1}{4}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1901em; vertical-align: -0.345em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8451em;"><span style="top: -2.655em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">4</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.394em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.345em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span> inch per month nits, found further down the hair shaft, are likely to be empty shells. The emerging nymphs stay on the original host for a further 7 days until they reach adulthood. Only the adult lice are contagious, as nymphs cannot spread to another host.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="history">HISTORY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Detection of living louse or eggs on hair shaft (identification of live eggs is difficult).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Complaints of itchy scalp (include onset).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>History of potential head lice exposures (especially family members or close contacts).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>History of outbreak in school or nursery.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Previous management of symptoms and infestation control measures (i.e. family members treated and interventions to rid hats, combs, brushes, etc., of louse infestation).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any other symptoms (secondary skin lesions, dermatitis of skin and neck area, etc.).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="physical-examination">PHYSICAL EXAMINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Visual inspection, as traditionally performed by the school nurse, has been found to be unreliable in the detection of head lice, producing unacceptably high levels of false-positives and -negatives. Combing wet hair (especially close to the scalp) with a plastic detection comb (teeth 0.2–0.3 mm apart) is considered to be a reliable way in which to detect head lice infestation. Louse specimens (and/or nits) can then be attached to clear sticky tape for confirmation by a health care professional.</li>
<li>Note any secondary skin lesions or dermatitis of neck and shoulder areas. It is sometimes possible to visualise bite marks where lice have fed on scalp but these are often obliterated by scratching (which can result in secondary bacterial infection).</li>
</ul>
<p>9 Dermatological problems</p>
<ul>
<li>Examine eyelashes and eyebrows for infestation.</li>
<li>Posterior occipital and/or cervical lymphadenopathy is not uncommon as a result of scalp infestation.</li>
<li>Family members/close contacts should likewise be examined (using the detection comb on wet hair) for infestation once an initial case of pediculosis has been confirmed.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-differential-diagnoses">2 DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-differential-diagnoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A definitive diagnosis of pediculosis is only confirmed when live lice have been detected and confirmed by a community health care professional.</li>
<li>Consider foreign bodies, secretions from the hair follicle (hair muffs), seborrhoeic dermatitis, contact dermatitis, eczema and impetigo.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Additional diagnostics: rarely necessary. Transfer of live louse to sticky tape for further inspection by a health care professional is helpful in diagnosis. In addition, live nits will fluoresce under a Wood light whereas examination of a louse or nit under a microscope can confirm characteristic appearance and rule out foreign bodies (i.e. dandruff).</li>
<li>Pharmacotherapeutics: There are currently four insecticides—malathion, permethrin, phenothrin and carbaryl—in use in the UK. Note that a number of licensed products, that nurses with prescribing status may prescribe, are listed in the Nurse Prescribers Formulary at N17-18. However, the Cochrane Collaboration Review (1999) could find only limited evidence of the effectiveness of any of these four insecticides and, as a result, its current policy is to manage each proven case using a mosaic of treatments (i.e. retreatment with a different insecticide if one treatment has failed or reinfection has occurred). For each treatment:</li>
<li>Apply two applications of an insecticide 7 days apart.</li>
<li>Hair should be checked thoroughly with a fine plastic detector comb 2–3 days after the second application.</li>
<li>If adult lice are still present, the treatment should be repeated with a different insecticide.</li>
<li>Investigate the reasons for treatment failure. Consider initial misdiagnosis, inadequate or incorrect application of treatment, and/or reinfection (often due to inadequate contact tracing or inadequate treatment of fomites).</li>
<li>Some products can cause skin irritation, and alcoholic formulations should be avoided in small children and in patients with asthma. Likewise, malathion should not be used in infants less than 6 months of age.</li>
<li>Shampoo formulations are not recommended.</li>
<li>Interest in the use of naturally occurring products to treat head lice (quassia, tea tree oil, other essential oils, herbal remedies, petrol) has increased in recent years. However, evidence with regard to efficacy, standards of use and safety is limited. In addition, some therapies (i.e. petrol) can be dangerous.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="behavioural-interventions">Behavioural interventions:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#behavioural-interventions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Routine inspection for lice infestation: comb wet hair periodically (with a plastic fine-toothed comb) as a means of detecting early head lice infection. Demonstration of techniques and written information for parents/carers is vital (see Patient education).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Mechanical treatment (Bug Busting): combing of wet, conditioned hair using a fine detector comb until all the lice have been removed. The combing needs to be repeated every 3–4 days for a period of 2 weeks. It is important to note that while there is a lack of substantive evidence to suggest that mechanical treatment methods are effective, such methods are gaining in popularity in the treatment of head lice. Mechanical removal of head lice may be an option in families who decline to use an insecticide or in whom treatment has repeatedly failed. However, mechanical treatment is generally not recommended for whole populations.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Disinfection of fomites: all items in contact with the scalp (combs, hairbrushes, slides, hats, etc.) should be washed in hot (60°C) water. Likewise, all bedding, clothes and washable toys should receive the same treatment. Objects unable to be washed can be treated with insecticide powders or sealed in plastic bags and left for 2 weeks.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Treatment of infested eyelashes: apply a petroleum-based ocular ointment to eyelashes 3–4 times daily for a period of 10 days; remove nits mechanically from lashes.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="patient-education">Patient education:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#patient-education" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Review medication regimen, including application instructions, length of time for applications, etc.</li>
<li>Stress the importance of concordance with all aspects of treatment. Remind families that appropriate home management (including medication, treatment of infected contacts and behavioural interventions) is essential for effective eradication of head lice infection.</li>
<li>It is often helpful to explain to parents the rationale behind the head lice treatments, including information on the life cycle of head lice.</li>
<li>Warn parents that pruritus may persist for up to 2 weeks after treatment (related to chemical irritation from the medication and/or sensitivity to the bite of the louse); this does not mean that there has been a treatment failure.</li>
<li>Patient education materials: The Prevention and Treatment of Head Lice (DoH, 2000) is available free to schools and health professionals in the UK from Department of Health, PO Box 777, London SE1 6XH.</li>
</ul>
<p>Bug Buster help line: 020-8341-7167, <a href="http://www.nits.net/bugbusting" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.nits.net/bugbusting</a>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="follow-up">FOLLOW-UP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#follow-up" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Ideally, follow-up is advisable to evaluate treatment success within 2–3 days of the second treatment.</li>
<li>Signs of treatment failure are the same as for the original diagnosis (i.e. detection of live lice).</li>
</ul>
<p>9.13 Psoriasis</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="medical-consult-specialist-referral">MEDICAL CONSULT/SPECIALIST REFERRAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-consult-specialist-referral" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Usually not necessary, as head lice infestation is rarely associated with serious clinical consequences, although in rare cases inflammation of the scalp and secondary infection can occur. In these cases, referral to a general practitioner may be advisable.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="paediatric-pearls">PAEDIATRIC PEARLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paediatric-pearls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Lice infection is confirmed through detection of live lice or eggs; treat only true infections.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The minimum volume for a single application is usually a single small bottle (50–59 ml); however, this amount may have to be adjusted upwards for very thick or long hair.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Prophylactic use of insecticides (or automatic treatment of family members) is not recommended, although close contacts should be carefully checked for infestation after a case has been confirmed.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Use of a white cloth or tissue to wipe the detection comb with after each pass through the hair can aid in detection of hair debris and/or lice.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Treatment failures are most likely due to failure to administer second application of insecticide; failure to recognise and treat other infected contacts; incorrect insecticide use (especially failure to leave on the hair for the recommended length of time).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Do not overtreat. Chemical irritation and/or sensitivity from louse bites can result in pruritus that persists for up to 2 weeks; this is not a treatment failure.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Insecticides work by killing lice and eggs (ovicidal). Effectiveness depends on the insecticide itself (assuming correct application) and some preparations have greater ovidical activity than others. Consequently, the second application of insecticide is important. Note that shampoo formulations have low ovidical activity and may not kill lice, so they are not recommended.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Although there had been reported resistance to commonly used insecticides, it is important to rule out other causes for treatment failure and the possibility of psychogenic or allergic itching before retreatment.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bibliography">BIBLIOGRAPHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bibliography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

Chesney P, Burgess I. Lice: resistance and treatment. Contemp Pediatr 1998; 15(11):160–192.

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="9-13-psoriasis">9.13 PSORIASIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#9-13-psoriasis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Sandra Lawton</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory skin disorder characterised by episodes of flare and remission; it is not infectious.</li>
<li>Although less common in children, it is probably underdiagnosed. It has been estimated that 10% of patients with psoriasis present before the age of 10, with the average age of onset being 8 years.</li>
<li>Psoriasis usually presents as red, scaly, thickened patches commonly affecting knees, elbows, lower back and scalp (chronic plaque psoriasis); this presentation is easily recognised and accounts for 65% of cases in childhood. In contrast, guttate psoriasis is less prevalent and accounts for 25% of cases. Other forms of psoriasis are shown in (Table 9.19).</li>
<li>Scalp involvement affects 80% of children with facial, intertrigenous and napkin psoriasis seen commonly. Attacks of pustular and erythrodermic psoriasis are rare in children, as are psoriatic arthropathy and nail changes.</li>
<li>There is a strong genetic component to psoriasis, with a variety of potential triggers playing a role in disease expression (Table 9.20).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pathophysiology">PATHOPHYSIOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The skin consists of two layers: the epidermis and the dermis. In normal skin, cells reproduce, move from the dermis to the epidermis and are shed slowly. This process takes about 28 days and is called 'proliferation'.</li>
<li>In psoriasis, the new skin cells (keratinocytes) are made too quickly and push up to the surface of the skin with a 4-day turnover. In addition, there is a 30-fold increase in production of new epidermal cells.</li>
<li>These combined phenomena result in (1) the characteristic silvery scale of psoriasis; (2) a thickened epidermis;</li>
</ul>
<p>9 Dermatological problems</p>
<p>Table 9.19 Types of Psoriasis</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Type</th><th>Distinguishing features</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Chronic plaque psoriasis</td><td>• Accounts for approximately 65% of cases in children</td></tr><tr><td>• Easily recognised, red/pink, well-demarcated plaques with dry, silvery-white scale</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Knees are commonly affected</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Auspitz’s sign commonly seen (pinpoint bleeding if scales are picked off)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Guttate psoriasis</td><td>• Accounts for approximately 25% of cases in children; especially children and adolescents</td></tr><tr><td>• Characterised by small, round, red spots that appear suddenly on the trunk and become scaly</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Lesions are typically small, extensive and superficial (often described as looking like ‘raindrops’)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Streptococcal sore throat can trigger and, as such, is often self-limiting (lasting 2–3 months)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Some individuals may have recurrent attacks and occasionally lesions coalesce to become plaque psoriasis</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Scalp psoriasis</td><td>• Common site of psoriasis in children</td></tr><tr><td>• Characterised by a scalp which is dry and flaky or red and inflamed with well-defined plaques</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Scaling is thick and may form ‘lumps’ on head; areas often affected include behind the ears and just below hairline</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Associated hair loss almost always resolves spontaneously after psoriasis clears</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Napkin psoriasis</td><td>• Infants develop typical psoriasis plaques or a bright, red, weepy rash in the nappy area</td></tr><tr><td>Flexural psoriasis</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(uncommon in children)</td><td>• Most common in women and obese patients</td></tr><tr><td>• Commonly affects submammary, axillary and anogenital folds</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Glistening red plaques are clearly demarcated (no scaling); often there is cracking in the depths of the folds</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Pustular psoriasis</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(rare in children): two types</td><td>• Palmoplantar pustular psoriasis: characterised by localised, painful yellow/white pustules (3–10 mm) appearing on inflamed, erythematous skin; may leave brown marks (areas of hyperpigmentation) after healing</td></tr><tr><td>• Most resistant to treatment with increased prevalence in females and associated with smoking</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Generalised pustular psoriasis: a medical emergency and requires immediate referral to specialist care</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Can be a complication of long-standing psoriasis or related to the withdrawal of corticosteroid therapy, hypocalcaemia, infections and local irritants</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• The top layer of skin may come away in sheets and the patient can become acutely ill</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Erythrodermic psoriasis</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(rare in children)</td><td>• Medical emergency and, as such, requires immediate referral</td></tr><tr><td>• Characterised by erythema of whole body with patches of scaling that is fairly superficial and, as such, different from chronic plaque</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Patients can develop oedema of the limbs, cardiac failure and impaired liver and renal function (as a result of vasodilation)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Triggers include severe sunburn, withdrawal of systemic steroids, irritation of the skin from coal tar and dithranol and systemic infections</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Psoriatic arthropathy</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(rare in children)</td><td>• Many types, may present before or after rash; indication for referral</td></tr><tr><td>• Blood tests for rheumatoid factors will be negative, despite arthropathy for several years prior to skin signs</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• The prognosis in psoriatic arthropathy appears to be better than in rheumatoid arthritis, often with less pain and disability</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Nail psoriasis</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(rare in children)</td><td>• Thimble pitting is the most common, followed by onycholysis (separation of the distal edge of the nail from the bed)</td></tr><tr><td>• Treatment is often difficult</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Table 9.20 Potential Psoriasis Triggers</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Potential trigger</th><th>Association</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Infection</td><td>• Throat infection with group A β-haemolytic streptococcus can often precipitate an outbreak of guttate psoriasis in children and young adults</td></tr><tr><td>Skin trauma</td><td>• Psoriatic lesion can appear at site of trauma (scratches, surgical wound, sunburn, skin infection); known as Koebner phenomenon lesions often take 7–14 days to develop</td></tr><tr><td>Medications</td><td>• Use of lithium, beta-blockers, antimalarials and some non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs have been known to exacerbate psoriasis</td></tr><tr><td>Alcohol</td><td>• An association between high alcohol intake and psoriasis has been reported</td></tr><tr><td>Climate</td><td>• In general, psoriatic symptoms improve in warm climates but may be exacerbated in cold ones</td></tr><tr><td>Sunlight</td><td>• While beneficial in 90% of cases, for some patients sunlight may exacerbate symptoms</td></tr><tr><td>Stress</td><td>• Anecdotal evidence suggests emotional upset and/or stress triggers flare</td></tr><tr><td>Smoking</td><td>• Smoking aggravates psoriasis and it is associated with palmoplantar pustular psoriasis</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>(3) activation of local immune processes (WBC infiltrates); and
(4) an increased blood supply to the skin (capillary dilatation causes the erythematous, raised patches).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="history">HISTORY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>• Family history of psoriasis.
• Potential triggers.
• Date/child’s age when lesion(s) appeared, including their location at onset, appearance and areas which are currently involved.
• Appearance of lesions and degree of associated pain, pruritus and discomfort.
• Recent illness prior to onset (particularly sore throat).</p>
<p>9.13 Psoriasis</p>
<p>COMMON PAEDIATRIC PROBLEMS</p>
<ul>
<li>Recent medications (particularly systemic steroids use).</li>
<li>Recent trauma prior to onset and/or relationship of lesion to trauma.</li>
<li>Joint pain.</li>
<li>Current medication (topical and systemic): any known allergies.</li>
<li>Previous treatment(s) and response.</li>
<li>Improvement with sun exposure and/or seasonal variations.</li>
<li>Knowledge about skin condition (psoriasis).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="physical-examination">PHYSICAL EXAMINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Systematic head-to-toe examination of the skin with special attention to the scalp, joint flexures, palms, soles and nails. Be sure to check in the retroauricular portion of the scalp and perianal region as these are sites of involvement that are commonly overlooked.</li>
<li>Determine texture, temperature and perfusion of skin.</li>
<li>Lesions should be examined in detail with meticulous description and documentation on a body plan.</li>
<li>Determine the degree of pain, itching (pruritus) and soreness associated with the psoriasis. Auspitz's sign (pinpoint bleeding when scale removed) is found in plaque psoriasis while the Koebner phenomenon is the appearance of psoriasis lesions at the site of trauma (scratches, surgical wounds, sunburn or skin infections).</li>
<li>Joints should be examined for signs of swelling or deformity (psoriatic arthropathy) as should palms and soles (to rule out pustular psoriasis).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="differential-diagnoses">DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differential-diagnoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The different patterns of psoriasis in childhood have different differential diagnoses; see Table 9.21.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="management">MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The goals of psoriasis management are centred on controlling symptoms, managing exacerbations, maintaining comfort and adapting regimens to individual children and their families. In addition, vital components of</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Table 9.21 Differential Diagnoses of Psoriasis</th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Common clinical patterns in childhood</td><td>Consider</td></tr><tr><td>Chronic plaque</td><td>• Discoid eczema, tinea corporis, pityriasis versicolor</td></tr><tr><td>Guttate</td><td>• Drug eruption, pityriasis versicolor, pityriasis rosea, pityriasis rubra pilaris, tinea corporis, Gianotti-Crosti syndrome</td></tr><tr><td>Scalp</td><td>• Atopic eczema, scalp infestation, infantile seborrhoeic dermatitis</td></tr><tr><td>Napkin psoriasis</td><td>• Candida infection, irritant dermatitis, nappy rash, infantile seborrhoeic dermatitis, histiocytosis X</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>management include educating, supporting and empowering children (and their families) as well as improving their quality of life.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Additional diagnostics: not routinely required, as the diagnosis of psoriasis is established from history and physical examination findings. However, the following can be considered: throat culture (useful if streptococcal infection is suspected, as group A <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-haemolytic streptococcus is associated with acute onset of guttate psoriasis in children and adolescents); further investigations (skin biopsy, and bacterial, fungal and/or viral cultures are sometimes useful if there is diagnostic doubt); haematological screening (required if systemic medications are to be used as there are implications for the therapies prescribed).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pharmacotherapeutics: first-line interventions are topical treatments followed by phototherapy and systemic medications (specialist management only). Note that care needs to be taken with regard to topical medications in children (see Ch. 5). Table 9.22 summarises appropriate pharmacotherapeutics.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Patient education:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Educate patients about their skin condition, its management and its chronicity. Stress the importance of controlling the disease through physical care, maintenance of skin integrity (avoiding trauma) and consistent use of medications (especially topical treatments).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Reinforce with families that following instructions as closely as possible is important; therapy that is too vigorous may worsen symptoms while non-adherence to treatment</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>regimens will not result in improvements.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Discuss with families strategies to maintain comfort, such as tackling distressing symptoms (e.g. itch, soreness, dryness, bleeding and pain). Outline warning signs that require evaluation (appearance of pustules or increase in number; significant increase in symptom severity, especially if accompanied by fever or an ill-appearance).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Review lifestyle changes and trigger avoidance that help prevent recurrence (avoiding skin injury, streptococcal infection, sunburn, stress, insect bites, itching, tight clothes/shoes and occlusive skin dressings).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Teach patients and families about their medication uses, side-effects and potential problems. Reinforce instructions and monitor use frequently.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Inform families that skin care regimens can be adapted to suit their individual needs.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Behavioural interventions: adherence to skin care regimen; keep home cool and central heating low; heat dries the skin; avoid perfumed products; find a hairstyle that avoids the need for grips and bands, which pull the hair; beware of the common triggers—how they affect the child and action to be taken.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="follow-up">FOLLOW-UP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#follow-up" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The majority of patients can be supported and treated in primary care if the skin care regimens, behavioural interventions and patient education points are followed. The support of secondary care would then be on an 'as required or indicated' basis. Therefore,</li>
</ul>
<p>9 Dermatological problems</p>
<p>Table 9.22 Pharmacological Management of Psoriasis</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Treatment</th><th>Mechanism of action</th><th>Guidance</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Emollients</td><td>• Soothe: relieve the irritation and itch (anti-pruritic)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Soften: lubricate and soften the plaques, keeping them more flexible and comfortable so they are less likely to crack</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Hydrate: by keeping the plaque moist, scale removal is achieved, which in turn allows easier application and enhanced penetration of other topical therapies</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Anti-inflammatory: emollients may slow down the rate of cell turnover (further research is required)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Potential steroid sparing effect: emollients may reduce the need to use topical corticosteroids as rate of cell turnover may be reduced (further research is required)</td><td>• Apply thinly, frequently, gently and in the direction of hair growth to prevent folliculitis (irritation and inflammation of hair follicles). Must be allowed to soak into the skin before active topical therapies are used (20 min); it is no good putting therapies on scale</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Many types available: soap substitutes, bath oils, shower therapies and moisturisers, so it is important to be familiar with various options so that the patient can be involved in the choice</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• See Section 9.3</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Coal tar</td><td>• Helps clear psoriasis by an antimitotic effect but the exact action is still unknown; used to treat psoriasis over many years</td><td>• Disadvantages include unpleasant odour and mess of application</td></tr><tr><td>• Often used in conjunction with UVB (ultraviolet radiation)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Apply once or twice/day. Cover the whole plaque and wipe on rather than rub in</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Most tars will stain bedding and clothing so patients should be advised to use old clothing and linen</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Dithranol (anthralin)</td><td>• Inhibits mitosis and slows down the excessive rate of keratinocyte division. Has been used for over 100 years to treat psoriasis</td><td>• Stains skin, hair, linen, clothing and bath (a purple/brown colour)</td></tr><tr><td>• In hospital, dithranol is applied and left on overnight</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• In primary care, short contact dithranol is applied once daily and removed after 30 min in the bath or shower</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Treatment should continue daily for 3–4 weeks and the strength of the dithranol increased every few days</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Apply to the plaque while sparing surrounding skin, as it will cause staining, irritation and burning</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Topical steroids</td><td>• Use of topical steroids in the management of children with psoriasis occurs under specialist supervision</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Vitamin D analogues</td><td>• Vitamin D derivatives induce differentiation and suppress proliferation of keratinocytes</td><td>• Used in mild-to-moderate psoriasis</td></tr><tr><td>• Easy to use and not messy</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Two types: calcipotriol and tacalcitol (tacalcitol is not licensed for use in children)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Topical retinoids</td><td>• Not to be used in children</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Phototherapy</td><td>• Administered in specialist units only</td><td>• Often used in conjunction with other therapies</td></tr><tr><td>• Short-term complications include erythema and ‘sunburn’</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Long-term complications include photoaging and possible (though slight) increased risk of skin cancers</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Systemic drugs</td><td>• Administered in specialist units only</td><td>• Methotrexate, acitretin, ciclosporin</td></tr><tr><td>• Not generally used in children: all have potential side-effects and complications. They require haematological monitoring and are used in recalcitrant forms only</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>it is important for primary providers to have a clear understanding of the indications for subsequent dermatology consultation/referral (see below).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="medical-consultation-specialist-referral">MEDICAL CONSULTATION/SPECIALIST REFERRAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-consultation-specialist-referral" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Any child with pustular or erythrodermic psoriasis requires immediate referral.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any child with acutely unstable psoriasis or widespread symptomatic guttate psoriasis that would likely benefit from phototherapy.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any child/family in whom the condition is causing severe social and psychological problems; prompts to referral should include sleeplessness, social exclusion and reduced quality of life or self-esteem.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any child in whom the rash is sufficiently extensive to make self-management impractical and/or the rash is in a sensitive area (such as face, hands, feet, genitalia) with the symptoms that are particularly troublesome.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any child in whom the rash is leading to time off school sufficient enough to interfere with education.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any child who requires an assessment for the management of associated arthropathy.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any child that has (or develops) features that create diagnostic uncertainty and/or those children who fail to respond to management in general practice.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="paediatric-pearls">PAEDIATRIC PEARLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paediatric-pearls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>It is impossible to predict the prognosis for an individual. However,</li>
</ul>
<p>9.14 Scabies</p>
<p>if treated properly, psoriasis will generally improve, with remissions sometimes lasting for years.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Listen to the parents and child and consider their wishes; they will require a tremendous amount of support (both psychologically and practically). The chronic nature of the disease requires a high degree of care continuity and providers need to allow sufficient time for this.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Strategies for supporting patients include use of support groups, coping techniques, stress management, counselling, listening and talking.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Psoriasis is considered to be stable if there are no new plaques or, if plaques are present, the amount of scale is decreasing and the lesions are not increasing in size, distribution or redness.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Useful addresses: <strong>Psoriasis Association</strong>, Milton House, Milton Street, Northampton NN2 7JG (tel: 01604-711-129) and the <strong>Psoriatic Arthropathy Alliance</strong>, PO Box 111, St. Albans, Herefordshire AL2 3JQ (tel: 01923-672-837 or <a href="http://www.paalliance.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://www.paalliance.org/</a>)</p>
</li>
</ul>
