<p>Paige D. Psoriasis in children. Dermatol Pract 1998; 6(5):10-12.</p>
<p>Van Onselen J. Psoriasis in practice. London: Haymarket Publishing; 1998.</p>
<p>Williams HC. Dermatology. In: Stevens A, Raferty J, eds, Health care needs assessment: series 2. Oxford: Radcliffe Medical Press; 1997.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="9-14-scabies">9.14 SCABIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#9-14-scabies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Rosemary Turnbull</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Scabies is a highly contagious condition caused by the parasite <em>Sarcoptes scabiei</em>; humans are the only known reservoir.</li>
<li>It affects all age groups and is not gender-specific. Epidemics are reported to occur in 15-year cycles.</li>
<li>Scabies is not particular to socioeconomic class and is not a result of poor hygiene. Close personal contact with an infected human (with or without symptoms) is necessary for transmission. The scabies mite can live 36 hours isolated from a human host, but the extent of fomite transmission is unclear.</li>
<li>The scabies rash is characterised by cutaneous eruptions and an intense pruritus, this being particularly bad at night (especially in bed, as mite activity increases due to a rise in body temperature).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology">PATHOPHYSIOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The female scabies mite burrows in the stratum corneum (rarely penetrating through the epidermis) for 15–30 days after the initial infestation.</li>
<li>She lays her eggs in the burrow (travelling 2–4 mm/day) and can lay up to three eggs daily for 4–5 weeks (after which she dies within the burrow). The eggs take 3 days to hatch into larvae and subsequently undergo a further three nymph stages before the mites are capable of reproduction. After mating, the male will die and the gravid female begins the cycle again.</li>
<li>As such, there may be no pruritus until 4–6 weeks after the initial infestation.</li>
<li>The actual skin eruption is a consequence of an immune response to the scabies mite.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="history">HISTORY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Onset and duration of the rash.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Degree of itching and temporal factors (i.e. Is the itch worse at night?).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Progression/distribution of the rash (i.e. From where does it seem to spread?).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Potential exposures to scabies (e.g. close contacts with scabies, outbreaks in nursery/school, etc.).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Anyone else in the family itching or have evidence of a rash?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Measures taken thus far to relieve itching (with results).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physical-examination">PHYSICAL EXAMINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The child should be examined closely (see Sec. 9.1), paying particular attention to the finger and toe webs.</li>
<li>Carefully check the inner aspect of the wrists, the axilla, waistline and gluteal cleft.</li>
<li>In infants, carefully inspect the soles of the feet as well as scalp and face.</li>
<li>Examine the skin closely for burrows, which are characterised by grey-white scaly lines (typically an elongated ‘S’ shape with a broad base). In addition, punctate brown-black dots may be seen at the leading edge.</li>
<li>There may also be evidence of excoriated areas of skin, nodules and vesiculopustular lesions.</li>
</ul>
<p>9 Dermatological problems</p>
<ul>
<li>Secondary infection of the lesions and/or eczematous changes as a result of chronic scratching is not uncommon.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="differential-diagnoses">DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differential-diagnoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Diagnosis is crucial, as treatment may complicate pre-existing skin diseases such as eczema. Consider contact dermatitis, drug reaction, eczema, insect bites, infantile acropustulosis and papular viral exanthems.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Additional diagnostics: examination of the contents of the burrow under the microscope will reveal the scabies mite, eggs, larvae and/or mite faeces. Use a needle to extract the contents from the burrow. Visualisation of the mite or byproducts is the definitive diagnosis.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pharmacotherapeutics: Regular administration of chlorpheniramine (Piriton) suspension may offer some relief of pruritus. The current scabicide treatment of choice varies, as products are generally rotated to avoid resistance. It is important to check the products currently being used in specific areas. Commonly used scabicides include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Derbac-M (malathion 0.5% aqueous solution). Applied to whole body from neck down. Leave on for 24 hours. In cases of reinfestation use only once weekly.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Lyclear Dermal Cream (permethrin 5% cream) 30 g tubes. Apply to entire body, including scalp and face, avoiding the eyes. Leave in situ for 8 hours.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Behavioural interventions:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Follow administration instructions exactly. Written information should supplement verbal instructions. The medication will need to be applied over the entire body, including the scalp and face. Ensure that toe and finger webs are covered. Note that if the hands are washed before the appropriate length of time has elapsed, then more solution must be applied.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>After desired time, bath/shower in warm water to remove all the solution. A normal bath/shower can then be taken.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Treat all close contacts (whether symptomatic or not) at the same time. Ensure enough lotion/cream is issued to treat all contacts. Do not rely on carer buying additional lotion.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>All clothing and bed linen should be laundered in hot wash and dried at a high heat.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Use clean clothes and bed linens after treatment.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Patient education:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Discuss with parents/carers the exact cause of the rash. Reassure them that it is quite a common problem and is not an indication of family hygiene.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Review the behavioural interventions above and stress the importance of treating all contacts at the same time. Explain to parents that the most common causes of ineffective treatment are misapplication of medication and failure to treat all contacts simultaneously. This is true whether family members are symptomatic or not (contacts may be infested and yet still asymptomatic).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Inform parents that until treatment is completed, the child must be kept away from nursery/school.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Warn families that the itching may persist for up to 6 weeks after treatment and it is not indicative of failed treatment. However, the appearance of new burrows suggests reinfestation and parents should return for re-evaluation/examination.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="follow-up">FOLLOW-UP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#follow-up" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>None is usually required.</li>
<li>Issue telephone number for parent to contact you if they see new papules after treatment.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="medical-consult-specialist-referral">MEDICAL CONSULT/ SPECIALIST REFERRAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-consult-specialist-referral" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Any child in whom the diagnosis is unclear.</li>
<li>Any child who is immunocompromised.</li>
<li>Any child with recurring infestation despite adequate treatment.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="paediatric-pearls">PAEDIATRIC PEARLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paediatric-pearls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Suspect scabies in any sudden onset of itching and excoriations.</li>
<li>Lyclear cream is best for children, as it can be used on the scalp and face.</li>
<li>If there is a rash on the soles of an infant’s feet, think scabies.</li>
<li>Scabies is not particular to a socioeconomic class.</li>
<li>If reinfestation occurs, think a carrier has not been properly treated.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bibliography">BIBLIOGRAPHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bibliography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Anonmyous. The management of scabies. Drug Therap Bull 2002; 40(6):43–46.</p>
<p>Hughes E, Van Onselen J. Dermatology nursing: a practical approach. Edinburgh: Churchill Livingstone; 2001.</p>
<p>Morgan-Glenn PD. Scabies: in brief. Pediatr Rev 2001; 22(9):322–323.</p>
<p>Prendiville J. Scabies and lice. In: Harper J, Oranje A, Prose N, eds, Textbook of paediatric dermatology, Vol. 1. Oxford: Blackwell Science; 2001.</p>
<p>Rasmussen JE. Scabies. Pediatr Rev 1994; 15(3):110–114.</p>
<p>9.15 Viral skin infections (warts and molluscum contagiosum)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="9-15-viral-skin-infections-warts-and-molluscum-contagiosum">9.15 VIRAL SKIN INFECTIONS (WARTS AND MOLLUSCUM CONTAGIOSUM)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#9-15-viral-skin-infections-warts-and-molluscum-contagiosum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Karen Spowart</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Warts are benign, proliferative, intraepithelial tumours caused by the human papilloma virus (HPV) of which there are more than 100 different types identified to date. Those responsible for skin warts are types 1-4.</li>
<li>Warts commonly occur in children; approximately 10% of children between 5 and 10 years of age have warts. Those with atopic eczema are particularly at risk, as warts can develop at sites of trauma (Koebner phenomenon). Likewise, immunocompromised children are at increased risk of wart and molluscum infection, with those on long-term chemotherapy tending to develop large and very persistent lesions.</li>
<li>Commonly encountered warts in children are outlined in Table 9.23. Although most HPV sites have preferred sites of infectivity, note that there is significant overlap between the various HPV types.</li>
<li>In young children, perianal and genital warts are often acquired non-sexually (autoinoculation or heteroinoculation from carer's warts); however, the possibility of sexual abuse must be considered and/or ruled out.</li>
<li>Molluscum contagiosum are discrete, smooth, pearly papules caused by a pox virus. They are commonly referred to as 'water warts'.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology">PATHOPHYSIOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The incubation period for HPV ranges from 1 to 6 months, although a latency period of 3 or more years has been suggested. Humans are thought to be the only reservoir of HPV.</li>
<li>The mechanisms of transmission are not well understood. However, transmission is thought to occur via direct physical contact (although</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>Type of wart</th><th>Characteristics</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Common</td><td>• Easily identified as a firm papule with a hyperkeratotic surface</td></tr><tr><td>• Most commonly found on the hands, although any site can be affected</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Particularly common in children and may be painful, especially when periungual</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Plane</td><td>• Small flesh-coloured warts, often multiple, occurring on the face and backs of hands</td></tr><tr><td>Plantar (verrucae)</td><td>• Occur on the sole of the feet</td></tr><tr><td>• Body weight causes them to grow inwards; the associated pressure can result in considerable pain</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Multiple individual lesions (particularly on the heel) are known as mosaic warts</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Plantar warts tend to be persistent and difficult to treat</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Genital and perianal (anogenital warts)</td><td>• Caused by human papilloma virus (HPV) types 6, 11, 16 and 18</td></tr><tr><td>• In young children genital and perianal warts are usually acquired non-sexually (vertical transmission, inoculation by carer). However, the possibility of child sexual abuse must be considered and/or ruled out</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Molluscum contagiosum (water wart)</td><td>• Caused by pox virus</td></tr><tr><td>• Characterised by pearly white or skin-coloured papules that are waxy with central punctum</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Lesions are usually multiple and grouped in clusters; typically occur on the face, neck and trunk</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Spread is by direct contact and autoinoculation is common (secondary to scratching). As a result, lesions typically occur on adjacent skin surfaces</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>fomite spread has been postulated). After infection, the child is able to spread the virus to themselves (autoinoculation). This is commonly related to the manipulation of the warts (i.e. picking, scratching, shaving). Transmission can also occur from the warts of a carer or parent (heteroinoculation).</p>
<ul>
<li>Vertical transmission (e.g. transmission from the birth canal) can result in anogenital and laryngeal warts.</li>
<li>The dermal papillae of the wart are thin and contain abundant blood vessels. These vessels correlate with the 'black dots' and pinpoint bleeding seen after trauma to the wart.</li>
<li>The incubation period for molluscum contagiosum is thought to be 2–7 weeks, but it may be as long as 6 months. Humans are the only known source of the causative virus.</li>
<li>It is spread through direct contact, fomites and autoinoculation. The</li>
</ul>
<p>period of communicability is unknown, but infectivity is considered to be low (although outbreaks have occurred).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="history">HISTORY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Length of time the warts/molluscum have been present.</li>
<li>Location and any pattern of distribution or spread (i.e. increasing or decreasing numbers of lesions, where lesions started, etc.).</li>
<li>Associated pain.</li>
<li>Treatments used prior to consultation (with results).</li>
<li>The degree to which the warts are bothering parent and child.</li>
<li>Other family members affected.</li>
<li>Expectations of the consultation.</li>
<li>If perianal or genital warts are present (especially if children are &gt;3 years of age), a careful history for sexual abuse</li>
</ul>
<p>9 Dermatological problems</p>
<p>is required. This should include maternal or paternal history of anogenital warts and history of warts in close contact of child.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physical-examination">PHYSICAL EXAMINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Privacy during the examination (especially with perianal or genital warts) is key. Children may have experienced name-calling at school or may be generally embarrassed about their warts (especially if they are multiple); therefore, they may be reluctant to show them and extra sensitivity is required.</li>
<li>Examine the entire patient for a potential source of infection (especially important for perianal or genital warts). In addition, it is wise to check parents/carers to rule out heteroinoculation.</li>
<li>Document size, location and number of lesions with a diagram; careful documentation at presentation allows for comparison at subsequent consults.</li>
<li>Typical appearances of different types of warts are outlined in Table 9.23.</li>
<li>Warts are more likely in areas of trauma. In addition, with autoinoculation, they may appear in a linear pattern.</li>
<li>While less common than other routes of transmission among children &lt; 3 years of age, it is important to carefully check for signs of sexual abuse when any child presents with perianal and genital warts.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="differential-diagnoses">DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differential-diagnoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Most warts (especially common warts) are distinguishable on clinical grounds and the diagnosis is straightforward. However, the following should be considered:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Flat warts: consider dermal nevi, molluscum contagiosum, milia, folliculitis and lichen planus.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Plantar warts: consider corns, calluses, and foreign bodies. Mosaic warts (multiple lesions particularly on the heel) can be confused with pitted keratolytis.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Anogenital warts: consider condyloma lata, molluscum contagiosum, skin tags and haemorrhoids.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The possibility of sexual abuse requires consideration if anogenital warts are present.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The differential list for molluscum contagiosum includes folliculitis, warts and condylomata accuminata.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Spontaneous resolution of both common warts and molluscum is high (66% of common warts will resolve within 2 years and most molluscum lesions have resolved within 1 year). Consequently, the decision to treat both common warts and molluscum is based on the child's age, extent of involvement and the degree to which the lesions are causing distress. In addition, because resolution of common warts is associated with cell-mediated immunity, watchful waiting is reasonable (especially in young children).</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Additional diagnostics: none usually required. Scraping of molluscum lesions will show molluscum bodies under magnification and the diagnosis of warts is typically apparent from physical examination.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pharmacotherapeutics: see Table 9.24.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Behavioural interventions:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stress the importance of 'no picking, scratching or manipulating warts'; it is often useful to cover the warts with a plaster.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Paring of common and plantar warts to remove excess keratin formation (and enhance treatment effects) is best achieved by gentle rubbing with a manicure emery board until the lesion is flat. Alternatively, disposable scalpel blades (sizes 10 and 15) are effective at removing hard skin of plantar warts.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Patient education:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Review pharmacotherapeutics and behavioural interventions with parent and child.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Discuss with parents the risk of infectivity. More specifically, explain that the mechanisms of transmission are not well understood and as such, it is difficult to predict infectivity. Children with impaired skin integrity and/or immunodeficiency are at greater risk of infection, but otherwise the risk of infection is fairly low. Infected children should not be prevented from attending school or nursery.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Explain to parents (and child) that good skin care and avoidance of 'picking' will also prevent infection.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Concordance with wart paints is generally not very good. Careful explanation about the necessity to persist with wart paint treatments over a significant period of time is essential.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Review with parents the importance of follow-up if lesions return. Explain that it is possible to have subclinical or latent infections despite clearing and with reappearance, treatment is best initiated early.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="follow-up">FOLLOW-UP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#follow-up" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Generally unnecessary in the majority of cases.</li>
<li>3-weekly appointments for cryotherapy if tolerated.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="medical-consult-specialist-referral">MEDICAL CONSULT/ SPECIALIST REFERRAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-consult-specialist-referral" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Any child with suspected sexual abuse.</li>
<li>Any child with extensive lesions, painful plantar warts or warts that are refractory despite adequate management.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="paediatric-pearls">PAEDIATRIC PEARLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paediatric-pearls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Due to a large proportion of warts and molluscum resolving spontaneously, no treatment is reasonable, especially in young children.</li>
<li>Approaches to treatment must be relevant to the severity of the problem. However, warts can be</li>
</ul>
<p>9.15 Viral skin infections (warts and molluscum contagiosum)</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Type of wart</th><th>Treatment</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Common</td><td>• Watchful waiting (see discussion in Management)</td></tr><tr><td>• Daily application of a keratolytic such as Salactol (salicylic acid 16.7%, lactic acid 16.7% in flexible collodion)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Prior to application, the surface of the wart should be gently rubbed with an emery board until flat</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• A drop of the paint should be applied to the centre of the wart and allowed to dry</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• The process should be repeated until the wart has completely disappeared</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• For persistent warts the use of cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen can be used; however, this procedure is painful and not well tolerated in young children</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Warts should be frozen for sufficient time (5–10 s) to cause the surrounding skin to develop a white halo. This can be repeated at 3-weekly intervals until the warts have resolved</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Plane</td><td>• A weak over-the-counter (OTC) keratolytic in gel form such as 12% salicylic acid (Salatac) or 26% Occlusal are beneficial</td></tr><tr><td>Plantar (verrucae)</td><td>• Best treated initially with salicylic acid plasters (40%)</td></tr><tr><td>• As much of the hard, overlying skin should be pared away as is possible with application of a piece of the salicylic plaster to exactly cover the wart; hold the plaster in place with an adhesive bandage</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• The plaster should be left in place for 24–48 hours with the process repeated until the wart has disappeared</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Cryotherapy can be used in the treatment of plantar warts but is extremely painful and not well tolerated by children (see above)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• For multiple plantar warts (mosaic warts) the use of formalin soaks is more effective</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• The affected area should be soaked every night for 10–15 min (it is necessary to protect the surrounding skin with petroleum jelly)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• After each soak the soft tissue can be gently pared away</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Genital and perianal (anogenital warts)</td><td>• Effective treatment can be obtained with podophyllin (15%, 20% or 25% in benzoin compound tincture)</td></tr><tr><td>• Podophyllin is an extract of plant root and highly irritant. The surrounding skin should be protected with petroleum jelly. Note that it is usually an outpatient procedure</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Use a cotton bud to paint the podophyllin onto the individual lesions. The paint should be allowed to dry</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• The treated area should be washed 4 hours after podophyllin application using soap and water</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• This treatment programme has to be repeated weekly for the next 4–6 weeks</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Cryotherapy is also an effective form of treatment, but it has limitations with young children (see above)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• In young children genital and perianal warts are usually acquired non-sexually (vertical transmission, inoculation by carer). However, the possibility of child sexual abuse must be considered and/or ruled out</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Molluscum contagiosum (water wart)</td><td>• Watch and wait (6–12 months) for spontaneous resolution; family will require reassurance during this time. After 1 year without resolution, refer for dermatology evaluation</td></tr><tr><td>• Cryotherapy is an effective treatment, but it has limitations with young children (see above)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Additional treatment available in specialist care (i.e. paediatric dermatology)</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>upsetting for both parents and children; name-calling and bullying are not uncommon (especially among children with extensive lesions). Consequently, it is important to negotiate a treatment plan that is acceptable to both parent and child and considers the degree of distress the lesions are causing.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Whereas it is generally accepted that anogenital warts in young children (those under 3 years or age) are acquired through non-sexual contact, the possibility of sexual abuse must always be considered.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Black pinpoint dots are often on the surface of warts; they are a function of thromboses capillaries.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Plantar warts interrupt natural skin lines, calluses do not.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Consider the possibility of underlying immunodeficiency in children with extensive, treatment refractory HPV infection.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bibliography">BIBLIOGRAPHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bibliography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<p>CHAPTER 10</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="problems-related-to-the-head-eyes-ears-nose-throat-or-mouth">Problems Related to the Head, Eyes, Ears, Nose, Throat or Mouth<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#problems-related-to-the-head-eyes-ears-nose-throat-or-mouth" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="10-1-congenital-blocked-nasolacrimal-duct">10.1 CONGENITAL BLOCKED NASOLACRIMAL DUCT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#10-1-congenital-blocked-nasolacrimal-duct" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Anna Hunter</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Blockage of the nasolacrimal duct is defined as an obstruction in the portion of the tear drainage system that extends from the lacrimal sac to the nose.</li>
<li>Congenital blockage of the nasal lacrimal duct is a common complaint in the newborn period, as at birth the lower end of the nasolacrimal duct is frequently non-canalised (usually near the inferior meatus of the nose).</li>
<li>Canaliculisation of the nasolacrimal duct occurs spontaneously or by conservative medical management during the infant's first year of life.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology">PATHOPHYSIOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>In fetal development, the nasolacrimal duct is the last part of the lacrimal drainage system to canaliculise.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The lacrimal system has two parts (Fig. 10.1): the tear-secreting system (e.g. the lacrimal gland and its accessory lacrimal glands) and the plumbing system (e.g. the upper and lower lacrimal puncti, canaliculi and nasolacrimal ducts).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Canaliculisation of the lacrimal apparatus begins at the end of the first trimester of pregnancy and is usually completed by the seventh month <em>in utero</em>. Occlusion of the nasolacrimal duct is due to failure of complete canaliculisation of the lacrimal system at birth.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tears are composed of three layers: a lipid layer, an aqueous layer and a mucin layer. The lipid layer is the outermost layer and is produced by the meibomian glands of the eyelids; its function is to retard the evaporation of the aqueous layer.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The middle, aqueous layer of the tear film is produced by the lacrimal gland and the accessory lacrimal glands (situated in the upper and outer orbital margins). The inner, mucin layer is produced by the goblet cells in the conjunctiva. This innermost layer has direct contact with the conjunctiva of the eye and provides a wettable surface for the aqueous layer to adhere to.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Normal tears contain several antimicrobial substances such as lysozyme, betalysin, lactoferrin and immunoglobulins (IgA, IgG).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Opening and closing of the eyelids (e.g. normal blinking) acts as a pumping mechanism. When the eyes are closed, tears (along with the micro debris) are collected and drawn into the lacrimal punctum; when the eyes are open, this mixture is expressed into the nose.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In the baby with the congenital blocked tear duct, tears cannot drain and the stagnant tear film accumulates debris and exudate from the tarsal glands that becomes a focus for infection.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251224-9aea0c8b.jpeg" alt="img-2.jpeg">
Figure 10.1 The lacrimal system.</p>
<p>10.1 Congenital blocked nasolacrimal duct</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="history">HISTORY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Onset of symptoms and when the watery discharge was first noticed: typically an infant presents to the surgery or clinic at about 2 months of age (the time when full tear flow is established) with a complaint of 'watery eye', or 'cold in the eye with matter'.</li>
<li>Presence of discharge and if so, type amount, consistency, degree of inflammation, etc.</li>
<li>Involvement of one or both eyes.</li>
<li>Other eye infections or eye symptoms (especially at birth or soon after).</li>
<li>General state of health and well-being (growth, developmental milestones, etc.).</li>
<li>Other systemic complaints: fever, cough, irritability, upper respiratory tract infection (URTI) symptoms, etc.</li>
<li>Treatments tried thus far with effectiveness.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physical-examination">PHYSICAL EXAMINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Observe the general appearance, alertness and engagability of the infant. Pay attention to mother's level of anxiousness and confidence in handling/interacting with her infant. Outline the plan for the physical examination and describe your findings.</li>
<li>Head and ear, nose and throat (ENT): inspect the eyelids (maceration, swelling, inflammation), especially the lower eyelid towards the nasal aspect. Note any crusted discharge around the lids and lashes; always compare the affected side with the unaffected. The lower lid margin may be macerated (as a function of the increased discharge). Inspect the conjunctiva (palpebral and bulbar); mild conjunctivitis of the palpebral membranes may be seen, but the bulbar conjunctiva is usually clear and white. Palpate gently around the nasal aspect of the lower lid (pressing gently on lacrimal sac); note any tenderness and/or expression of material from the puncta.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="differential-diagnoses">DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differential-diagnoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Additional causes of increased tear production include (all ages):</li>
</ul>
<p>congenital glaucoma (rare), reflex tearing secondary to dry eye, seventh nerve palsies (rare), trichiasis, entropion.</p>
<ul>
<li>Additional causes of decreased eye drainage include (rare): imperforate puncta or canaliculi, ectropion, lateral canthus dystropia, traumatic injury to the nasolacrimal duct.</li>
<li>The possibility of bacterial or viral conjunctivitis should be ruled out (see Sec. 10.3), as well as the possibility of nasolacrimal abscess and/or dacryocystitis (acute infection of the nasolacrimal sac).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Additional diagnostics: usually none are required unless the possibility of acute infection is under consideration and then a swab would be indicated. Some clinicians advocate the use of a dye disappearance test; fluorescein is applied to the conjunctival sac and after 5-10 min the patient is observed. If normal (i.e. negative test) the tear meniscus will have minimal staining after 10 min; in an abnormal (i.e. positive test) the height of the stain will either increase or fail to decrease.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pharmacotherapeutics: use a broad-spectrum antibiotic ophthalmic ointment such as chloramphenicol ointment (1%) applied three times daily to the affected eye or Fucithalmic 1% applied twice daily for a week. Ointment is preferable so the medication stays around the target area (e.g. the conjunctiva and lacrimal duct). Note that antibiotics should only be used if drainage is present with inflammation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Behavioural interventions:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Remind carers to wash their hands before and after attempting nasolacrimal duct massage.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Massage of nasolacrimal duct area (Creiger's manoeuvre) several times a day; the goal is to increase hydrostatic pressure on the walls of the blocked nasolacrimal canal in order to rupture the membranous obstruction. Place the index finger over the common canaliculus area to block the exit of the material</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>through the puncta and apply downward pressure. Alternatively, in order to promote canaliculisation of the duct, the carer can apply gentle pressure to the skin over the medial eyelids and lacrimal sac with 10 straight downward motions (towards the nose) 4 times daily.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Patient education:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Review massage technique with carer and have him/her demonstrate this.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Discuss signs and symptoms of an acute eye infection, as it is not uncommon for the blocked duct to become infected (dacryocystitis).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="follow-up">FOLLOW-UP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#follow-up" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>If spontaneous resolution (95% of infants by 12 months of age), none required. Consider re-evaluation at 6 months of age (if no resolution), as referral will need to be considered (see Referral).</li>
<li>Consider follow-up phone contact if carer especially anxious.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="medical-consult-specialist-referral">MEDICAL CONSULT/ SPECIALIST REFERRAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-consult-specialist-referral" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Any infant in whom there is no resolution within 6 months, as it is likely that there will need to be probing of the canaliculus under a general anaesthetic. Note that the success rate for correction of the persistently blocked duct (dacryostenosis) is age-sensitive: 96% if probing and irrigation are performed before 13 months of age; 77% if the procedure is performed between 13 and 18 months of age; and 54% success rate if performed between 18 and 24 months of age. As such, consider the length of time between referral, initial consultation and likely waiting time for correction.</li>
<li>Any infant in whom there is ambiguity with regard to the diagnosis.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="paediatric-pearls">PAEDIATRIC PEARLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paediatric-pearls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The diagnosis of a blocked nasolacrimal duct can be confirmed if the contents of the nasolacrimal duct are expelled when gentle pressure is applied underneath the lacrimal duct on the nasal aspect.</li>
</ul>
<p>Problems related to the head, eyes, ears, nose, throat or mouth</p>
<ul>
<li>Nasolacrimal massage and instillation of ophthalmic medication are usually easier while the infant is feeding. Alternatively, if the carer sings a nursery song that involves 'beeping' the nose or stroking the cheek, nasolacrimal massage can be incorporated into the song's routine ('rub, rub, rub your little nose').</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bibliography">BIBLIOGRAPHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bibliography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Crawford JA. Lacrimal duct disorders. Int J Ophthalmol 1984; 24:39-53.</p>
<p>Kanski J. Clinical ophthalmology, 2nd edn.
Oxford: Butterworth-Heinemann; 1989.
Kushner B. Congenital nasolacrimal system obstruction. Arch Ophthalmol 1982; 100:597-600.
Nelson LB, Calhoun JH, Harsey RD. Pediatric ophthalmology, 3rd edn. Philadelphia: WB Saunders; 1991.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="10-2-eye-trauma">10.2 EYE TRAUMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#10-2-eye-trauma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Rebecca C. Robert and Janet Marsden</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Eye trauma is a common reason for primary care or Accident and Emergency (A&amp;E) visits. The reported incidence of traumatic ocular injuries depends on country, type of injury and treatment centre. Nonetheless, several common features appear in the paediatric population: (1) higher frequency of injuries occur in school-age children and adolescents; (2) the male-to-female predominance; (3) injuries are commonly sustained during sports and recreational activities (especially those that involve the use of a ball); and (4) injuries are more likely to occur during unsupervised play.</li>
<li>Eye trauma ranges from relatively benign corneal abrasions to serious and potential sight-blinding globe ruptures. The decision to manage and/or refer depends on the extent of ocular trauma and its potential consequences.</li>
<li>Nurse practitioners (NPs) must systematically and skilfully evaluate the eye trauma patient and make decisions with regard to appropriate management, referral and/or emergency treatment.</li>
<li>The most common ocular injuries covered in this section are outlined in Table 10.1.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology">PATHOPHYSIOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The clear, transparent cornea overlying the iris and pupil is composed of five</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>Table 10.1 Common Cause of Ocular Injury</th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Type of injury</td><td>Common causes</td></tr><tr><td>Corneal abrasion</td><td>• Scratching eye with finger, branch, paper, metal, hairbrush, mascara wand, foreign body, contact lens (foreign body between lens and eye, improper fit, trauma on entry/removal, overwear), sunlamp, welding or carbon arc</td></tr><tr><td>Chemical burn</td><td>• Alkali agents (lye, cements, plaster), acids, solvents, detergents, tear gas, mace, sparklers, flares that contain magnesium hydroxide</td></tr><tr><td>Ultraviolet light injury</td><td>• Ultraviolet rays from sunlight or tanning machine (inappropriate use without safety goggles)</td></tr><tr><td>Foreign body</td><td>• Commonly: dirt, glass, rust, hair. Think intraocular foreign body for potential penetrating foreign bodies such as metal striking metal, or objects that enter while hammering</td></tr><tr><td>Traumatic iritis and hyphaema</td><td>• Blunt trauma (e.g. fist, balls)</td></tr><tr><td>Ruptured globe/perforation</td><td>• Severe direct blunt trauma (e.g. fist, balls, stone), projectile injuries (e.g. pellet guns, sling shots), sharp instrument entering the orbit (can lids, toys), foreign bodies which strike the eye during hammering. Posterior rupture may occur after blunt trauma and may not be obvious</td></tr><tr><td>Intraocular haemorrhages</td><td>• Normal birth process (rarely present after 3-4 weeks) • Child abuse: shaking of baby (shaken baby syndrome)</td></tr><tr><td>Orbital (blow-out) fractures</td><td>• Blunt trauma to the front of the eye</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>layers, the outermost being the epithelium. Partial or complete removal of a focal area of this epithelial layer (e.g. scratching eye with a hairbrush) exposes nerve endings with resultant ocular pain. This type of injury is classified as a corneal abrasion. Healing of the outermost epithelial layer does not result in scarring; however, if the corneal trauma interrupts deeper layers, scarring may occur. Small foreign bodies are a frequent cause of corneal abrasion, but if there is deeper penetration of the cornea, scarring may occur. Injury with larger objects, such as pieces of glass or metal, may result in corneal laceration. In addition, corneal lacerations may perforate the cornea, as may very-high-speed foreign bodies.</p>
<ul>
<li>A penetrating or lacerating injury through the full thickness of the cornea or sclera is a severe injury and can lead to damage to underlying structures or even loss of ocular contents.</li>
<li>Chemical trauma due to alkali or acid substances may also damage/disrupt the cornea and other tissues. Of these substances, alkalis are more damaging</li>
</ul>
<p>10.2 Eye trauma</p>
<p>due to their ability to lyse cell membranes and penetrate the cornea progressively. Acids precipitate proteins and therefore are not progressive; however, they may likewise cause devastating damage.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Behind the cornea (and in front of the lens) lies the anterior chamber, a space normally filled with clear, aqueous fluid. Blunt trauma to the eye may cause rupture of iris vessels with subsequent haemorrhage into the anterior chamber, termed <em>hyphaema</em>. The ciliary body, lying at the base of the iris and just behind it, contains ciliary muscles whose function is to contract and relax. This, in turn, enables the lens to change shape, resulting in visual accommodation. Inflammation of the ciliary body with ciliary muscle spasm produces ocular discomfort. Cycloplegic agents (e.g. cyclopentolate, tropicamide and homatropine) help to relieve the spasm and therefore a component of the pain. They are often used in the treatment of corneal abrasions or in the case of uveitis to keep the iris away from the lens where it may adhere.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Of the orbital structures, the medial wall and orbital floor are the most fragile and, as such, more susceptible to <em>fracture</em> from blunt trauma.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A ruptured globe results from severe trauma that causes disruption and disorganisation of the integrity of the globe, possibly with loss of ocular contents. Posterior rupture occurs after a high-speed blunt trauma and may not be obvious.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Ocular trauma may also cause an inflammatory response of the iris and ciliary body tissue with release of white blood cells and protein. This is known as <em>traumatic uveitis</em>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Figures 10.2 and 10.3 outline the important anatomy of the eye.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="history">HISTORY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Injury situation: how and when injury occurred (activity engaged in when trauma occurred); type of object, speed and direction (if known); and use of safety glasses.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Vision-related symptoms: onset, course and severity or any visual changes</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251224-6a6cec4a.jpeg" alt="img-3.jpeg">
Figure 10.2 Anatomy of the eye (cross-sectional view).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251224-a350136a.jpeg" alt="img-4.jpeg">
Figure 10.3 Anatomy of the external eye.</p>
<p>(binocular vision, blurred or decreased vision, photophobia and/or tearing); and characteristics of any ocular pain (dull, sharp, foreign body sensation, burning).</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Previous history of eye problems: prior injuries, surgeries, amblyopia, congenital abnormalities and any medical conditions that increase susceptibility to infection (immunocompromise, diabetes, etc.).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Visual acuity (prior to injury), if known, in addition to use of glasses or contact lenses.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Date of most recent tetanus immunisation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Table 10.2 outlines historical information commonly associated with traumatic ocular injuries.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="physical-examination">PHYSICAL EXAMINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>A systematic approach to the paediatric eye examination ensures a complete and accurate assessment of the eye. Move from external to internal—this approach is the least threatening to</li>
</ul>
<p>Problems related to the head, eyes, ears, nose, throat or mouth</p>
<p>children and helps gain their confidence (especially among younger children who are especially fearful of eye examinations/drops).</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Note that a drop of ocular anaesthetic often greatly facilitates the examination and may aide in the diagnosis of corneal/conjunctival disruption (as symptoms will be relieved). Proxymetacaine is preferred in children as it does not sting.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>To open swollen (or forcibly shut) eyelids, place thumbs on the infraorbital and supraorbital rims (thus avoiding any pressure on the globe in the case of possible traumatic globe rupture). Likewise, take care if there is any possibility of fracture.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Always examine both eyes. After completing the basic examination, proceed with fluorescein staining if indicated. Table 10.2 outlines physical examination findings characteristic of various ocular injuries.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Note that a history of an ocular chemical burn is an eye emergency and, therefore, the injured eye should be irrigated before completing a complete eye examination.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Assess visual acuity, peripheral vision and ocular movements: be sure to measure acuity in each eye individually (cover each eye well) and both eyes together. Note if there is an eye preference or if the child objects to the covering of one eye over the other.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Table 10.2 Common Findings in Ocular Injuries</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Type of ocular injury</th><th>Findings</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Corneal abrasion</td><td>·Mild to sharp/severe pain with foreign body sensation, photophobia, tearing and redness ·Fluorescein stain ‘lights up’ in the traumatised area, conjunctival injection, eyelid oedema</td></tr><tr><td>Chemical burn</td><td>·Ocular pain and burning</td></tr><tr><td>Conjunctival ischaemia</td><td>·Epithelial defects ‘light up’ on fluorescein stain (may range from mild defects to corneal opacity), hyperaemia, mild eyelid oedema, burns of the periocular skin, abnormal pH</td></tr><tr><td>Conjunctival blanching</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Vessel attenuation</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Ultraviolet light injury</td><td>·Ocular pain and photophobia ·Fluorescein stain ‘lights up’ a diffuse punctate stain, injected eye, tearing and discomfort</td></tr><tr><td>Foreign body/perforation</td><td>·Foreign body sensation, pain, tearing, decreased vision (with intraocular foreign body) ·Visualisation of foreign body on cornea or conjunctiva, may have vertical lines that ‘light up’ with fluorescein, differentiate a foreign body under the upper lid from an object dragged across cornea by the lid ·Conjunctival injection, eyelid oedema ·Sharp trauma to the cornea may show drainage of aqueous fluid (illuminated with fluorescein) or an irregular pupil</td></tr><tr><td>Conjunctival laceration</td><td>·Mild pain, foreign body sensation, red eye ·Under white light and fluorescein staining, conjunctiva may appear to be rolled up on itself</td></tr><tr><td>Traumatic uveitis (iritis)</td><td>·Dull aching/throbbing pain, photophobia, tearing ·Perilimbal injection, pain in traumatised eye when light is shone in either the non-traumatised or traumatised eye, small or large pupil sometimes decreased vision</td></tr><tr><td>Hyphaema</td><td>·Pain, blurred vision ·Loss of red reflex, presence of haemorrhage in front of iris</td></tr><tr><td>Ruptured globe (sclera or cornea is disrupted)</td><td>·Pain, decreased vision ·Dark spot on the sclera (may indicate uveal prolapse), oval-shaped pupil</td></tr><tr><td>Intraocular haemorrhages</td><td>·If retinal haemorrhages only, no symptoms ·Retinal haemorrhages on fundoscopy</td></tr><tr><td>Orbital fracture</td><td>·Pain (especially on attempted vertical eye movement), local tenderness, binocular double vision, eyelid swelling, crepitus after nose blowing ·Inability to look upward or lateral direction, point tenderness, crepitus, orbital oedema ·Enophthalmos</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Toys/bright objects can be used ('look for the toy') as an aid to the assessment of ocular movements and peripheral vision.</p>
<ul>
<li>Examine external eye structures, including the lid and orbital area. Note any swelling, lacerations, discoloration, crepitus, debris and/or discharge. Remove debris, discharge, etc., using warm water or saline irrigation.</li>
<li>Examine conjunctival and corneal surfaces: note clarity, injection, haemorrhages, size, shape and response of pupils to light. If pupils demonstrate anisocoria, check under dim illumination to note whether the size difference of the pupil changes (change = abnormal, no change = normal variant). Check for irregularities in the shape of the pupil and iris. An irregularly shaped pupil may indicate damage to the iris or perforation of the globe.</li>
<li>Assess the fundus and ocular components (including documentation of red reflex).</li>
<li>Fluorescein staining is used to highlight any damaged corneal epithelial cells, such as in corneal abrasion. It also outlines any abrasions of the conjunctiva. To perform, use a single use Minim to instill a drop or a fluorescein-impregnated paper strip touched to the inferior canthus while the patient looks upward; then have the patient blink once. Any damage to the corneal epithelium will 'light up' a bright yellow colour. The colour is intensified by using the cobalt blue light on the ophthalmoscope (a slit lamp can also be use if available). Document the location and size of the epithelial defect (extremely helpful for future assessment of healing).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="differential-diagnoses">DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differential-diagnoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The cause of the ocular injury is often apparent from the patient's history. However, infection should be ruled out (see Sec. 10.3) and non-accidental injury (NAI) should be considered as a possibility in children and adolescents presenting with traumatic eye injuries. In addition</li>
</ul>
<p>10.2 Eye trauma</p>
<p>consider trauma complicated by infection, hordeolum, chalazion, dacryocystitis, herpes simplex keratitis (fluorescein stain illuminates lesion with a dendritic pattern), refractive error, orbital tumour, referred pain (e.g. sinusitis, tooth abscess) and glaucoma.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Additional diagnostics: with the exception of tests of visual acuity and fluorescein staining, any other tests require referral to ophthalmology.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pharmacotherapeutics: dependent on the specific ocular injury (Table 10.3). However, for the majority of eye trauma managed by NPs, pain can be controlled with oral analgesics and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) ophthalmic drops. Note that anaesthetic eye drops should only be used to facilitate the initial eye examination (and never for pain relief post-injury) as they will inhibit re-epithelialisation of the cornea. If their use is prolonged, further damage will result to the cornea. Any loss of corneal epithelium gives a route for pathogen ingress which may lead to corneal or intraocular infection. All corneal epithelial loss should be treated prophylactically with a broad-spectrum topical antibiotic.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Behavioural interventions: aetiology-specific (see Table 10.3).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Patient education: review with all families the medications to be</p>
</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>Type of injury</th><th>Behavioural interventions and pharmacotherapeutics</th><th>Follow-up</th><th>Ophthalmology referral</th><th>Comments</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Corneal abrasion</td><td>• Fluorescein stain (with documentation of result)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Cycloplegic agent not typically used in young children; pain control can usually be achieved with ophthalmic non-steroidal anti-inflammatory (NSAID) such as diclofenac (Voltarol) or ketorolac (Aculor). Note, however, these drugs are not licensed for use in children</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Apply generous amount of broad-spectrum antibiotic ointment (chloramphenicol)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• No patching required</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Continue ointment four times daily for 5 days</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Discontinue contact lens use until at least 1 week after completely healed</td><td>• Follow-up in 24 hours to assure abrasion has healed/decreased in size</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Usually no further follow-up required if first 24 hours were uncomplicated; children usually heal quickly</td><td>• Abrasions not showing signs of healing within 24 hours</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Increase or worsening of symptoms</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Any abrasion due to contact lens use</td><td>• Antibiotic ointment generally preferred because it offers a better barrier function between eyelid and abrasion</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Research has shown no benefit to patching and in young children may increase the risk of amblyopia development</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Most corneal abrasions heal within 3 days</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Use of cycloplegic agent among young children increases the possibility of amblyopia (even in 24 hours)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Cycloplegic may be used in management of uveitis</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Chemical burn</td><td>• Immediate irrigation with normal saline</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Evert lid and irrigate underneath. Consider irrigating eye from medial to lateral aspect of eye</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• After 5–10 min of irrigation, check pH with litmus paper. Continue irrigation until pH reaches 6.8–7.5 (this may take 1–2 litres of fluid), then refer immediately</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Do not delay referral to ophthalmology</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Medication (antibiotics, steroids, cycloplegic, etc., as per ophthalmology)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Systemic pain medicine as needed</td><td>• As per ophthalmology</td><td>• Immediate referral</td><td>• Immediate (and copious) irrigation is vital</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Bottled water or tap water may be used if no other fluids available</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Helpful to set up intravenous (IV) tubing (without needle) and continuously irrigate with this apparatus</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Ultraviolet light injury</td><td>• Fluorescein stain</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• If positive findings: apply drop of cycloplegic agent and provide systemic pain relief and ketorolac (Aculor) NSAID ophthalmic drops. Note not licensed for use in children</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Avoidance of sun, use of sunglasses, hat</td><td>• If symptoms settle, no further follow-up required</td><td>• If fluorescein stain reveals lesion → chloramphenicol ophthalmic drops or ointment</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Ophthalmology referral if no resolution within 24 hours</td><td>• Follow-up if no improvement in 24–48 hours</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Importance of prevention (i.e. sun safety) reinforced, especially use of sunglasses when sun reflecting on snow or water; use of protective goggles with sun beds/lamps, etc.</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• If corneal injury, erosions will always be present</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>(continued)</p>
<p>Problems related to the head, eyes, ears, nose, throat or mouth</p>
<p>Table 10.3 continued</p>
