<p>used for home management, signs and symptoms of problems and the plan for follow-up care. In addition, promotion of eye safety and prevention of eye trauma</p>
<p>should be reviewed. More specifically:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Play should be supervised and sharp objects, pellet guns, air guns, etc., should not be used as toys.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Extreme caution, avoidance or restricted use of fireworks such as sparklers.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Use of protective eye wear in sports (or activities) where there is greater</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>10.3 The 'red eye'</p>
<p>potential for injury. This includes use of safety glasses in classrooms such as woodworking and chemistry.</p>
<ul>
<li>Mandatory eye wear in sports for children with one functioning eye or recent ocular surgery.</li>
<li>Familiarity with use of eyewash fountains in schools.</li>
<li>Appropriate storage of strong alkalines such as caustic soda, oven cleaner, cement, mortar, plaster and household cleaners.</li>
<li>Appropriate cleaning and wear of contacts lenses as well as annual eye examinations to check fit and condition of lenses.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="follow-up">FOLLOW-UP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#follow-up" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Dependent on the specific injury involved (Table 10.3) and at the discretion of ophthalmology. However, in general (and regardless of the aetiology of the injury), there should be improvement in pain and symptoms on a daily basis. If there is not (or if the symptoms become worse), an emergency re-assessment and/or ophthalmology referral are required.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="medical-consult-specialist-referral">MEDICAL CONSULT/ SPECIALIST REFERRAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-consult-specialist-referral" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Any child with significant symptomatology or traumatic injury.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any child with foreign body sensation for &gt;24 hours.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any child without improvement in symptomatology within 24 hours.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any child with a corneal ulcer, chemical burn, penetrating trauma, orbital fracture, lid laceration, traumatic iritis, hyphaema or ruptured globe (Table 10.3).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="paediatric-pearls">PAEDIATRIC PEARLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paediatric-pearls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Maintain an ‘eye box’ complete with anaesthetic ophthalmic drops, cycloplegic agents, antibiotic ointment and drops, indicator paper, fluorescein strips or drops, normal saline, eye shields, intravenous (IV) tubing, etc. This greatly facilitates an efficient, accurate eye examination and treatment.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Patching is no longer the standard recommendation in the treatment of corneal abrasion (however, some cases may require patching by an ophthalmologist).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Never prescribe anaesthetic drops—this will inhibit re-epithelialisation of the cornea.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>To instil ophthalmic drops in an uncooperative child, hold child tightly, pull lower lid down gently and instil drops into fornix or onto exposed globe. Alternatively, lie the child on his back and instil drops onto closed lids and ask him to blink (this will not work for ointment instillation).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Consider an age-appropriate dose of chlorpheniramine, paracetamol or ibuprofen if child is unable to sleep.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Retinal haemorrhages in infants should always trigger initiation of a child protection pathway; they are child protection-related until proven otherwise.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bibliography">BIBLIOGRAPHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bibliography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cheng H, Burdon MA, Buckley S, et al. Emergency ophthalmology. London: BMJ; 1997.
Coody D, Banks JM, Yetman RJ, Musgrove K. Eye trauma in children: epidemiology, management, and prevention. J Pediatr Health Care 1997; 11:182-188.
Flynn CA, D'Amico F, Smith G. Should we patch corneal abrasions? A meta-analysis. J Fam Practice 1998; 47(4):264-270.
Forbes B. The management of corneal abrasions and ocular trauma in children. Pediatr Ann 2001; 30(8):465-472.
Levin AV. Eye emergencies: acute management in the pediatric ambulatory care setting. Pediatr Emerg Care 1991; 7(6):367-377.
Marsden J. Ophthalmic emergencies. In: Dolan B, Holt L, eds, Accident and emergency: theory into practice. London: Ballière Tindall; 2000.
Marsden J. Treating corneal trauma. Emerg Nurse 2001; 9(8):17-20.

Wingate S. Treating corneal abrasions. Nurse Pract 1999; 24(6):53-68.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="10-3-the-red-eye">10.3 THE 'RED EYE'<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#10-3-the-red-eye" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Judy Honig and Janet Marsden</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The ‘red eye’ refers to a variety of infectious and inflammatory ocular conditions. It is a very common ocular problem seen and treated in primary care. Although it is usually self-limiting and benign, it is important to identify the likely aetiology of the red eye and determine if the condition warrants further evaluation and/or management.</li>
<li>A diagnostic priority is to determine which ocular structure(s) are involved, as the differential diagnosis is largely determined by the sites involved (while considering developmental influences such as age).</li>
<li>As such, the objectives of the history, physical and management plan include (1) assessment of the acuity and severity of the problem; (2) appropriate (and timely) ophthalmological referral (this is</li>
</ul>
<p>Problems related to the head, eyes, ears, nose, throat or mouth</p>
<p>especially relevant among patients with prolonged symptoms of a non-emergent nature, as the referral of emergent conditions is usually readily apparent); and (3) maintenance of optimal visual functioning through adequate follow-up.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology">PATHOPHYSIOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Pathophysiology is aetiology-specific. However, inflammation of the conjunctiva is by far the most common cause of red eyes. It is defined as hyperaemia of the bulbar and/or palpebral conjunctiva (mucous membranes covering the front part of the eyeball) and may be associated with inflammation of the episclera or sclera, the cornea, eyelid and (occasionally) deeper structures.</li>
<li>Corneal ulceration, which also results in a red eye, affects the outer layers of the cornea and into the stroma (the third of the cornea's five layers). Corneal ulceration is commonly the result of pathogenic invasion (bacteria, virus or other) or may be the result of an autoimmune response.</li>
<li>Note that the anatomy of the eye can be found in Figs 10.2 and 10.3 (see Sec. 10.2).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="history">HISTORY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Onset, duration and severity (including age at onset of problem).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>History of trauma (see Sec. 10.2).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Detailed description of any discharge, including amount and appearance (profuse/scant, watery/mucopurulent, stringy/crusting, etc.).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Systemic symptoms or recent history of infection (e.g. URTI, fever, chills, neck/joint pain, rashes, ear pain, sore throat, sneezing, etc.).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Musculoskeletal complaints.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Visual problems, including photophobia and blurry vision.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Complaints of scratchiness or burning under the eyelids (especially common to have complaints of 'grittiness' with conjunctivitis).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Foreign body sensation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pain or tenderness in and around the eye.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Use of contact lenses.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Use of home treatments/ self-management.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Current medications.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Exposure to chemicals, irritants and/or infections (e.g. herpes simplex).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Exposure to others (family, classmates, daycare or nursery attendance) with the same symptoms.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Is the red eye a recurring and/or seasonal condition.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Family history of allergy or atopy.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physical-examination">PHYSICAL EXAMINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>General appearance of the child: this includes vital signs, activity level, allergic facies, obvious trauma, head lice, etc.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Head and ear, nose and throat (ENT):</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Eyes: careful examination to assess unilateral or bilateral involvement; oedema of the orbital/periorbital area, conjunctiva, eyelids or other structures (evert eyelid); redness/pinkness of conjunctiva (bulbar and palpebral), including the texture (e.g. 'bumpiness' of conjunctivae is associated with viral or allergic conjunctivitis); discharge (type, consistency, colour); pupillary function, ocular movements, visual acuity and fields of vision. Fluorescein staining can be used to assess the cornea (see Additional diagnostics). Be sure to note any pain; lesions/vesicles on the face, eyelids, and mucous membranes; tearing and/or foreign body sensations (evert eyelid). Note that subconjunctival haemorrhage is associated with Haemophilus influenzae and Streptococcus pneumoniae infections.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Ears: colour, opacity, landmarks, light reflex and mobility of the tympanic membrane. Note presence/absence of fluid behind drum.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Nose: colour and consistency of turbinates (grey, dull, swollen/ boggy turbinates indicative of allergic disease); patency of nares and any nasal discharge.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Throat/mouth: hydration status, lesions, tonsils (colour, presence of exudate, size) and condition of teeth. Also note cracked/peeling or bleeding lips and/or mucous membranes.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Lymph: presence of cervical lymphadenopathy (especially preauricular and cervical adenopathy).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Routine cardiovascular, respiratory, abdominal and musculoskeletal examination. Note any abnormalities, including painful joints.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="differential-diagnoses">DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differential-diagnoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The most common cause of a red eye is bacterial, viral, allergic or chemical/irritant conjunctivitis. However, given the non-specificity of the complaint 'my child's eye is red', it is important to think broadly with regard to potential aetiologies. Likewise, it is important to identify cases that require specialist intervention and/or immediate attention. An expanded list of conditions that can present with a red eye are outlined in Table 10.4.</li>
<li>Note that it is important to consider the age of the child and associated epidemiology (season, exposures, temporal factors, etc.) when evaluating the complaint of a red eye.</li>
<li>Always include Kawasaki's disease on the differential list especially when the red eye is accompanied by systemic symptoms (lymphadenopathy, desquamating or erythematous extremities, prolonged elevated temperature and mucous membrane involvement). Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis (JRA) may also present as intraocular inflammation. Early diagnosis has important implications for treatment, prognosis and morbidity.</li>
<li>Likewise, consider the possibility of JRA if there has been prolonged ocular inflammation and complaints of achiness and/or painful joints (the chronic uveitis associated with JRA can easily be misdiagnosed as conjunctivitis).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Largely aetiology-specific; however, general principles in management of the</p>
<p>10.3 The 'red eye'</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Table 10.4 Differential Diagnosis of the Red Eye</th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Area of redness and/or involvement</td><td>Consider</td></tr><tr><td>Ocular adnexa</td><td>• Infection: hordeolum and chalazion, congenital blocked nasolacrimal duct, blepharitis, lice infestation, sinus infection, orbital/periorbital cellulitis, dental abscess, contact dermatitis, seborrhoea</td></tr><tr><td>• Trauma: frequent eye rubbing, blunt trauma</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Tumours: neuroblastoma, leukaemia, neurofibroma, orbital tumours</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Other: prolonged crying, cavernous sinus thrombosis</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Conjunctiva</td><td>• Infection: viral, bacterial or parasitic infection</td></tr><tr><td>• Tumours: as above</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Toxic/environmental/drugs: atropine, scopolamine, smoke/dust/pollen, make-up, contact lenses, chemical exposure</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Allergy/inflammatory: allergic conjunctivitis, keratoconjunctivitis sicca (dry eye), nasal inflammation, collagen vascular diseases, Kawasaki syndrome, inflammatory bowel disease, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, juvenile rheumatoid arthritis (uveitis)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Other: subconjunctival haemorrhage (secondary to cough, vomiting, bacteraemia or blood dyscrasias)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Corneal involvement and conjunctival redness</td><td>• Infection: keratitis</td></tr><tr><td>• Trauma: contact lenses, corneal ulcer/abrasion, chemical irritant</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Pupil distortion with conjunctival redness</td><td>• Trauma: hyphaema or perforation</td></tr><tr><td>• Inflammation: uveitis (will also have pupil miosis with reduced vision in one or both eyes)</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>red eye are outlined below and management of common causes of conjunctivitis in children are outlined in Table 10.5.</p>
<ul>
<li>Additional diagnostics: conjunctivitis in the neonate should be cultured (with appropriate technique and medium) to rule out gonorrhoea, chlamydia, herpes or other organisms acquired during birth. Note that a sticky eye in an infant less than 21 days old is a reportable disease and the appropriate notification forms should be completed and sent to the local public health medicine department. In older children, consider culture only if an unusual or serious pathogen is suspected (i.e. conjunctivitis in contact lens wearer). Purulent conjunctivitis in an infant with blocked nasolacrimal duct is unlikely to require culture, unless the infection does not clear with topical antibiotics (see Sec. 10.1). Use fluorescein staining with a slit lamp, pen torch with cobalt blue filter or ophthalmoscope if corneal involvement is suspected; this is especially important if there is associated ocular pain or foreign body sensation: see also Section 10.2. If presepal or orbital cellulitis is suspected, blood cultures and a swab of the discharge should be obtained.</li>
</ul>
<p>Computed tomography (CT) should be considered when orbital cellulitis or neoplasm are under consideration.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Pharmacotherapeutics: Aetiology-specific; note, however, that if antibiotics are used they should be continued for 48 hours after the symptoms have resolved. Note that ophthalmic steroid preparations should not be used except under specialist care. Likewise, topical anaesthetics should never be used (except for the initial examination after corneal injury) as they delay healing time, can mask further damage and can lead to further corneal damage (see Sec. 10.2).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Behavioural interventions (for conjunctivitis):</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Careful handwashing before and after cleansing of eye area and administration of medication.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cleanse crusted drainage on lids and lashes with cotton wool ball (or tissue) moistened with cooled, boiled water; wipe from the inside of the eyelid (by the nose) towards the outside; single cotton ball for each wipe on each eye.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Do not share pillowcases; wash clothes or towels.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cool compresses to eye can provide symptomatic relief as can paracetamol or ibuprofen if there is pain associated with the acute infection.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Be sure parents can get drops into the child's eyes. If struggling to get eye drops in, position child on his back with eyes closed; place eye drops on lid junction and then have him open his eyes. An opportunity for instillation of medication may be taken when the child is asleep by moving one of the lids gently and dropping the preparation onto the globe.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For eye ointment, run a ribbon of ointment along the inside of the lower lid and then have the child shut his eyes to spread the ointment over the globe.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Patient education:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Review behavioural interventions (above) and stress with parent the importance of infection control (handwashing, no sharing of towels, etc.).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In general, the child can return to school or nursery 24-48 hours after antibiotic treatment is initiated (and if discharge has subsided).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Viral conjunctivitis often lasts up to 3 weeks, but secondary bacterial infection is common. Stress with parents the importance of returning or telephoning if there is no improvement or if things deteriorate.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="follow-up">FOLLOW-UP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#follow-up" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Generally none is necessary if the red eye resolves spontaneously or with treatment.</li>
<li>Return for further evaluation/treatment if no improvement or deterioration of condition occurs.</li>
<li>If, after initial improvement, the red eye returns, this may signal an adverse reaction to the medication. Discontinue medication and return to clinic. If no improvement after 7-10 days, refer.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="medical-consult-specialist-referral">MEDICAL CONSULT/ SPECIALIST REFERRAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-consult-specialist-referral" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Any child with a loss of, or a decrease in visual acuity.</li>
</ul>

<p>10.3 The 'red eye'</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Table 10.5 continued</th><th></th><th></th><th></th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Condition</td><td>Potential causes</td><td>Common findings</td><td>Treatment</td><td>Comments</td></tr><tr><td>Uveitis</td><td>·Inflammatory process often related to systemic disease</td><td>·Deep red inflammation</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>·Dull iris colour</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>·Pain in and around eye</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>·Reduction in vision</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>·Perhaps smaller, sluggish pupil in affected eye</td><td>·Immediate ophthalmology referral</td><td>·Usually treated with mydriatics and steroids</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>·Systemic investigations will be commenced and appropriate referral made by ophthalmologists</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Corneal ulcer</td><td>·Usually related to infectious process (viral or bacterial infection)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>·Three main types seen in ambulatory care: bacterial, marginal and dendritic</td><td>·Fluorescein stain will identify extent of lesion(s); however, often difficult to distinguish between the three main types</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>·Cornea will have an area(s) of white or greyish opacity; it will not appear clear</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>·Underlying corneal infiltrate will show up as a white spot, haze or opacity of the cornea.</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>The borders of the affected area may look as if they are slightly heaped up</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>·Complaints of pain, foreign body sensation tearing and (often) photophobia</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>·Will likewise have concomitant conjunctivitis and possibly swollen lids</td><td>·Immediate ophthalmology referral</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>·Antibiotics or antiviral treatment usually started after lesions scraped and Gram-stained</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>·Follow-up as per ophthalmology</td><td>·Corneal ulcers with a lower threshold for ophthalmology referral than corneal abrasions</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>·Delay in treatment of an infected ulcer can result in devastating intraocular infection</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>·Discontinue contact lens use until ulcer completely healed (if applicable)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul>
<li>Any child with an abnormal pupil and/or severe ocular pain.</li>
<li>Any child with suspected herpetic (including varicella) or gonococcal conjunctivitis, periorbital/orbital cellulitis and/or foreign body.</li>
<li>Any neonate with conjunctivitis or young child with marked conjunctivitis as they are at greater risk of orbital cellulitis due to their lack of a formed septum.</li>
<li>Any contact lens wearer with marked pain and/or conjunctivitis (due to the unusual organisms that may be involved).</li>
<li>Any child with corneal abrasion, corneal ulcer and/or pain for longer than 24 hours.</li>
<li>Any child with a corneal opacity.</li>
<li>Any child in whom the diagnosis is unclear or the red eye continues for a prolonged period (consider Kawasaki's disease, JRA or malignancy).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="paediatric-pearls">PAEDIATRIC PEARLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paediatric-pearls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Straightforward conjunctivitis will not decrease visual acuity or result in pupillary involvement. If present on physical examination, these findings should prompt immediate consultation and/or referral.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Thick, profuse and purulent discharge with foreign body sensation and eyes crusted shut with discharge is suggestive of bacterial conjunctivitis. Serous or lightly purulent discharge with profuse tearing is associated with viral infection. Bacterial conjunctivitis is, by far, the most common cause of a red eye in children. However, due to the increased risk of secondary bacterial infection in viral conjunctivitis, treatment of both infections is usually the same: broad-spectrum antibiotics with periodic removal of discharge. There should be improvement within 3-4 days with bacterial conjunctivitis and 2-3 weeks with a viral infection.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Conjunctivitis in the neonate requires aggressive evaluation and treatment. Significant, sticky, watery conjunctivitis appearing in the newborn 5-14 days after birth is likely to be chlamydia infection. It will require systemic antibiotics, treatment of the parents and reporting to the public health department.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Conjunctivitis accompanied by clusters of vesicles on face, eyelids and mucous membranes is indicative of herpetic infection (including varicella) and requires referral.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Swelling of lids with erythema, diffuse conjunctival hyperaemia with a</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>'cobblestone' appearance, itchiness and rhinitis are often associated with allergic conjunctivitis. In addition, a cold compress over red eyes that results in resolution of erythema is a diagnostic clue indicative of allergic conjunctivitis. Large 'cobblestones' should be referred to an ophthalmologist, as control of symptoms may require the use of topical steroids.</p>
<ul>
<li>Corneal ulcers often present as a 'red eye' without a history of trauma and they are usually due to a viral or bacterial infection. As such, a low threshold for fluorescein staining will decrease the possibility of a missed diagnosis, which can result in a devastating intraocular infection.</li>
<li>Haemophilus influenzae and Streptococcus pneumoniae infection are associated with subconjunctival haemorrhage.</li>
<li>Consider Kawasaki's disease with bilateral red eyes, non-purulent drainage and systemic symptoms.</li>
<li>Chronic uveitis is associated with pauciarticular JRA (involvement of less than five joints) and can be misdiagnosed as conjunctivitis. Although it is uncommon, it can lead to a loss of vision if not detected early. Note that uveitis is also known as iridocyclitis and iritis.</li>
</ul>
<p>10 Problems related to the head, eyes, ears, nose, throat or mouth</p>
<ul>
<li>Head lice that involve eyelashes can be treated by coating the eyelashes with petroleum jelly for a 12-hour period (see Sec. 9.12). In addition, consider the possibility of pubic lice in lashes (which will require referral).</li>
<li>Children with recurrent styes (hordeola) can benefit from daily washing of eyelids with baby shampoo (diluted with water) to reduce bacterial growth. In addition, recurrent styes can be associated with increased glucose levels; consider checking urine.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bibliography">BIBLIOGRAPHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bibliography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="10-4-common-oral-lesions">10.4 COMMON ORAL LESIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#10-4-common-oral-lesions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Kelly A. Barnes and Thomas R. Ollerhead</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The NP may be the first health care professional to encounter an oral lesion in an infant, child or adolescent.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Many of these lesions are benign, self-limiting and will not require treatment. However, it is important that the NP is familiar with the more common lesions and that she is able to determine the need for referral and follow-up of the less common (or less benign lesions).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The incidence of individual lesions varies. Some lesions are so common that they are considered a normal developmental variant (e.g. geographic tongue or palatal cysts), whereas others will require specialist intervention and management (e.g. parulis).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A glossary of dental definitions can be found in Table 10.6 and commonly encountered oral lesions are outlined in Table 10.7. Important anatomy of the tooth is illustrated in Figure 10.4.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology">PATHOPHYSIOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Lesion specific (see Table 10.6).</li>
</ul>
<p>Table 10.6 Glossary of Dental Terms</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Term</th><th>Definition</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Alveolar bone</td><td>• The bone of the maxilla and mandible which contains the teeth</td></tr><tr><td>Alveolar process</td><td>• If you were speaking about one arch, it would be the alveolar process of the maxilla or mandible</td></tr><tr><td>Alveolar mucosa</td><td>• The lining epithelium of the oral cavity</td></tr><tr><td>Alveolar ridge</td><td>• The ridge of bone where the teeth sit</td></tr><tr><td>Alveolar socket</td><td>• The socket is where the root of a tooth is housed within the alveolar bone</td></tr><tr><td>Alveolus</td><td>• A general term for alveolar bone</td></tr><tr><td>Ankylosis</td><td>• The cementum of the root is fused with alveolar bone, as such, the periodontal ligament space is absent in this condition</td></tr><tr><td>Anterior tongue</td><td>• The most forward aspect of the tongue</td></tr><tr><td>Apices</td><td>• The end of the root</td></tr><tr><td>Avulsion</td><td>• When a tooth is knocked completely out of the mouth</td></tr><tr><td>Buccal mucosa</td><td>• The lining mucosa of the oral mucosa on the side of the cheek</td></tr><tr><td>Carious</td><td>• Decay of the tooth's enamel and/or dentin</td></tr><tr><td>Carious communication</td><td>• Decay has progressed through the outer enamel into the dentin and entered the pulp chamber of the tooth. The pulp is normally a sterile environment, and when bacteria that cause decay enters this tissue, the stage is set for infection and abscess formation, be it acute or chronic</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>(continued)</p>
<p>10.4 Common oral lesions</p>
<p>COMMON PAEDIATRIC PROBLEMS</p>
<p>Table 10.6 continued</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Crown</th><th>• That portion of the tooth which is seen in the oral cavity</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Dorsal tongue</td><td>• The keratinised surface of the tongue (the taste buds are located on the dorsal aspect)</td></tr><tr><td>Eruption</td><td>• A tooth that emerges from the alveolar process to erupt through the soft tissue into the oral cavity</td></tr><tr><td>Exfoliation</td><td>• Primary (baby) teeth are lost when the permanent successors cause the resorption of the primary tooth roots</td></tr><tr><td>Intrusion</td><td>• A tooth that is forced inward into the alveolar process. This type of injury forces the periodontal ligament space to be compressed</td></tr><tr><td>Floor of the mouth</td><td>• The area under the tongue</td></tr><tr><td>Lateral luxation</td><td>• An injury to a tooth, whereby the tooth is moved in a lateral direction within the socket</td></tr><tr><td>Lingual</td><td>• Towards the tongue or having to do with the tongue</td></tr><tr><td>Lower anterior teeth</td><td>• The four incisors make up the four teeth in the anterior part of the mouth</td></tr><tr><td>Masticatory trauma</td><td>• Trauma sustained during mastication (eating)</td></tr><tr><td>Mucobuccal fold</td><td>• The fold of tissue within the oral cavity that makes up the vestible towards the lips or cheeks</td></tr><tr><td>Mucogingival junction</td><td>• The area where the keratinised gingiva (that surrounds the teeth) meets the soft, freely moveable, non-keratinised mucosa of the oral cavity</td></tr><tr><td>Occlude</td><td>• The action of bringing the teeth together into maximum contact (i.e. biting together)</td></tr><tr><td>Occlusal surface</td><td>• The chewing surface of the teeth, where the cusps and fossa are located</td></tr><tr><td>Periodontal structure</td><td>• The periodontium consists of the alveolar bone, cementum and the periodontal ligament. It is a general term for the collective support of the teeth</td></tr><tr><td>Primary dentition</td><td>• Baby teeth (milk teeth)</td></tr><tr><td>Pulp</td><td>• The nerve and blood supply of the tooth. It is this tissue which gives a tooth its vitality</td></tr><tr><td>Replantation</td><td>• When a tooth is avulsed (knocked out of the mouth) it can be replanted if it meets replantation criteria (see Sec. 10.5)</td></tr><tr><td>Root</td><td>• That area of the tooth that can usually only be visualised by a radiograph in a healthy dentition</td></tr><tr><td>Secondary dentition</td><td>• Permanent teeth</td></tr><tr><td>Subluxation</td><td>• An injury to a tooth whereby abnormal loosening occurs</td></tr><tr><td>Tooth germ</td><td>• The embryological structure where a tooth develops from</td></tr><tr><td>Upper anterior teeth</td><td>• The four upper incisors (laterals and centrals) make up the upper anteriors</td></tr><tr><td>Ventral tongue</td><td>• The underside of the tongue. Covered by vascular non-keratinised lining epithelium</td></tr><tr><td>Vermillion border</td><td>• Where the skin of the lips meets the skin of the face. It marks the transitional zone between internal mucous membrane and external skin</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Table 10.7 Common Oral Lesions</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Lesion</th><th>Definition and appearance</th><th>Comments</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Congenital lesions</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Palatal cysts</td><td>• Small keratin-filled developmental cysts</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• 1–3 mm in diameter and white or yellowish in colour</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Usually occur in clusters of 2–6, although they can be singular</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Appear most often along the midline of the palate near the junction of the hard and soft palates</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• May also occur more anteriorly along the midline or on the posterior palate, lateral to the midline</td><td>• Common in newborns</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• No treatment necessary (cysts are self-limiting and often resolve several weeks after birth)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Leukedema</td><td>• Diffuse, greyish-white coloration of the buccal mucosa</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Surface texture may appear wrinkled or thickened</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Lesions are usually bilateral and will not ‘rub off’</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Stretching of the cheek skin greatly diminishes the appearance of the lesion (or causes it to disappear); this is diagnostic for the lesion</td><td>• Variation of normal oral mucosa</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Increased prevalence in the black population</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Does not require treatment</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Natal teeth</td><td>• Natal teeth are present in the oral cavity at birth, whereas neonatal teeth erupt in the first 30 days of life</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Often erupt in pairs and 85% occur in the mandibular incisor area</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Thought to be caused by the superficial position of the tooth germ above the alveolar bone, which can result in insufficient root formation, mobility and premature exfoliation</td><td>• 1–10% of natal or neonatal teeth are supernumerary</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Treatment dependent on maintenance of a normal complement of primary dentition to allow for normal arch development</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Extraction recommended if extreme mobility or poor crown formation</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>(continued)</p>
<p>10 Problems related to the head, eyes, ears, nose, throat or mouth</p>
<p>Table 10.7 continued</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Lesion</th><th>Definition and appearance</th><th>Comments</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Commissural lip pits</td><td>• 1–4 mm invaginations that present as blind fistulas at the corners of the mouth on the vermillion border</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• May be unilateral or bilateral</td><td>• Seen more commonly in males than females</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Tendency to run in families suggests autosomal dominant trait</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• No treatment required</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Developmental borders</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Seen on dorsal and/or lateral borders of the tongue</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Erythema is caused by the atrophy of the filiform papillae of the tongue (aetiology unknown)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• The lesions may change shape or coalesce over short periods of time (weeks to months) and will spontaneously regress and reappear</td><td>• Common, benign condition often detected in routine examination</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Females affected more commonly than males (2:1)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Also called benign migratory glossitis or erythema migrans</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Usually asymptomatic but can be sensitive to spicy foods</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• No treatment necessary</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Fordyce granules</td><td>• Ectopic sebaceous glands found within the oral cavity</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Present as yellow or yellowish-white papular lesions, usually occurring in clusters</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Found most frequently on the buccal mucosa, on the cheeks and the inner surface of the lips, but may also be found in the retromolar area distal to the last molar and the anterior tonsillar pillar</td><td>• Represent normal anatomical variation of the oral mucosa</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Very common; more than 80% of the population have Fordyce granules</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• First appear at approx. 10 years of age; increase in number during puberty</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• No treatment necessary</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Retrocuspid papillae</td><td>• Appear as tissue enlargements of the mucosa that are lingual to the mandibular canine teeth at the mucogingival junction</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Usually bilateral, 2–3 mm in diameter, soft, sessile nodules</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Composed of normal mucosal connective tissue</td><td>• Have been reported in 72% of children less than 10 years of age</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• More common in females</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• No treatment necessary, most will regress with age</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Benign tumours</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Mucocele</td><td>• Fluid-filled bulla-type lesion that may range from a few millimetres to a centimetre or more in diameter</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Results from a traumatic rupture (e.g. lip biting or lip trauma) of a salivary gland duct that allow spillage of mucin into the surrounding soft tissue</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• 75% are found on the lower lip but can also affect buccal mucosa, anterior or ventral side of the tongue and floor of the mouth (termed a ranula)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• If palpated, the lesion feels fluctuant but firm</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Colour may be bluish grey (due to mucin in the tissues), although superficial lesions appear normal in colour</td><td>• 75% of cases found on lower lip</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Duration may vary from a few days to several years</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Most will rupture and subsequently heal on their own but long-standing ones may require surgical excision</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Fibroma</td><td>• Represents a reactive hyperplasia of fibrous connective tissue in response to local trauma</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Appears as an elevated, smooth surface nodule of normal mucosal colour</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Most commonly found on the buccal labial mucosa, but may be anywhere in the oral cavity</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Presents as either sessile or pedunculated and will usually feel firm to palpation</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Can range from a few millimetres to several centimetres in diameter</td><td>• Most common benign tumour of the oral cavity</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Usually asymptomatic, unless secondary trauma causes surface ulceration</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• If a known irritant is removed, the lesion may regress on its own</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• If fibroma is not associated with a known irritant, then surgical excision is indicated</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Papilloma</td><td>• The papilloma appears as an exophytic growth with many cauliflower-like projections</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• The lesion is well-circumscribed, pedunculated, and of normal mucosal hue</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Usually found on the tongue, hard/soft palate, buccal mucosa, gingivae, lips and/or uvula</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• The size ranges from a few millimetres to several centimetres in diameter</td><td>• Treatment consists of surgical removal</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• These lesions may or may not be associated with subtypes of the human papilloma virus (HPV)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Haemangioma</td><td>• Capillary haemangioma appears as flat area with reddish pigmentation which rapidly proliferates over first 6–12 months of life, producing an elevated lobulated mass that is red to purple in colour</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• See Section 9.4</td><td>• Most common benign tumour in infancy and childhood</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Capillary haemangioma is the most common</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• If not an aesthetic issue or subject to masticatory trauma may be left untreated (will undergo spontaneous involution)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Congenital epulis of the newborn</td><td>• Soft tissue tumour that occurs on alveolar ridge of the newborn</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Pink to red, smooth surface, pedunculated mass on alveolar ridge</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Often presents just lateral to the midline on the maxillary anterior ridge, but can occur on the mandibular ridge</td><td>• 90% occur in females</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Usually requires surgical excision, although complete regression has been reported in some cases</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>(continued)</p>
<p>10.4 Common oral lesions</p>
<p>Table 10.7 continued</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Lesion</th><th>Definition and appearance</th><th>Comments</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Odontogenic cysts</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Eruption cyst</td><td>• Soft, translucent swelling within the gingival mucosa overlying the crown of an unerupted deciduous or permanent tooth</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Cyst is produced by the accumulation of fluid within the follicular space surrounding the developing tooth</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Usually of normal mucosal colour but may be filled with blood, which will impart a purple to brown colour</td><td>• Usually found in children less than 10 years of age</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Treatment is not usually required as the cyst often ruptures or regresses spontaneously, allowing tooth eruption</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Alternatively, the cyst can be unroofed or if the tooth fails to erupt, excision of the roof of the cyst is indicated</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Parulis</td><td>• Soft, fluctuant, gingival mass that can occur on either the facial or lingual gingival tissue of a non-vital tooth. It is commonly called a 'gum boil'</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• It is the result of the infectious process from necrotic pulpal tissue in a tooth with a carious communication or severe traumatic injury</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• In the acute stage of the infection, the gingival swelling will appear and is often accompanied by pain and tenderness to palpation and mastication</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• The tooth may be mobile and extrude from the socket</td><td>• The acute stage of the infection may be accompanied by systemic symptoms such as fever, malaise and lymphadenopathy</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Accumulation of purulent material can lead to a sinus tract intraorally where drainage will occur</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Patients that do not develop a sinus tract may develop a facial cellulitis as the infection spreads through the facial spaces (see Sec. 9.6)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Requires immediate referral to a dentist or oral surgeon</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Treatment focuses on removal of the source of the infection. Options include endodontic therapy (e.g. root canal) or extraction of the tooth</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Infectious lesions</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1)</td><td>• Primary infection with HSV-1 in children is often subclinical, but if primary infection produces symptoms it is termed herpetic gingivostomatitis</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Onset of gingivostomatitis is acute and accompanied by fever (39.4–40.5°C), cervical lymphadenopathy, irritability and multiple oral lesions</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Lesions typically are small, pinpoint vesicles that rupture to form erythematous lesions that enlarge and develop focal areas of ulceration</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Lesions can occur along gingival, anterior tongue, hard palate and buccal mucosa with concurrent gingival swelling, pain and erythema. Often there is foul odour to breath</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Autoinoculation of eyes, face, chin, hands and genital area can occur (if ocular involvement, referral required see Sec. 10.3)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Recurrent infections occur in 30–40% of cases and represent a reactivation of latent HSV within the trigeminal ganglion. Most common site of recurrent infection is vermillion border of lips (termed herpes labialis) triggered by sunlight, stress, fatigue and trauma</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Recurrent lesions characterised by multiple, small papules that develop into fluid-filled vesicles. The vesicle ruptures usually within 2 days and complete healing often occurs within 7–10 days</td><td>• HSV is a member of the human herpes virus family</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• HSV-1 is spread through infected saliva or active perioral lesions (highly infectious)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Most common cause of stomatitis in children &lt;5 years of age; highest incidence occurs between 2 and 4 years of age</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Treatment is supportive and palliative (analgesia, antipyretics, fluids, nutrition)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Cold ice lollies and/or fluids can be helpful in relieving pain and encouraging oral intake</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Careful monitoring of food and fluid intake as dehydration can be a problem (secondary to oral pain and refusing fluids)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Mild cases resolve in 5–7 days but can extend to 2 weeks</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Acyclovir can be used to ameliorate recurrent infections but it must be started very early</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Highly communicable; newborns, children with eczema or burns and/or immunocompromised children must not be exposed</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Herpangina</td><td>• Begins acutely with abrupt onset of fever up to 40.5°C, sore throat, dysphagia, malaise and sometimes headache, vomiting and abdominal pain</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Oral lesions develop on the posterior oral cavity, usually on the tonsillar pillars, less frequently on the soft palate, tonsils or uvula</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Lesions are small red papules that quickly evolve into small vesicles on an erythematous base that ulcerate rapidly, leaving shallow ulcers 2–4 mm in diameter</td><td>• Caused by Coxsackie A virus and less commonly by Coxsackie B (enteroviruses)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Highly infectious and can occur in epidemic form mainly in the summer</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Treatment is palliative and supportive (analgesia, fluids, antipyretics)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Fever lasts 1–4 days, systemic symptoms improve in 4–5 days and recovery is usually complete in 1 week</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Careful monitoring of food and fluid intake as dehydration can be a problem (secondary to oral pain and refusing fluids)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Ice lollies and/or cold fluids can be helpful in relieving pain and encouraging oral intake</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Hand, foot and mouth (HFM)</td><td>• Enterovirus infection characterised by vesiculocutaneous stomatitis, papular or vesicular exanthema on the hands and/or feet and mild constitutional symptoms (low-grade fever to 38.5°C and malaise)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Lesions are almost always present and precede the appearance of the hand and foot lesions</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• The oral lesions are similar to those of herpangina but are not confined to the posterior oral cavity and may be more numerous</td><td>• Caused by Coxsackie A virus and less commonly by Coxsackie B (enteroviruses)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Highly infectious and can occur in epidemic form mainly in the summer</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Treatment is palliative and supportive (analgesia, fluids, antipyretics)</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>(continued)</p>
<p>Problems related to the head, eyes, ears, nose, throat or mouth</p>
<p>Table 10.7 continued</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Lesion</th><th>Definition and appearance</th><th>Comments</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td></td><td>·The labial and buccal mucosa as well as the tongue are the sites most commonly affected ·Hand and foot lesions less consistently present (occur in 1/4 to 2/3 of patients). Maculopapular eruptions that progress to vesicles. Rarely tender or pruritic and most commonly on dorsal aspects of fingers and toes but may also appear on palms, soles, arms, legs, buttocks and face</td><td>·Cold ice lollies and/or fluids can be helpful in relieving pain and encouraging oral intake ·Enlarged cervical nodes common</td></tr><tr><td>Recurrent aphthous ulcerations</td><td>·Ulcers arise on non-keratinised mucosa that is covered by a yellow-white fibrin purulent membrane surrounded by an erythematous halo ·The buccal and labial mucosa, ventral surface of the tongue, floor of the mouth, mucobuccal fold and soft palate are all commonly affected sites ·Minor aphthous ulcerations are usually between 3 and 10 mm in diameter and heal without scarring in 7–14 days. Pain is often proportional to the size of the ulceration ·Major, recurrent aphthous ulcerations are commonly 1–3 cm in diameter, are deeper and more painful than the minor variant, take 2–6 weeks to heal and may cause scarring</td><td>·Painful ulcers that begin in childhood and often continue into adulthood ·Onset of major aphthae is after puberty ·Aetiology unknown, although an autoimmune or hypersensitivity reaction of the oral epithelium has been postulated ·Contributing factors include local trauma, stress, food or drug allergies, nutritional deficiencies (folic acid, B12, and iron) and hormonal fluctuations ·Treatment of minor aphthae is supportive (see HFM), whereas major aphthae may require topical steroids, and/or dexamethasone elixir in addition to analgesia, adequate fluids and good nutritional support</td></tr><tr><td>Candidiasis</td><td>·Characterised by adherent white plaques that resemble cottage cheese on the oral mucosa ·The plaques can be removed by rubbing the area with gauze. The underlying mucosa will usually appear erythematous</td><td>·Opportunistic fungal infection caused by Candida albicans ·Called ‘oral thrush’ ·Commonly seen in infants and children ·Predisposing factors include an immunocompromise (including premature birth), broad-spectrum antibiotic usage, and/or steroid therapy ·Treatment includes debridement of mucous membranes with gauze prior to application of a topical antifungal (nystatin)</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251224-e0a403a0.jpeg" alt="img-5.jpeg">
Figure 10.4 Anatomy of a tooth.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="history">HISTORY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Age.</p>
<ul>
<li>Onset (acute or chronic), precipitating symptoms and duration of symptoms.</li>
</ul>
<p>Presence or absence of pain.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Swelling, induration or fluctuance.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Changes in the lesion(s) since onset.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Treatments attempted (with results).
History of trauma.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Medication use (note that phenytoin, cyclosporin, and calcium channel blockers have been implicated in gingival hyperplasia).
History of allergies.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Other contacts/family members with similar lesions.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Additional symptoms: fever, rash, malaise, systemic symptoms, inflammation.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="physical-examination">PHYSICAL EXAMINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>General appearance: Note the general appearance of the child (ill, well, playful, etc.) with attention to vital signs and level of activity. If systemic symptoms are present (or suspected) a complete physical examination will be required (see Ch. 4).</li>
<li>Head and ENT: careful assessment of the lesion(s) noting size, appearance, area(s) affected, presence of pain and/or inflammation, and distribution/location of the lesion(s).</li>
<li>Lymph: thoroughly evaluate the lymph nodes of the head and neck as</li>
</ul>
<p>10.5 Common oral trauma</p>
<p>infected/infectious lesions in the mouth can inflame the head and neck lymph chains.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="differential-diagnoses">DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differential-diagnoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Dependent on the aetiology of the lesion; however, it is important to always consider oral pathology and systemic infection as part of the differential list.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The management of oral lesion is aetiology-specific (see Table 10.6). However, general principles of management of commonly encountered oral lesions are outlined below.</p>
<ul>
<li>Additional diagnostics: not usually indicated. Exfoliative cytology studies can be performed if the diagnosis is in question. If an oral infection (secondary to a carious lesion) is suspected, radiographic studies would be warranted. Likewise, if systemic illness is assumed, then consider a full blood count, C-reactive protein, cultures or other diagnostics that may assist in confirming the diagnosis.</li>
<li>Pharmacotherapeutics: aetiology-specific; however (for the most part), medications used in the management of common oral lesions are limited to antipyretics, analgesics and, occasionally, antibiotics or antifungals.</li>
<li>Behavioural interventions:</li>
<li>It is important to keep the mouth as clean as possible; if brushing is not an option (due to pain from the lesions), suggest rinsing the mouth</li>
</ul>
<p>after meals with warm water or brushing the teeth 30 min after an analgesic has been administered.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Other interventions are likely to be at the discretion of the dentist.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Patient education:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Discuss with parents the aetiology of the lesion(s), home management, the expected course and unexpected events that should prompt a re-visit or follow-up phone call. It is very important that the parent understands when to seek care if the problem is not resolving as expected.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="follow-up">FOLLOW-UP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#follow-up" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>If the lesion resolves as expected, then no further follow-up is required. However, if anxiety levels are running high, telephone follow-up can be effective in helping the family manage.</li>
<li>Further follow-up is aetiology-specific, and is often at the discretion of the dentist or other health care professional.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="medical-consult-specialist-referral">MEDICAL CONSULT/ SPECIALIST REFERRAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-consult-specialist-referral" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Any child in whom the diagnosis is not clear.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any child with a gravely ill or toxic appearance.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any child with a suspected oral infection that will require specialist intervention (e.g. parulis).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any child in whom the oral lesion could present a safety hazard (e.g. loose natal teeth).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any child who is not able to maintain adequate food or fluid intake due to presence of the oral lesion(s).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any child with a long-standing, unresolved lesion (e.g. large mucocele, large fibroma, papilloma, congenital epulis).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="paediatric-pearls">PAEDIATRIC PEARLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paediatric-pearls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Establish a good relationship with your local dentist; he can be an invaluable resource with regard to the identification and management of an oral lesion.</li>
<li>Eruption cysts are much more common with the eruption of canine teeth and molars (30% of children will experience one) in contrast to a cyst associated with the eruption of an incisor (11%).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bibliography">BIBLIOGRAPHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bibliography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
