<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="11-4-stridor-and-croup-laryngotracheobronchitis">11.4 STRIDOR AND CROUP (LARYNGOTRACHEOBRONCHITIS)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#11-4-stridor-and-croup-laryngotracheobronchitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Joan Marshall</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Stridor is a harsh, vibratory sound of variable pitch caused by partial obstruction of the upper airway. Although most stridor is caused by benign clinical conditions, it is a frightening respiratory problem for parents and children. Occasionally, it may be a sign of a serious or even life-threatening disorder and as such, requires careful evaluation.</li>
<li>Acute inspiratory stridor is usually associated with obstruction of the laryngeal area and is most commonly observed in children with croup. Croup comes under the umbrella term 'croup syndrome', a non-specific term that refers to any condition producing inspiratory stridor and includes laryngotracheobronchitis (LTB), spasmodic croup, bacterial tracheitis and epiglottitis. Note that the terms 'laryngotracheobronchitis' and 'croup' are often used synonymously.</li>
<li>Viral croup (acute laryngotracheobronchitis or LTB) is an acute illness that commonly occurs in children between 6 months and 3 years of age (peak incidence is during the second year of life with boys affected more commonly than girls). Most croup episodes are caused by parainfluenza viruses (types 1, 2 and 3), although numerous other pathogens can also be involved (RSV, adenovirus, enterovirus and rhinovirus).</li>
<li>Children with viral croup present with acute inspiratory stridor, barking seal-like cough and hoarse voice. It is usually preceded by a cold for a few days, poor appetite, sore throat and low-grade fever; it differs from other types of croup as it is of gradual onset (12-48 hours). The child's symptoms may become more evident at night time and the stridor can become more severe when the child is upset and/or crying.</li>
<li>Spasmodic croup (spasmodic laryngitis) is usually caused by allergic agents, gastroesophageal reflux (GOR) or psychological factors. The condition (which can be atopic) occurs in children aged between 1 and 3 years and is characterised by an abrupt night-time onset (awakening the child from sleep) of marked inspiratory stridor. It usually settles without any intervention after a few hours. Spasmodic croup may also be considered a variant of viral croup, especially when it recurs over several nights and is accompanied by a mild URTI. A small percentage of children with spasmodic croup may also have asthma.</li>
<li>Chronic inspiratory stridor is most commonly caused by laryngomalacia. This condition results from a flaccid epiglottis combined with partial laryngeal collapse on inspiration; it is usually seen in infancy.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology">PATHOPHYSIOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Acute infection (usually through respiratory droplet spread) provokes an inflammatory response that results in (1) mucosal oedema; (2) inflammation of the subglottic area; and (3) increased mucus production that can affect the entire respiratory tract.</li>
<li>The localised inflammation of the subglottic region produces the barking cough and inspiratory stridor, but it is subglottic oedema (significantly narrowing the area) which can result in respiratory compromise. During inspiration, the walls of the subglottic space are drawn together. This can aggravate the localised inflammation and result in further oedema, more narrowing and significant respiratory distress.</li>
<li>Because a child's airway is narrow, only a small amount of oedema is required to reduce the diameter and cause increased airflow resistance. It is therefore, extremely important that a child with croup is kept calm and quiet. A distressed and upset child will have more turbulent airflow, which</li>
</ul>
<p>11 Respiratory and cardiovascular problems</p>
<p>compounds the problems of increased resistance and respiratory distress.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="history">HISTORY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Age, frequency and duration of symptoms.</li>
<li>Activity and nature of symptoms at onset (playing, sleeping, gradual or abrupt).</li>
<li>Quality of cry, cough and voice.</li>
<li>Progression of symptoms since onset, home treatment and factors that have relieved or aggravated.</li>
<li>Other associated symptoms (URTI, fever, vomiting, diarrhoea, abdominal pain, hoarse voice, rhinorrhoea, etc.).</li>
<li>Difficulty with breathing, swallowing and/or intake of oral fluids.</li>
<li>Previous history and treatment of croup.</li>
<li>History of stridor at birth, airway malformation, intubations and cardiac or respiratory problems.</li>
<li>History of allergies and/or atopy and immunisation status.</li>
<li>Possibility of foreign body or chemical aspiration.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physical-examination">PHYSICAL EXAMINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Astute observation is key and a ‘hands off approach’ should be adopted. Keep the child as calm as possible: it is important to leave the child with carer in an upright position.</li>
<li>Focus observations on the degree of respiratory compromise: rate, grunting, recessions, colour, work associated with breathing, ability to take oral fluids, degree of stridor and positioning (leaning forward, drooling and ill-appearance suggest epiglottitis). Note signs of engagability with carer, tiredness, increased agitation, drowsiness, lethargy and altered mental status. A croup scoring system (Table 11.6) can be helpful in assessing the severity of symptoms. While there is subjectivity associated with the scoring, it can be a useful adjuvant to monitor a child over time. A score of 3 or more is likely to require more aggressive management.</li>
<li>Head and ENT: examination of the oropharynx remains controversial as the risk of increased distress to the child must be balanced with the</li>
</ul>
<p>information likely to be gained from direct visualisation. Likewise, inspection of the tympanic membranes needs to be considered with regard to the degree of distress this will cause the child. Neck masses or bruising suggest stridor that is related to bacterial infection or trauma.</p>
<ul>
<li>Cardiopulmonary: air entry is assessed as well as presence of cyanosis, wheezes/crackles, quality of voice and air entry into lungs. Note whether stethoscope is required to hear stridor and whether there is stridor at rest.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="differential-diagnoses">DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differential-diagnoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Diagnosis of croup is typically apparent from the history and physical examination; however, consider additional diagnoses as presented in Table 11.7.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Additional diagnostics: laboratory tests/procedures are not usually required for the diagnosis. However, the following procedures</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>Table 11.6 Croup Scoring System^{a}</th><th></th><th></th><th></th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Observation</td><td>Score</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Level of consciousness</td><td>0</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>normal (alert, interactive)</td><td>1–4</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>minimal to moderate alteration</td><td>5</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>altered mental status (lethargic, disorientated)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Air entry</td><td>0</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>normal</td><td>1</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>slightly decreased</td><td>2</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>very decreased</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Inspiratory stridor</td><td>0</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>none</td><td>1</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>at rest (with stethoscope)</td><td>2</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>at rest (without stethoscope)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Retractions</td><td>0</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>none</td><td>1</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>slight</td><td>2</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>moderate</td><td>3</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>marked</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Colour</td><td>0</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>without cyanosis</td><td>4</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>cyanotic when agitated</td><td>5</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>cyanotic at rest</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>aAdapted from Super (1989) and Westley (1978).</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Table 11.7 Differential Diagnosis of Croup</th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Potential aetiology</td><td>Characteristics</td></tr><tr><td>Congenital:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Tracheomalacia</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Laryngomalacia</td><td>• Presents in first month of life, child is well, stridor increases with excitement</td></tr><tr><td>Infectious:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Epiglottis</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Retropharyngeal or peritonsillar abscess</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Diphtheritic croup</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Bacterial tracheitis</td><td>• Stridor with toxic appearance, forward leaning, drooling (no Hib immunisation)</td></tr><tr><td>• Muffled voice, fever, ill appearance, stiff neck dysphagia</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Missing/incomplete diphtheria vaccinations</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Ill/toxic appearance with fever and stridor that is rapidly progressing in severity; incomplete immunisations (Hib)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Toxins:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Foreign body aspiration</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Caustic ingestion (smoke or heat irritation)</td><td>• Playing and well before sudden onset of stridor in a healthy child, may be accompanied by coughing/choking and history of play with small objects</td></tr><tr><td>• History of exposure to heat, smoke or chemicals</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Allergic/inflammatory:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Hypersensitivity or anaphylaxis</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Asthma</td><td>• Documented allergy, history of insect sting, new medication or food</td></tr><tr><td>• History of labile and severe asthma</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>11.4 Stridor and croup (larygotracheobronchitis)</p>
<p>may be of use in clinical decision making:</p>
<ul>
<li>Pulse oximetry should be documented at least once; note that it is not diagnostic for respiratory failure.</li>
<li>FBC, CRP and blood cultures may be of help if bacterial infection is suspected. Note however, that venepuncture is likely to increase anxiety with a resultant increase in respiratory distress. Invasive diagnostics are not routinely recommended and, if required, should be carried out in a controlled environment when the child's airway is deemed secure.</li>
<li>Neck/chest X-ray usually unnecessary; an anterior and posterior view may show subglottic narrowing and a lateral view may rule out epiglottitis, retropharyngeal abscess and foreign body.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pharmacotherapeutics">Pharmacotherapeutics:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pharmacotherapeutics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Paracetamol: (10–15 mg/kg every 4 hours as required) to reduce pyrexia.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Steroids: the efficacy of systemic steroids in decreasing mucosal oedema and subglottic narrowing is well established. Choice of preparation (and administration route) are influenced by the setting and clinical judgement. Improvement is typically seen within 1 hour of steroid administration and, therefore, dexamethasone is a first-line treatment for moderate-to-severe croup. Note that oral dexamethasone is as effective as nebulised budesonide and the oral solution is readily available. In addition, both nebulisation and intramuscular (IM) injection can increase distress to the child and their use should be considered carefully: (1) dexamethasone, orally (150 μg/kg) or IM injection (0.6 mg/kg; max = 10 mg); (2) nebulised budesonide (2 mg) in a single dose.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Nebulised epinephrine/adrenaline (1/1000) 5 ml with high-dose oxygen can be used with moderate-to-severe cases to reduce inflammation/oedema.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Antibiotics: reserved for bacterial infections and are of no benefit in the treatment of viral croup.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Behavioural intervention: the mainstay of treatment for mild croup is paracetamol, observation and adequate fluid intake. In some areas, humidity and/or use of mist tent therapy is still advised for the treatment for croup though recent research challenges the efficacy of this treatment. Caution should be exercised in using steam-generated humidity, as the risk of scalding the airway is more dangerous than the croup itself. In some instances, humidity can also induce bronchospasm.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Patient education:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Clear and explicit discharge instructions (with contact phone number) should be given to the carer: this will include symptoms of worsening illness and/or increasing respiratory distress (breathing becomes more difficult, poor colour/pallor/cyanosis, drooling/difficulty swallowing, refusing liquids, increased heart rate and significant fever).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Reinforce with parents the importance of seeking care if any of those symptoms develop or if the child becomes restless, irritable, exhausted or confused. Likewise, parents should call if they are worried/concerned about their child's condition or home management.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Review home management of mild croup (fluids, fever control, comfort measures, observation) and let parents know that symptoms should gradually resolve over 3–4 days (although it is not uncommon for the stridor to last up to 1 week and the cough for longer).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Reassure parents that there will be no long-term damage to the respiratory system.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="follow-up">FOLLOW-UP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#follow-up" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Generally not indicated for uncomplicated viral croup, as the condition is self-limiting. Follow-up phone contact may be beneficial for anxious parents.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="medical-consult-specialist-referral">MEDICAL CONSULT/ SPECIALIST REFERRAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-consult-specialist-referral" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Any child with a toxic appearance or one who is cyanosed, dehydrated or exhausted.</li>
<li>Any child in whom epiglottitis is suspected.</li>
<li>Any child with tracheal, sternal or subcostal recessions at rest, other signs of respiratory compromise/distress (respiratory rate &gt;50–60) and/or deteriorating condition.</li>
<li>Any child under 1 year of age and/or any child in whom there is no improvement after initial treatment.</li>
<li>Any child whose diagnosis is uncertain or who has a history of chronic, persistent or recurrent stridor which is likely to require further investigation/treatment.</li>
<li>Any child in whom there is a suspicion of foreign body aspiration.</li>
<li>Any child where there are family/social reasons to suggest the child cannot be cared for at home (including extreme carer anxiety).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="paediatric-pearls">PAEDIATRIC PEARLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paediatric-pearls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Clinical discretion must be used with regard to examination of the throat in a child with stridor. The likelihood of missed pathology needs to be balanced against the possibility of increased upset caused by examination of the oropharnyx.</li>
<li>Reduce anxiety levels by having a calm, confident and ‘hands off’ approach.</li>
<li>Regular reassessment is required as a child can deteriorate quickly, developing a partial/complete airway obstruction.</li>
<li>In young infants with recurrent croup, the following should be considered: congenital abnormalities, underlying anatomical problems and GOR.</li>
<li>Bacterial infection of the lower respiratory system is a complication of croup. It can cause progressive airway obstruction that leads to a life-threatening event. Urgent intervention with hospital admission is required in these cases.</li>
</ul>
<p>11 Respiratory and cardiovascular problems</p>
<ul>
<li>Always consider the possibility of foreign body aspiration or ingestion as a potential aetiology (especially in toddlers).</li>
<li>Beware the toxic/ill appearing child: always consider epiglottitis. It is a medical emergency and will require an ENT/anaesthesia input.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bibliography">BIBLIOGRAPHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bibliography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="11-5-syncope">11.5 SYNCOPE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#11-5-syncope" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Ritamarie John</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Syncope is described as a sudden, transient, reversible loss of consciousness and muscle tone.</li>
<li>Syncope is not a rare event in paediatrics; it has been estimated that 15% of children will have a syncopal episode at some point during childhood.</li>
<li>Most syncope does not reflect cardiac disease but it is important to differentiate worrisome from benign syncope.</li>
<li>Potential aetiologies for syncope include cardiac, neurocardiac, seizure migraine, breath-holding spells, hypoglycaemia, hysteria, orthostatic and situational. As there is a potential for life-threatening causes of syncope, a careful history and physical examination is key.</li>
<li>Syncope causes significant anxiety for families, playmates and school personnel. In order to alleviate their fears, it is vital that the family’s concerns are taken seriously. Likewise, it is imperative not to falsely reassure patients and families.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology">PATHOPHYSIOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The specific pathophysiology of syncope is dependent on the aetiology of the episode.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The most common mechanism of syncope is vasovagal (i.e. neurocardiac syncope). It is caused by autonomic dysfunction, in which a variety of external stimuli (pain, emotional upset, long periods standing, etc.) trigger increased vagal tone that subsequently causes a decrease in heart rate and peripheral vasodilation. This primary vasodepressor response results in hypotension, decreased cerebral perfusion pressure and a syncopal episode.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The child with breath-holding spells may involuntarily activate the Valsalva reflex, thereby increasing intrathoracic pressure, decreasing venous return and subsequently decreasing cardiac output. These processes lead to cerebral ischaemia, unconsciousness and decreased muscle tone (i.e. syncope). With the onset of cyanosis, generalised clonic jerks and bradycardia can occur.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hyperventilation causes syncope by producing cerebral vasoconstriction. If the patient simultaneously does a Valsalva manoeuvre the cerebral hypoperfusion is accentuated.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cough syncope occurs because of decreased venous return to the right heart, reduced left ventricular filling and decreased cardiac output, resulting in hypoperfusion to the brain.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Functional problems associated with the heart (e.g. outflow obstruction, myocardial dysfunction or arrhythmias) may lead to syncope as a result of decreased cerebral perfusion and/or cardiac ischaemia. Cardiac syncope is potentially fatal and requires careful evaluation and treatment.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="history">HISTORY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Duration of the episode including what happened during the episode with regard to the child’s colour, unusual eye and limb movements, loss of continence and length of time child was unresponsive.</li>
<li>It is crucial to obtain information (from the child and observers) about what happened before the event (e.g. activity, environment, presence of seizure-like activity, and whether the child ‘knew’ or felt that she was going to pass out).</li>
</ul>
<p>11.5 Syncope</p>
<ul>
<li>Position prior to the episode, as standing-associated syncope suggest a vasovagal mechanism.</li>
<li>24-hour dietary recall and the association of the syncope to meals.</li>
<li>Presence of associated symptoms: palpitations, chest pain, headache, sweating, nausea and/or auditory or visual auras.</li>
<li>Medication history, including over-the-counter (OTC) medicines, herbal remedies and weight reduction medications, all of which can induce arrhythmias. Note that families may not consider herbal or homeopathic medications as part of the history, so use of these products needs to be explored.</li>
<li>History of exposures (e.g. alcohol, carbon monoxide, drug use).</li>
<li>Past medical history, including previous cardiac surgery and history of Kawasaki disease.</li>
<li>Family history of syncope, sudden or early death, epilepsy, neurological disease, deafness (long QT syndrome may have familial deafness), endocrine disorders, long QT syndrome, cardiomyopathies, arrhythmias or myocardial infarction at a young age.</li>
<li>A social history should include careful enquiry regarding stressors, sexual abuse or any secondary gain that might result from a syncopal episode.</li>
<li>Note that a worrisome history in a child presenting with syncope includes an age &lt; 6 years, recumbent position, prolonged loss of consciousness of 5 min or longer, presence of cardiac disease or heart murmur, and syncope occurring with exercise.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physical-examination">PHYSICAL EXAMINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>A complete physical examination with special attention to the cardiovascular and neurological systems.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Check blood pressure sitting, standing and supine. An orthostatic change in heart rate or blood pressure should be noted (i.e. a drop of 20 mmHg when moving from a supine to a standing position). Compare blood pressure readings in each arm.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Listen for murmurs in at least two positions (e.g. sitting and supine) and check peripheral and central pulses.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If hyperventilation is being considered, the child should be hyperventilated to see if syncope occurs.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Careful and thorough neurological examination.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="differential-diagnoses">DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differential-diagnoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Syncope can be divided into cardiac, non-cardiac and neurocardiac aetiologies (Table 11.8).</li>
<li>It is imperative that cardiac causes of syncope are differentiated from benign causes of syncope (e.g. breath-holding spells, vasovagal, hyperventilation and cough-induced syncope). A careful history and physical assessment is the basis upon which further clinical or laboratory testing is based.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The management of syncope is largely dependent upon the aetiology of the episodes.</p>
<ul>
<li>Additional diagnostics: Many children will have a clear history of vasovagal syncope and additional diagnostics are not necessary. Note that electrocardiography (ECG) is suggested for all cases of unexplained syncope, as ruling out life-threatening cardiac disease is a priority. In addition, consider a chest X-ray and FBC as initial tests (Table 11.8) with more extensive investigation coordinated by specialist care for children with recurrent or unexplained episodes.</li>
<li>Pharmacotherapeutics: aetiology-specific. Note that among children with cough syncope and asthma, better control of their asthma will reduce the syncope. Scopolamine or other anticholinergics (e.g. atropine) can be used in frequent and severe cyanotic breath-holding spells as they will increase the heart rate by blocking the vagus nerve. Pseudoephedrine prevents venous pooling and blocks systemic hypotension when used as an adjunctive medication for vasovagal syncope. If iron-deficiency anaemia is present with breath-holding-induced syncope, correct anaemia as it has been reported to worsen the frequency and severity of the breath-holding spells.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="behavioural-interventions">Behavioural interventions:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#behavioural-interventions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>For breath-holding spells, it is better to keep the child horizontal and wait (if loss of consciousness &gt;2 min, activate emergency services).</li>
<li>Prevention of syncope by avoiding situations that have resulted in syncope (e.g. long periods standing in a warm room, maintaining adequate hydration and nutrition, etc.).</li>
<li>In hyperventilation syncope, reassurance and rebreathing into a bag can prevent the episodes.</li>
<li>Children with recurrent syncope should take precautions similar to those used among children of a similar age with epilepsy. More specifically, close monitoring when participating in water-related activities and restrictions on climbing. Note, however, that most children with recurrent syncope do not experience spells during vigorous activity.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="patient-education">Patient education:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#patient-education" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Parents (and children) will require significant reassurance, support and education regarding the syncopal episodes. Review behavioural interventions (above).</li>
<li>As most cases of syncope are vasovagal, breath-holding or hyperventilation-related, families will need to understand why these episodes happen and what can be done to prevent them. Note that most children outgrow their breath-holding episodes; however, they may be predisposed to vasovagal syncope as adults.</li>
<li>Parents should keep a record of the syncopal episodes if the child experiences more than two episodes within 6 months.</li>
<li>Reassure parents that pallid breath-holding spells do not result in brain damage.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="follow-up">FOLLOW-UP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#follow-up" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Families need to return if the syncope reoccurs. Of particular concern is any syncope associated with exercise.</li>
</ul>
<p>11 Respiratory and cardiovascular problems</p>

<p>11.6 Chest pain</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="medical-consult-specialist-referral">MEDICAL CONSULT/SPECIALIST REFERRAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-consult-specialist-referral" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Any child in whom the aetiology of the syncope is not readily apparent from the history or physical examination (e.g. those without classic vasovagal, breath-holding or hyperventilation-related syncope).</li>
<li>Any child with recurring syncope or episodes associated with a recumbent position, prolonged loss of consciousness, presence of cardiac disease (or strong familial history of cardiac disease), exercise, cardiac symptoms or seizures.</li>
<li>Any child less than 6 years of age with syncope that is not related to breath-holding spells.</li>
<li>Any child in whom there is the possibility of a behavioural component to the episodes.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="paediatric-pearls">PAEDIATRIC PEARLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paediatric-pearls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Vasovagal syncopal events are more common in pre-adolescents and adolescents and are induced while standing up in warm places.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Children under 6 years of age with syncope not associated with breath-holding spells are more worrisome.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>There are rare causes of syncope such as familial dysautonomia, which is found in people who are of Ashkenazi Jewish descent. This will present early in childhood.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cough-induced syncope may be the sign that asthma is not in good control.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Recurrent syncope related to prolonged QT interval may be missed on routine ECG, as it may only occur with exertion.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Carbon monoxide may cause syncopal spells: enquire about exposures.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Temporal lobe epilepsy may mimic a syncopal episode and/or syncope may trigger a convulsion in an epileptic child.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cardiac-related syncope is associated with little or no prodrome and occurs even when the child is lying down. There may be a prolonged loss of consciousness, history of palpitations, family history of sudden death and the episode may be associated with exercise.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Consider pregnancy in a sexually active adolescent female with a vasovagal syncopal episode.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bibliography">BIBLIOGRAPHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bibliography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Ackerman M. The long QT syndrome. Pediatr Rev 1998; 9(7):3232-3238.
Benditt D, Lurie K, Fabian W. Clinical approach to diagnosis of syncope: an overview. Cardiol Clin 1997; 15: 165-176.
Braden D, Gaymes C. The diagnosis and management of syncope in children and adolescents. Pediatr Ann 1997; 26(7):422-426.

Lewis D, Dhala A. Syncope in the pediatric patient: the cardiologist's perspective. Pediatr Clin N Am 1999; 46:205-219.
Narchi H. The child who passes out. Pediatr Rev 2000; 21:384-388.

Willis J. Syncope. Pediatr Rev 2000; 21:201-204.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="11-6-chest-pain">11.6 CHEST PAIN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#11-6-chest-pain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Ritamarie John</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Chest pain is a common complaint in children and adolescents. It is found in children of all ages, with an average age at presentation of 12 years.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The different aetiologies of chest pain in children have a developmental component. Young children are more likely to have a respiratory, gastrointestinal (GI) or cardiac source for their chest pain and they are more likely to have an organic cause for the pain. Older children and adolescents may still have a cardiac, GI or respiratory aetiology, but psychogenic, musculoskeletal or idiopathic causes increase in this age group. There is no racial or sexual predilection.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The main objective in the evaluation of chest pain in children is to differentiate children that will require further work-up and referral from those in whom, analgesics, reassurance and follow-up are the mainstays of management.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Remember that chest pain is significant for families as it tends to be associated with cardiac disease and death; these fears can add to the anxiety levels of both parents and children.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pathophysiology">PATHOPHYSIOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Chest pain can arise from several sources in children. The pain may come from the structures within the thorax or it can be referred from visceral organs.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cardiac disease will cause ischaemic chest pain, worsening with exercise and increased workload on the heart. This pain is from thoracic sympathetic nerves as well as the cardiac nerves. Pain from the pericardium can arise from the phrenic or the laryngeal-oesophageal plexus, causing substernal pressure or shoulder, neck or arm pain. Mitral valve prolapse can cause chest pain due to papillary muscle or endocardial ischaemia. Aortic pain will arise in the adventitia of the blood vessel and is produced from stimulation of the sympathetic chain.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pleural pain comes from irritation of the parietal pleura since the visceral pleura is insensitive to pain with signals transmitted via intercostal nerves.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>11 Respiratory and cardiovascular problems</p>
<ul>
<li>Central diaphragmatic pain comes from the phrenic nerve and, therefore, the child may present with shoulder pain on the affected side.</li>
<li>Musculoskeletal causes of chest pain result from stimulation of the sensory nerves in the affected intercostal muscle or dermatome.</li>
<li>Oesophageal pain is produced by stimulation of the nerves in the spinal segments and may present with anterior superior chest pain and/or pain around the neck.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="history">HISTORY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>A careful history is imperative; allow the child and family to express their concerns. Explore the child's fears about the pain. Adolescents will worry that their heart is causing the chest pain.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Onset, severity and frequency of the pain, including the length of time before the family sought care.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Type of pain (burning, sharp, stabbing, etc.) and whether it interferes with everyday activities.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Precipitating, aggravating and relieving factors.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The association of pain to exercise and meals.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Recent trauma or muscle overuse.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Intake of spicy foods and medications (especially tetracycline or other 'tablets').</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Recent use of cocaine (and if positive, frequency and extent of use).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Use of oral contraceptives and history of recent leg trauma (i.e. to rule out possibility of embolism).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Recent or significant stress.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Associated symptoms: fever, weight loss, syncope, palpitations, joint pain, rashes, attention-seeking behaviour.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Past medical history, including asthma, Kawasaki disease, diabetes and sickle cell disease.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Family history of cardiac problems (including sudden or early death, syncope or heart disease), asthma, sickle cell disease, cystic fibrosis and smoking.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="physical-examination">PHYSICAL EXAMINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>A thorough and complete physical examination is required, as the potential aetiologies of chest pain are numerous (Table 11.9). Pay particular attention to the cardiac, pulmonary and abdominal examinations.</li>
<li>Worrying physical examination findings include severe distress, chronically or acutely ill appearance, cardiac involvement (e.g. murmurs, arrhythmias, tachycardia), pulmonary findings (e.g. rub, rales, wheezing), skin rashes/bruising, abdominal pathology, concomitant arthritis and acute anxiety.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="differential-diagnoses">DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differential-diagnoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The most common causes of chest pain in children and adolescents include musculoskeletal, trauma, respiratory conditions, GI problems, cardiac pathology and various miscellaneous causes (breast mass, cocaine abuse, sickle cell crisis, thoracic tumour). The history and physical examination findings are the basis upon which further testing is considered and the differential list is narrowed (Table 11.9).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="management">MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Additional diagnostics: aetiology-specific (see Table 11.9); however, if the history of physical examination suggests cardiac pathology consider electrocardiogram (ECG), chest X-ray, 24-hour cardiac monitoring and exercise stress testing. Likewise, if a pulmonary aetiology is suggested, consider a chest X-ray and pulmonary function tests.</li>
<li>Pharmacotherapeutics: aetiology-specific; for many cases of benign chest pain, OTC analgesia (paracetamol, ibuprofen or antacids) are sufficient. Note, however, that serious aetiologies are not well correlated with frequency and severity of pain.</li>
<li>Behavioural interventions: aetiology-specific; however, for the majority of benign chest pain, reassurance, relaxation (including stress management) and analgesia will suffice. A symptom diary that includes reference to activity or stress levels in addition to the pain often helps the child and family see the associations and triggers for the pain.</li>
</ul>
<p>Table 11.9 Differential Diagnoses of Chest Pain in Children</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>History</th><th>Physical examination findings</th><th>Additional diagnostics, differential diagnoses and comments</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Musculoskeletal</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Pain of acute onset</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• History of blunt trauma</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Pain relieved by analgesics</td><td>• Pain in chest wall with area of localised tenderness possible</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• May have bruising</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Breath sounds clear</td><td>• Consider soft tissue injury, rib fracture, muscle haematoma with possibility of cardiac or great vessel contusion if significant blunt trauma</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Consider rib X-ray</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Consider mechanism of injury, as rib fractures can be related to child protection issues</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• History and physical examination findings should match</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• History of muscle strain, vigorous exercise or activity and/or lifting of heavy weights/objects</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Pain relieved by analgesics</td><td>• Generalised tenderness over chest wall</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Pain reproducible with same activity</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Can have patient put hands together and push/pull apart (or push against examiner's hands) in order to reproduce pain</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Breath sounds clear</td><td>• Consider chest wall strain</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• No other diagnostics indicated</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>(continued)</p>
<p>11.6 Chest pain</p>
<p>COMMON PAEDIATRIC PROBLEMS</p>

examination: tachycardia, ectopic beats and/or gallop rhythm</td><td>• Consider ECG, chest X-ray, 24-hour cardiac monitoring</td></tr><tr><td>• Pain on exertion</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• murmur</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Pulmonary</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Complaints of cough, fever, ill-appearance</td><td>• Adventitious sounds</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Increased intake</td><td>• Anxiety</td><td>• Obtain drug screen</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>• Cocaine intoxication may present with pneumothorax, hypertension and arrhythmias</td><td>• Will require intervention around drug use/abuse</td></tr><tr><td>• Complaints of breast enlargement, breast tenderness or asymmetry</td><td>• Normal examination</td><td>• Consider physiological breast changes of puberty and/or pregnancy</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>11 Respiratory and cardiovascular problems</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Patient education:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Reassure children and families (after acknowledging and addressing their fears) that most chest pain is benign and self-limiting. Life-threatening causes of chest pain are very rare. Stress, asthma, GOR and musculoskeletal aetiologies are, by far, the most common causes of chest pain in children.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Review, with the family, signs and symptoms of more serious problems and when to seek care.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any child who is experiencing acute distress.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any child with an ill or anxious appearance, history of significant trauma or family history of sudden death.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any child experiencing pain with exercise, syncope, palpitations, and/or dizziness.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any child with serious emotional upset.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any child with a suspected foreign body and/or caustic ingestion.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="follow-up">FOLLOW-UP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#follow-up" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Follow-up is an essential component in the management of chest pain and should be discussed with the family: this may include further diagnostics, referral or watching/waiting.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="medical-consult-specialist-referral">MEDICAL CONSULT/ SPECIALIST REFERRAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-consult-specialist-referral" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Any child that is in severe distress and has vital sign changes or positive findings on physical examination and/or diagnostic testing.</li>
<li>Any child in whom a cardiac, pulmonary or other significant aetiology is suspected.</li>
<li>Any child requiring intervention for drug or cocaine abuse.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="paediatric-pearls">PAEDIATRIC PEARLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paediatric-pearls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>A good history and thorough physical examination is the key to problem identification; avoid expensive and invasive diagnostics with chronic pain, benign history and normal examination.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Be sure to review normal findings as part of the examination in order to reassure the child and family.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Chest pain during exercise is a red flag for organic disease.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fever with chest pain requires consideration of organic aetiologies such as pericarditis, myocarditis or pneumonia.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Analgesics (e.g. paracetamol or ibuprofen), rest and relaxation may be all that is needed for musculoskeletal chest pain.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A trial of antacids may be both therapeutic and diagnostic in cases of reflux and oesophagitis.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For the anxious child, teaching relaxation techniques or yoga classes may alleviate the chest pain.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Follow-up is the key if the first visit does not reveal anything specific after a careful history and physical examination. Use of a symptom diary can be a useful adjuvant and may reveal a potential cause.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bibliography">BIBLIOGRAPHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bibliography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<p>CHAPTER 12</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="gastrointestinal-and-endocrine-problems">Gastrointestinal and Endocrine Problems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gastrointestinal-and-endocrine-problems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-1-acute-abdominal-pain">12.1 ACUTE ABDOMINAL PAIN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-1-acute-abdominal-pain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Katie Barnes</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The overall incidence of acute abdominal pain (AAP) is unknown, as the vast majority of episodes are managed successfully at home. It has been estimated that 1–2% of children presenting to emergency settings with AAP will have serious disease (acute appendicitis being the most common surgical diagnosis). The patient’s age has important implications for the expression of pain (see Sec. 13.3) as well as for the potential aetiology of the pain (Table 12.1).</li>
<li>The primary objective in the evaluation of AAP is the accurate and timely differentiation of those conditions which are benign, self-limiting and within the nurse practitioner’s (NP’s) scope of practice from those that represent more significant pathology and therefore, require medical consultation and referral.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology">PATHOPHYSIOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>AAP results from the stimulation of nerve fibres from the parietal peritoneum (e.g. peritoneal lining and mucosa) and/or the abdominal viscera (e.g. deep muscular wall and the associated structures of the visceral cavity). Parietal pain is characteristically sharp, localised and stimulated by inflammation, whereas visceral pain is usually dull, poorly localised and triggered by tension and stretching. However, there is common enervation of many abdominal organs and referred pain can result when there is mixing of signals or when there is an overflow of signals from the visceral to the parietal pathways.</li>
<li>For the most part, epigastric pain usually results from pathology in the foregut (stomach, pancreas, liver and upper small bowel) whereas periumbilical pain is generated from the midgut (distal small bowel, caecum, appendix and ascending colon). Suprapubic pain is typically related to the hindgut (distal intestine, urinary tract, pelvic organs).</li>
<li>It is important to remember that progressive pathology can change the symptomatology: visceral stretch receptors stimulated in early appendicitis would likely cause diffuse non-specific epigastric pain that later becomes localised to the right lower quadrant and sharper as the inflammation of the appendix increased (i.e. stimulation of the parietal fibres).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="history">HISTORY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Onset, frequency, distribution and characteristics of the pain (if child able to describe). Include information on aggravating/relieving factors and whether the pain has awoken the child from sleep.</li>
<li>Where the pain started, whether it is shifting/changing, whether it is worsened by movement and whether other family members are affected.</li>
<li>Associated nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea/bloody stool, fever or other symptoms (e.g. rashes, dysuria, constipation, weight loss, anorexia, sore throat and/or joint pain).</li>
<li>Previous history of AAP, relationship of pain to meals (or specific foods) and what has been done to relieve pain.</li>
<li>Age-related history (Table 12.1).</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>Table 12.1 Age-related AAP History</th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Age group</td><td>Query</td></tr><tr><td>Infants</td><td>• Unusual facial expression, cry, and activity/sleep pattern disruption (thrashing, restless, motionless)</td></tr><tr><td>Toddlers/pre-school</td><td>• Aggressive behaviour and/or disturbed sleep patterns</td></tr><tr><td>School-age</td><td>• Child’s description and ‘one-finger’ localisation (e.g. asking the child to point to the pain ‘using only 1 finger’)</td></tr><tr><td>• Bullying or trauma at school</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Adolescents</td><td>• Sexual and menstrual history (consider obtaining history without parent)</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Gastrointestinal and endocrine problems</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="physical-examination">PHYSICAL EXAMINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>It is vital that the initial contact with the child is not painful. Likewise, careful observation of the child during the physical examination is imperative; useful manoeuvres to assess the degree of peritoneal inflammation and visceral pain include asking the child to 'hop on each leg' or 'climb' onto the examination table (or carer's lap). In addition, it is useful to establish the child's baseline level of response by touching an arm or leg and comparing complaints of 'how much that hurts' with the discomfort associated with the abdominal examination.</li>
<li>Skin: examine for rashes, petechiae and/or purpura.</li>
<li>Head, ear, nose and throat (ENT) and lymph examination: careful examination as pharyngitis in school-aged children often presents as AAP.</li>
<li>Cardiopulmonary: note respiratory symptoms as pneumonia in young children can present as AAP.</li>
<li>Neurological and musculoskeletal: limit examination to assessment of pain on movement and overall level of alertness.</li>
<li>Abdomen: should be done last; include rectal examination as it is integral to evaluation of the suspected appendicitis. However, it should only be performed once, accompanied by careful explanation and consent from child and carer. Observe abdomen for distension and/or visible peristalsis. Palpate the abdomen carefully, starting with the least painful area and include a careful feel for masses (remove nappy). Rebound tenderness, psoas and obturator signs (as performed in adults) usually not helpful (even with older children/adolescents); much more helpful is an assessment of the child's ease of movement (hopping, walking, climbing).</li>
<li>Determination of abdominal tenderness can likewise be ascertained during auscultation for bowel sounds by pressing firmly with the stethoscope or through percussion of the lower chest and abdomen (beginning in an area that is unlikely to be tender). Include</li>
</ul>
<p>assessment of costovertebral angle (CVA) and suprapubic tenderness, liver, spleen and inguinal canal.</p>
<ul>
<li>If history suggests gynaecological aetiology, pelvic examination should be considered.</li>
<li>Repeat examinations (with careful documentation at regular intervals) are a mainstay of early assessment and management.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="differential-diagnoses">DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differential-diagnoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Numerous and often age-related (Table 12.2). Although the majority of aetiologies are benign, it is crucial that surgical emergencies are distinguished from medical conditions (Table 12.3).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="management">MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Additional diagnostics: usefulness limited to excluding the likelihood of other aetiologies (Table 12.3).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pharmacotherapeutics: use of medication is aetiology-specific; pain relief often deferred in early evaluation to prevent masking of pain levels and/or fever.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Behavioural intervention: aetiology-specific; often includes dietary changes, fluids and symptom management.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Patient education:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>strong NP/family communication and follow-up is vital; families must clearly understand the importance of returning/ringing if symptoms are worse or unresolved</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>discuss with them the potential aetiologies that are under consideration and be sure that they are clear on their role in home management</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>additional patient education is aetiology-specific.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="follow-up">FOLLOW-UP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#follow-up" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Return visit or phone call if pain has not settled (see Patient education).</li>
<li>No further follow-up required if symptomatology resolves with supportive care.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="medical-consult-specialist-referral">MEDICAL CONSULT/ SPECIALIST REFERRAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-consult-specialist-referral" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Any child in whom there is any suspected surgical, gynaecological or urogenital emergency.</li>
<li>Any child with a gravely ill appearance or one requiring a more extensive evaluation.</li>
<li>Any child in whom a diagnosis is unclear.</li>
<li>Any child who has not responded to initial management.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="paediatric-pearls">PAEDIATRIC PEARLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paediatric-pearls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Appendicitis can occur concomitantly with another illness: i.e. gastroenteritis, upper respiratory tract infection (URTI).</li>
<li>With recurrent acute abdominal pain that occurs repeatedly over a prolonged period, always consider the possibility of child protection issues.</li>
<li>History and physical examination findings are the basis for additional diagnostics, consultation and/or referral; do not delay referral if physical findings are suspicious. This is especially important if preliminary laboratory results are not conclusive. The early presentation of appendicitis in children often has unremarkable results—high normal white cell count (WCC),</li>
</ul>

<p>Common extra-abdominal causes of AAP: pneumonia, pharyngitis, URTI/otitis media.</p>
<p>Uncommon extra-abdominal causes: Henoch-Schonlein purpura, Hgb SS disease, child abuse/NAI, ectopic pregnancy, testicular torsion, duodenal ulcer and other intestinal obstructions.</p>
<p>Key: + = positive; - = negative; +/- = positive or negative; WCC = white cell count; ESR = erythrocyte sedimentation rate; FOB = faecal occult blood; AXR = abdominal X-ray; U/S = ultrasound; U/A = urinalysis or dipstick.</p>
<p>12.2 Childhood constipation and encopresis</p>
<p>urinalysis that may/may not be normal); the child who looks ill probably is.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>A single negative finding (e.g. soft, non-tender abdomen when child asleep) is worth many positive/equivocal findings.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is useful to establish the child’s baseline level of response (palpating an arm or leg) and compare it with the discomfort associated with the abdominal examination.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Illnesses with marked lymph involvement may inflame mesenteric nodes, resulting in acute non-specific abdominal pain (ANSAP).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Progressive nature to pain: think appendicitis.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Apley’s law: the further from the umbilicus, the more likely a discernible cause; therefore, periumbilical pain is less likely to be pathogenic.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Repeat examinations at regular intervals (with specific and clear documentation of findings) are a mainstay of early assessment and management.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Acute abdominal pain with purpura on ankles and buttocks, hypertension and abnormal urinalysis or dipstick: think Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Bloody stools are always of concern (HSP, dysentery, intussusception).</p>
</li>
</ul>
