<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="differential-diagnoses">DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differential-diagnoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Numerous: can be categorised by type of hyperbilirubinaemia (Table 12.11). In addition, there are some aetiologies of jaundice that are more common in certain ages (Table 12.12).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="management">MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Specific management of jaundice is aetiology-dependent. In addition, with the exception of initial evaluation (to rule out mild cases of physiological, breast-milk and infectious/viral-related jaundice) management is likely to be coordinated in specialist centres. Consequently, management principles outlined below are largely limited to diagnostics useful at presentation, management of physiological/breast-milk jaundice and the importance of early investigation of conjugated hyperbilirubinaemia in the newborn (Table 12.13).</p>
<ul>
<li>Additional diagnostics:</li>
<li>Largely determined by clinical setting, differential diagnoses, patient age, history and clinical presentation.</li>
</ul>
<p>12.4 Jaundice</p>
<p>2</p>
<p>Table 12.13 Conjugated and Unconjugated Hyperbilirubinaemia in Infancy Basic Management*</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Type</th><th>Comments</th><th>Management</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Unconjugated</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(physiological and</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>breast-milk jaundice)</td><td>• Physiological jaundice related to high red blood cell breakdown and liver immaturity (liver can't keep up with conjugation process)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Presents within the first few days of life and should be returned to normal in approximately 2 weeks</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Breast-milk jaundice probably overlaps with physiological and is multifactorial in its aetiology. Breast-milk jaundice continuing longer than 1–2 months should be investigated further</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Clinical findings in physiological and breast-milk jaundice: unconjugated component of total bilirubin elevated while conjugated level normal (&lt;20 μmol/l); normal haemoglobin, reticulocyte count and stool colour; no maternal blood group incompatibility or physical examination findings (jaundice excepted); urine negative for bilirubin</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Unconjugated hyperbilirubinaemia can indicate a haemolytic problem or physiological deficiency of glucuronyl transferase (e.g. Criglar–Nijjar syndrome)</td><td>• Phototherapy may be required in term infants with unconjugated bilirubin &gt;300 μmol/l</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Weight, gestational age, and postnatal age are considered (in addition to bilirubin levels) in decision to initiate phototherapy</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Exchange transfusion may be required to prevent kernicterus if unconjugated levels are extremely high</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• It is very important that the infant is well hydrated and feeding adequately; urine output should be &gt;2 ml/kg/h</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Conjugated</td><td>• Clinical findings include pale stools, dark urine, bilirubin (on dipstick) in fresh urine</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Serum levels of conjugated bilirubin ≥15% of total bilirubin should be considered abnormal</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Increased levels imply an impairment of bile excretion, which occurs in severe parenchymal disease and damage to portal tracts</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Requires urgent investigation and referral as early detection allows prompt treatment and management; both of which directly affect outcome</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Early diagnosis is vital to the outcome of biliary atresia as surgical repair prior to 8 weeks of age optimises the outcome</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• In addition to above, biliary atresia may present with failure to thrive (despite feeding well) and hepatomegaly with firm liver. Note that splenomegaly is a later sign that indicates significant liver damage (fibrosis or cirrhosis)</td><td>• Infants with conjugated hyperbilirubinaemia will require supplementation with fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E and K) and increased monitoring</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Prevention of failure to thrive through growth plotting (weekly weight, length and head circumference checks)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Specialist dietary consultation is important</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Breast-feeding is encouraged but caloric supplementation may be required</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Formula feeds should have increased medium-chain triglycerides: e.g. Pregestimil</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>*In jaundiced newborns, differential bilirubin levels at 14 days of age.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>An important first step is establishing whether jaundice is due to conjugated or unconjugated hyperbilirubinaemia. This is determined by measuring the total serum bilirubin level and, specifically, requesting a split bilirubin (i.e. conjugated and unconjugated levels). Direct bilirubin exceeding 15% of the total indicates conjugated hyperbilirubinaemia and should be urgently investigated.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Urine ‘dipstick’ for bilirubin should be performed in all patients presenting with jaundice. This is especially important in the evaluation of the newborn with marked jaundice (who should also receive a total serum bilirubin with split to rule out conjugated hyperbilirubinaemia). Note that urobilinogen is a normal finding in urine but bilirubin is not.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In addition, the following tests should be considered: liver function tests (Table 12.14), FBC with reticulocyte count and peripheral smear, blood cultures, urea/electrolytes, creatinine, urinalysis (with microscopy, reducing substances, amino acids and organic acids), viral infection screens (Epstein–Barr, cytomegalovirus and hepatitis A, B, C, D) and abdominal ultrasound (liver, gall bladder, spleen, kidney and biliary tract).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Further diagnostics for newborns: blood type and rhesus factor (infant and mother), Coombs’ test, sweat test (rule out cystic fibrosis), congenital infection screens (TORCH titres), metabolic screen (hypothyroidism, galactosaemia and hypopituitarism) and clotting screens, abdominal ultrasound. Note that the presence of a normal gall bladder nearly always excludes extrahepatic biliary atresia but it is important to rule out choledochal cyst. Radionuclear scanning and liver biopsy will be performed in specialist centres.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pharmacotherapeutics: aetiology-specific.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Behavioural interventions: aetiology-specific.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Patient education: largely aetiology-specific. Information on procedures, liver function and disease management are available from the specialist national referral centres (below). In addition, the Children’s Liver Disease Foundation has information leaflets written in conjunction with the centres (tel: 0121-212-3839) and a Family Support Officer:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Birmingham Children’s Hospital NHS Trust</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Kings College Hospital</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Leeds Royal Infirmary NHS Trust.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="follow-up">FOLLOW-UP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#follow-up" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Physiological jaundice must be followed closely for resolution. Jaundice continuing after 14 days needs to be investigated.</li>
</ul>
<p>12 Gastrointestinal and endocrine problems</p>
<p>Table 12.14 Liver Function Tests</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Test</th><th>Comments</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Total serum bilirubin with conjugated and unconjugated values</td><td>• Elevated levels cause jaundice</td></tr><tr><td>• Ratio of unconjugated to conjugate (split) is crucial in diagnostic decision making</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Aspartate transferase (AST)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Alanine transaminase (ALT)</td><td>• AST and ALT are enzymes found in hepatocytes; elevated levels indicate cellular inflammation and damage</td></tr><tr><td>• ALT is more specific to liver damage</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Alkaline phosphatase (ALP)</td><td>• ALP is associated with the cell membranes lining the biliary tree</td></tr><tr><td>• Increased levels occur in inflammation or necrosis of these cells</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Increased levels also occur when bile flow is impeded</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Caution with interpretation as levels are age-dependent; check age-specific reference ranges</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Serum albumin</td><td>• Made by the liver from other proteins</td></tr><tr><td>• Reflects the ability of the liver to synthesise these proteins</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Reduced in chronic liver disease</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Prothrombin time</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Partial thromboplastin time</td><td>• Prolonged in vitamin K deficiency and when there is reduced hepatic synthesis</td></tr><tr><td>• Both tests reflect the ability of liver to synthesise this protein</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Blood glucose</td><td>• May obtain serum value or obtained with finger prick (BM Stix)</td></tr><tr><td>• Levels reflect ability of the liver to metabolise nutrients</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul>
<li>Infants, children and adolescents with viral hepatitis must be followed closely. Any sign of decreasing liver function requires admission to hospital (including specialist referral). This includes changes in behaviour such as drowsiness, irritability and 'naughty'/aggressive behaviour which may indicate encephalopathy and cerebral oedema (acute/fulminant) liver failure.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="medical-consult-specialist-referral">MEDICAL CONSULT/SPECIALIST REFERRAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-consult-specialist-referral" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Any infant or child in whom the aetiology of jaundice is not readily apparent from history, physical examination and initial diagnostics.</li>
<li>Any infant or child in whom there is conjugated hyperbilirubinaemia.</li>
<li>Any child with an alteration in liver function or in whom there are any signs of liver disease.</li>
<li>Jaundice in the newborn that is not resolved within 14 days.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="paediatric-pearls">PAEDIATRIC PEARLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paediatric-pearls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Jaundice is common in the neonatal period and is likely to be 'physiological'. However, be careful not to ignore it or give false reassurance and watch for spontaneous resolution within 14 days (further investigations required if not resolved). Surgery-based urine dip sticks for bilirubin (urine must be fresh) can be a useful, cheap and quick screening tool.</li>
<li>Request total and split bilirubin levels as one of the first investigations.</li>
<li>Jaundice in the newborn which persists after 14 days must be investigated.</li>
<li>Pale stools and dark urine are physical symptoms to be specifically enquired into; note that urine in newborns should be colourless.</li>
<li>Breast-milk jaundice may develop during the first week of life in exclusively breast-fed infants and usually peaks at the end of the second week of life. However, occasionally it may persist as long as 1–2 months. The diagnosis is clinical, with differential bilirubin levels (checked at 14 days of age) revealing elevated unconjugated bilirubin and normal conjugated bilirubin (≤20 μmol/l). Physical examination is without findings (jaundice excepted) as are haemoglobin, reticulocytes and compatibility of maternal blood group. Breast-feeding can continue but jaundice should be monitored until resolved. If jaundice persists after 1–2 months, further studies should be instituted.</li>
<li>Early diagnosis of liver disease is vital and has a direct effect on outcome.</li>
</ul>
<p>While initial investigations should be commenced in primary and secondary care, expedient referral to a specialist centre is important. Early diagnosis of extrahepatic biliary atresia is especially important as the operation to facilitate biliary drainage (Kasai procedure) must be undertaken in a specialist centre by 8 weeks of age. Infants who undergo this procedure significantly later (or those in whom the procedure has failed) often require transplantation within 1–2 years.</p>
<ul>
<li>The Children’s Liver Disease Foundation publishes the information leaflet <em>Early Identification of Liver Disease in Infants</em>, which is available free of charge from the foundation (tel: 0121-212-3839).</li>
<li>Not all liver disease presents with jaundice in the early stages (especially older infants and children); careful history, physical examination and basic diagnostics (liver function tests, bilirubin levels that include split levels, FBC, urine dipstick and infection screens) are vital.</li>
<li>High turnover of red blood cells due to haemolysis can cause jaundice. Serum bilirubin levels will be elevated, with an increase in the unconjugated component.</li>
<li>Elevated total serum bilirubin levels with an elevated conjugated component ≥20 μmol/l are signs of liver disease: refer immediately.</li>
<li>Abnormal feeding (voracious appetite or anorexia) can be signs of chronic/progressive liver disease and may precede obvious jaundice.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bibliography">BIBLIOGRAPHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bibliography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Beath SV, Booth IW, Kelly DA. Nutritional support in liver disease. Arch Dis Child 1993; 69:545–549.
Hull J, Kelly DA. Investigation of prolonged neonatal jaundice. Curr Paediatr 1991; 89:228–230.
Jarvis C. The abdomen: developmental considerations in the infant and child. In: Jarvis C. ed., Physical examination and health assessment, 2nd edn. London: WB Saunders; 1996: 628–631.
Kelly DA. Diseases of the liver and biliary system in children. Oxford: Blackwell Science; 1999.</p>
<p>12.5 Threadworms</p>
<p>12 COMMON PAEDIATRIC PROBLEMS</p>
<p>Mieli-Vergani G, Howard ER, Portman B, et al. Late referral for biliary atresia: missed opportunities for effective surgery. Lancet 1989; 8635:421–423.</p>
<p>Mowat AP. Liver disorders in childhood, 3rd edn. Oxford: Butterworth-Heinemann; 1994.</p>
<p>Mowat AP, Davison LL, Dick MC. Early identification of biliary atresia and hepatobiliary disease: selective screening in the 3rd week. Arch Dis Child 1995; 72:90–92.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="12-5-threadworms">12.5 THREADWORMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-5-threadworms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Diane Norton</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Infection by <em>Enterobius vermicularis</em> (threadworms) is the most common parasitic infection in developed countries and a common cause of rectal itching in families with young children.</li>
<li>Threadworm infection predominantly affects pre-school and school-aged children between 5 and 10 years of age.</li>
<li>Characteristically, the child or parent will complain of rectal itching (starting about 1 hour after going to bed). There is continued disruption of sleep through the night and girls may additionally complain of vulvar itching and dysuria.</li>
<li>If the anus is inspected during the night, ova or white, thread-like worms (approximately 1 cm long) may be seen. In this scenario, parents will (understandably) be upset.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology">PATHOPHYSIOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Transmission of threadworms is via the faecal–oral route, with fomite spread common (the eggs can survive in bedding, clothing and house dust for many days).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Once ingested, the eggs hatch in the intestine and mature worms subsequently migrate to the rectum where eggs are laid in perianal skin (and become infectious within 2–4 hours).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Perianal itching is caused by the gravid worm exiting from the anus to lay eggs. The migrating female causes the child to scratch, which also results in the harbouring of eggs under the fingernails.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The worms trigger a minimal inflammatory response in the lower bowel mucosa, which correlates with few gastrointestinal symptoms.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Humans are the only known host and the entire cycle (from ingestion of eggs to perianal egg-laying) takes approximately 4–6 weeks.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="history">HISTORY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Temporality of symptoms (typically, perianal itching, occurs at night or early morning), physical complaints and an assessment of infection and transmission risk. More specifically, the history should address:</li>
<li>onset, frequency and extent of ‘itching’</li>
<li>day-care attendance, handwashing routines and any history of foreign travel or other exposures</li>
<li>other family members with symptoms and previous home management</li>
<li>any additional symptoms or visualisation of ova or worms.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physical-examination">PHYSICAL EXAMINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Assessment of the abdomen and inspection of the rectum and external genitalia may be negative or, in severe cases, there may be some slight rectal irritation or excoriation from scratching round the anus.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In pre-pubescent girls it is not uncommon to find some slight inflammation of the vulva (especially if there is secondary infection). It is unlikely that threadworms or ova will be seen.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Physical examination requires careful explanation and consent from both parent and child.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="differential-diagnoses">DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differential-diagnoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Additional aetiologies for rectal itching that should be considered include other parasitic infections, mild gastroenteritis, bacterial or fungal vulvovaginitis, chemical dermatitis, nappy rash, vulvitis from soaps or lotions, poor hygiene or sexual abuse.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Additional diagnostics: a definitive diagnosis of <em>Enterobius vermicularis</em> infection can be made by microscopic identification of the worms collected via a ‘tape test’ (a small piece of transparent Sellotape is wrapped around the carer’s finger, sticky side out, and patted over the anus in the early morning before the child rises). If other aetiologies are under consideration, stool for culture and ova/parasite and FBC may be of diagnostic help.</li>
<li>Pharmacotherapeutics: threadworm infection is treated with mebendazole, given as a single dose (for all children over 2 years of age) of 100 mg. Repeat dose after 2 weeks if reinfection is suspected. Note that chewable tablets of 100 mg are available and can be purchased from a pharmacy or a suspension is available on prescription. Consider treatment of all family members (with exception of pregnant women and children &lt;2 years) as threadworm communicability is high. Piperazine (Pripsen) can be given to</li>
</ul>
<p>12 Gastrointestinal and endocrine problems</p>
<p>children over 3 months of age but it is contraindicated for patients with epilepsy, renal failure or hepatic failure. Symptoms should resolve within a few days of treatment. The dosing schedule is as follows: 3 months to 1 year (2.5 ml of powder); 1–6 years (5 ml of powder); and for children over 6 years of age (1 sachet or 7.5 ml of powder). The dose should be repeated after 14 days.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Behavioural interventions:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Good hygiene practices with frequent warm baths if rectal itching/vulvar irritation is marked.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Careful handwashing routines are vital and nails should be kept short.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Laundry should be washed in hot water and care should be taken to avoid shaking the bedding and clothing before laundering; toys taken to bed may also require washing.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Discourage nail-biting and ensure those infected sleep alone.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Wearing cotton pants and gloves may help to discourage scratching while asleep.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Complications of threadworm infection are uncommon, but typically are related to secondary infection and irritation from the pruritus; these should be treated symptomatically.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Patient education:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Threadworm infection is very upsetting to families. Stress the benign course and simple treatment in addition to addressing specific concerns (likely to be related to transmission, communicability, daycare attendance and environmental control).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If microscopic confirmation is required, parents will need ‘tape-test’ instructions.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Remind the family that threadworms are contracted through human contact only and they are not ‘worms’ from domestic or farm animal contact.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Reassure family members that threadworm is not a sign of poor hygiene. However, it is an opportune time to review the role of handwashing in preventing not only threadworm infection but also as an important, good health practice.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p><strong>FOLLOW-UP</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Follow-up is generally not indicated unless symptoms persist or reappear.</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p><strong>MEDICAL CONSULT/ SPECIALIST REFERRAL</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Any infection in a child &lt; 2 years of age (or households with a pregnant woman).</li>
<li>Any child with a history or physical findings suggestive of sexual abuse.</li>
<li>Any child who experiences complications such as urethritis, vaginitis, salpingitis or pelvic peritonitis.</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p><strong>PAEDIATRIC PEARLS</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>The diagnosis of parasitic infection can only be made if the possibility is considered.</li>
<li>Reinfection is common if close contacts are not treated.</li>
<li>Threadworm infection can be spread through nursery or child care centres; be sure to inform the carer(s) if infection occurs.</li>
<li>The physical examination may not be helpful in determining the diagnosis and, therefore, a thorough history with a high index of suspicion is the key to an accurate diagnosis.</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p><strong>BIBLIOGRAPHY</strong></p>

<p>Finn L. Threadworm infections. Community Nurse 1996; 2(7):39.</p>
<p>Gilbert P. Skin problems and parasites in children 2: parasitic worms. Prof Care Mother Child 1998; 8(4):105–106.</p>

<hr>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="12-6-diabetes-mellitus">12.6 DIABETES MELLITUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-6-diabetes-mellitus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Adele McEvilly</p>
<hr>
<p><strong>INTRODUCTION</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Diabetes mellitus (DM) is a severe metabolic condition: it is a disorder of absolute (Type 1) or relative (Type 2) insulin deficiency that results in disruption of normal energy storage and metabolism. Type 1 Diabetes is caused by a cessation of insulin production, whereas Type 2 Diabetes is caused by a relative insulin deficit (e.g. insulin resistance at the tissue level). In childhood, the prevalence of Type 1 is far greater than Type 2 and, therefore, is more likely to be encountered in paediatric practice.</li>
<li>The reduction in insulin production in Type 2 disease is very gradual and it may take up to 2 years before symptoms present. Insulin production has usually decreased as much as 70% by the time clinical symptoms of insulin deficiency are apparent (e.g. polydipsia, polyuria, ketonuria, nocturia, enuresis, glycosuria, hyperglycaemia and weight loss). In addition, the lack of blood glucose control and hyperglycaemia can result in ketosis, acidosis, dehydration, shock and death (e.g. diabetic ketoacidosis or DKA).</li>
<li>Type 2 Diabetes is the third most common chronic medical problem in childhood (most common endocrine</li>
</ul>
<p>12.6 Diabetes mellitus</p>
<p>problem), with the incidence increasing at all ages and across races. Boys and girls are equally affected, with an estimated 16 new cases per 100,000 children per year. Prevalence is estimated at 1:400 children of school age with diabetes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology-type-i-diabetes">PATHOPHYSIOLOGY (TYPE I DIABETES)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology-type-i-diabetes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Diabetes is caused by an autoimmune response in a child who is born with a genetic risk for Type 1 DM; the trigger is either an infection and/or something within the environment. This autoimmune response results in (1) recruitment of cytotoxic lymphocytes and (2) production of anti-insulin and anti-islet cell antibodies which progressively destroy the beta cells of the Islets of Langerhans in the pancreas (the site of insulin production).</li>
<li>Subsequently, there is a failure of the insulin-producing capacity of the pancreas, with consequential loss of the body's ability to utilise glucose (e.g. transport it from the bloodstream into cells).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="history">HISTORY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Onset and duration of symptoms.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Family history of diabetes.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Typical physical symptoms of new onset Type 1 Diabetes:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Polyuria and enuresis: excessively wet nappies that soak the cot; bed-wetting in a child who was previously dry at night; rising several times a night to go to the toilet; leaving lessons to use the toilet.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Polydipsia: child will drink excessively from any fluid source they can reach; continually ask for drinks; leaving lessons to get drink; getting up at night for a drink.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Lethargy: a toddler who does not want to leave the pushchair; reduced interest in playing with friends; decreases/stops outside activities.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Ketone breath: commonly described as smelling like 'pear drops', although not everyone can smell pear drops.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Weight loss: a symptom often missed by parents, as it is attributed to</p>
</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>Table 12.15 Physical Examination Findings in Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA)</th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Symptom</td><td>Physical examination findings</td></tr><tr><td>Dehydration</td><td>• Mild (3–5%): dry mucous membranes, slightly reduced skin turgor</td></tr><tr><td>• Moderate (10%): as above, with sunken eyes and decreased capillary refill</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Severe (&gt;10% with signs of shock): very ill with poor perfusion, thready, rapid pulse, reduced blood pressure, markedly reduced urine output</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Decreased level of consciousness (LOC)</td><td>• Age-related findings, but infants would be listless with decreased responsiveness to stimuli. Older children display disorientation and/or decreased responsiveness to questions. Use modified Glasgow Coma scale to assess</td></tr><tr><td>Acidosis</td><td>• Ketone smell to breath (pear drops)</td></tr><tr><td>• Acidotic respirations (increased rate with sighing)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Electrocardiogram (ECG) may show T-wave changes indicative of altered electrolyte status</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>growth changes of the adolescents who wish to lose weight.</p>
<ul>
<li>Frequently there are vague complaints of abdominal pain, constipation, hunger, thrush or other infections (e.g. candidal vulvovaginitis).</li>
<li>More serious complaints associated with related acidosis include changes in behaviour, mental status and/or school performance; malaise and/or muscular weakness; Kussmaul breathing (sighing respirations); and coma/death (rare).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physical-examination">PHYSICAL EXAMINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>General observation of the child is important, including the degree of thirst and polyuria exhibited during the visit. Note weight (assess for changes if parent has recent weight), vital signs (including presence of Kussmaul respirations and ketone breath), hydration status, activity level and degree of interactiveness.</li>
<li>A physical examination in early Type 1 DM presentation is typically normal; however, a full assessment should be performed, including evaluation of the musculoskeletal and neurological systems, looking for abnormalities in tone, strength and level of consciousness.</li>
<li>Assess degree of hydration in mouth (palpating inside cheek for sandpaper-type feel) and skin turgor by checking the skin on the abdomen.</li>
<li>Rule out signs and symptoms of shock.</li>
<li>If left untreated, early symptoms of Type 1 DM give way to rapid onset of DKA, a potentially life-threatening</li>
</ul>
<p>complication. Physical signs and symptoms of DKA are outlined in Table 12.15.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="differential-diagnoses">DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differential-diagnoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Numerous: urinary tract infection (UTI), renal glycosuria, hypercalcaemia, other chronic illness (especially with children presenting with fatigue, malaise and weight loss), stress-related hyperglycaemia, drug-induced hyperglycaemia (steroid use), pneumonia, sepsis and acute abdominal event. Note that glycosuria (that is not diabetes-related) may occur following an acute infection.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The management of diabetes mellitus is complex and involves medical, educational and psychosocial support. These should be provided on a 24-hour basis by the paediatric diabetes team, who maintain links with primary care. The diagnosis will have an impact on all family members, who will each cope in their own individual way. Some parents will grieve for their normal healthy child and struggle with feelings of guilt at the diagnosis. Support provided must recognise and empathise with any difficulties the family may feel, as they have to come to terms with insulin injections, blood glucose monitoring, dietary adjustment, achievement of good blood glucose control and management of a chronic illness. The targets for care must be individual, taking into account</p>
<p>12 Gastrointestinal and endocrine problems</p>
<p>Table 12.16 Management of Diabetic Ketoacidosis</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Management</th><th>Details</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Initial management</td><td>• General resuscitation, including 100% oxygen, and intravenous fluid (to correct hypokalaemia and dehydration)</td></tr><tr><td>• Treat shock with 20 ml/kg boluses of 0.9% saline</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Once rehydration has commenced, insulin therapy is initiated</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Ongoing management</td><td>• Hourly blood glucose monitoring</td></tr><tr><td>• Confirm correction of dehydration</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Strict fluid balance monitoring/recording</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Regular monitoring of serum potassium</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Urine testing for glucose and ketones</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Frequent neurological observations (Glasgow scale)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Cardiac monitoring</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Observations for signs of cerebral oedema, including irritability, slowing of pulse, increasing blood pressure and papilloedema</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Table 12.17 Insulin Therapy</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Treatment</th><th>Details</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Administration</td><td>• Twice daily administration for a majority of children and adolescents</td></tr><tr><td>• Administered via subcutaneous injection with 5–8 mm needle and syringe or pen injector</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Insulin is absorbed at different rates from different sites; routine is required for consistent absorption (i.e. injections into arms or stomach in the morning and legs or buttocks in the evening)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Usual regimen is a combination of rapid-acting lispro insulin or short-acting soluble insulin, with an isophane intermediate-acting insulin</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• These may be free mixed in the syringe or given as a fixed mixture, which is more popular now with the increased use of pen injectors</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• A basal bolus regimen of three injections of rapid-acting insulin prior to main meals and an injection of isophane prior to bed is increasingly used in older children</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Dosage</td><td>• At diagnosis there is (presumed) residual insulin production and dose is calculated at 0.5 units/kg/24 hours, usually distributed as two-thirds in the morning and one-third in the evening</td></tr><tr><td>• Dosage increases to 1 unit/kg as residual insulin production decreases</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• In adolescence, due to insulin resistance, insulin requirements increase to 1.5 units/kg/24 hours and in some cases 2 units/kg/24 hours</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• The higher insulin doses are reduced at the end of growth and puberty</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Side-effects</td><td>• Hyperglycaemia</td></tr><tr><td>• Hypoglycaemia</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Hypertrophy local site irritation (soreness, bruising)</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>age, intelligence, family stability and personal targets. Diabetic ketoacidosis is the most life-threatening complication of Type 1 DM and, therefore, requires high dependency care. Basic management of DKA is outlined in Table 12.16.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Additional diagnostics: an index of suspicion is raised with positive urine glucose and ketones findings followed by capillary (fingerprick) measurement of blood glucose (normal range is 3–7 mmol/l). Diagnosis is confirmed with results from venous glucose, urea and electrolytes, arterial blood gases and full blood count (FBC). In addition, glycosylated haemoglobin can be considered as it gives an idea of blood glucose levels over the previous 2–3 months. Note, however, that it is used for monitoring and is not diagnostic on its own. Glycosylated haemoglobin is also useful in routine follow-up as it provides an objective index of diabetic control. Consider an electrocardiogram (ECG) if there is suspicion of acidosis.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pharmacotherapeutics:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Insulin therapy is the basis of medical treatment. Characteristics of therapy and dosage guidelines are outlined in Table 12.17. Note that in cases of DKA, hospital admission for continuous insulin infusion is often required.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Behavioural interventions: these are outlined in Table 12.18.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Patient education</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Home management at the time of diagnosis provides the ideal opportunity for education of the child, siblings and both parents; education should be adapted to suit the individual family and provided at a rate that suits them as they come to terms with the shock of diagnosis.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Knowledge and understanding of the family (including their individual dynamics) must be continually updated; therefore, the family’s management of DM must be reviewed and discussed at each visit.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Review with parents the chronic nature of the disease. A frequently encountered diabetes ‘myth’ is that children grow out of diabetes or are able to go onto tablets when they are older. It is important that parents come to terms with the lifelong implications of DM.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stress the importance of continuing education that is adapted to the child and family’s individual needs and abilities; negotiation, partnership and the development of self-care are vital.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Discuss with parents the positive support the child will need throughout childhood and into adolescence; this must include a period of interdependence that allows the young person to take on more responsibility as he becomes more confident and capable.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Reinforce with parents that education of all carers is essential: the child must always be in a safe environment; this includes educating staff in the school and nursery. The health professionals caring for the child and family should have some sort of provision to ensure this collaboration.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="follow-up">FOLLOW-UP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#follow-up" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Children with diabetes will be followed up for the rest of their lives and, while young, this will involve 3–4 monthly paediatric diabetes hospital clinic appointments where their height, weight and urine is checked.</li>
<li>Five years after diagnosis or from puberty onwards, an annual clinic</li>
</ul>
<p>12.6 Diabetes mellitus</p>
<p>COMMON PAEDIATRIC PROBLEMS</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Action</th><th>Comment</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Hyperglycaemia intervention</td><td>• In children, defined as pre-prandial blood glucose &gt;10 mmol/l</td></tr><tr><td>• Signs include those experienced prior to diagnosis and most parents notice a change in temperament</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Treatment depends on the causes, which include growth, inappropriate insulin or dietary management, stress, illness or exercise-related</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Full history required before advice is given and referral to diabetes team is essential if hyperglycaemia is persistent or ketones are present in urine</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Hypoglycaemia intervention</td><td>• Defined as blood glucose ≤4 mmol/l</td></tr><tr><td>• Signs include pallor, shaky feeling, headache, blurred vision, tingling, tiredness and/or twitching</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Initial treatment consists of increasing blood glucose level by increasing oral intake of refined glucose (10–20 g). Glucose (10 g) is available from one of the following: 2 teaspoons sugar, 3 sugar lumps, 3 glucose tablets, 200 ml milk, 50–55 ml of non-diet versions of Lucozade Sparkling Glucose Drink, or 90 ml of Coca-Cola</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Repeat treatment if no improvement after 5–10 min and continue until better</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Once feeling better: unrefined carbohydrate required (biscuit or sandwich)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• If unable to give glucose by mouth, Hypostop Gel (glucose 10 g) can be rubbed into gums provided the child is conscious</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• If unconscious or fitting, glucagon (1 mg) can be given by intramuscular injection</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Dietary intervention</td><td>• Healthy eating is mainstay of dietary management</td></tr><tr><td>• Unrefined (starchy) carbohydrates should be eaten as part of 3 main meals and 3 snacks each day with avoidance of refined carbohydrate (except at appropriate times)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Other nutritional requirements (protein, fats, fruit and vegetable intake, etc.) as for non-diabetic children</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Blood glucose monitoring</td><td>• Most effective way of monitoring metabolic control on a day-to-day basis</td></tr><tr><td>• Link between blood glucose control and long-term complications</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Blood glucose targets must be individual and realistic (i.e. ideal blood glucose levels may lead to frequent and severe hypoglycaemic episodes that can result in developmental delays in young children)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Parental stress can arise from the control/complication link, especially during adolescence when the two management styles may be at odds (e.g. the adolescent wanting to forget about the diabetes and parent more concerned with long-term implications of erratic control)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Glycosylated haemoglobin measurement is a longer-term index of blood glucose control as the amount of glucose attached to the red cell for its half-life is measured. As such, an overview of metabolic control over the preceding 6–8 weeks is obtained</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Note that there are different measures for this test and target ranges will vary across centres, as will values for individual patients</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Exercise</td><td>• Beneficial to metabolic control but must be managed effectively (i.e. prevention of hypoglycaemia)</td></tr><tr><td>• Extra refined carbohydrate should be eaten before and sometimes during exercise</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• For particularly strenuous or prolonged exercise, insulin may be reduced and extra unrefined carbohydrate taken</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Management should be discussed with the diabetes team</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Illness</td><td>• Illness may affect blood glucose levels and early contact should be made to the diabetes team to discuss appropriate management</td></tr><tr><td>• Stomach upset may require a reduction in insulin, while a feverish illness could lead to the development of high glucose levels and ketones, which would require an increase in insulin and referral to the diabetes team</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Carbohydrate intake needs to be maintained and this is often taken initially as small, frequent sweet drinks; increase volume as soon as well tolerated to avoid dehydration. If carbohydrates are not tolerated, urgent hospital referral is required</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Links with primary care should be maintained during illness</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>check should include eyes (through dilated pupils), microalbuminuria, blood pressure and examination of the feet. Periodically, blood tests should be carried out for thyroid and coeliac antibodies.</p>
<ul>
<li>A paediatric diabetes team should also offer home support, with visits either once or twice a year.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="medical-consult-specialist-referral">MEDICAL CONSULT/ SPECIALIST REFERRAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-consult-specialist-referral" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(including the paediatric diabetic nurse specialist)</p>
<ul>
<li>Any child in whom there is an exceptionally high blood glucose level associated with ketones, vomiting and/or dehydration as there is a suspicion of DKA and urgent referral is necessary.</li>
<li>Any child in whom an episode of illness is affecting blood glucose levels and parents are unsure about how to, or reluctant to, adjust insulin under guidance from the diabetes nurse.</li>
<li>Any child who has persistently high blood glucose levels over 2 or 3 days should be reviewed by the diabetes nurse and then referred to the consultant if the problem continues.</li>
<li>Any child who experiences frequent episodes of hypoglycaemia (more than 1 per week or more than 1 severe episode within a short space of time).</li>
<li>Any child who is planning to travel abroad or attend organised activity weeks.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="paediatric-pearls">PAEDIATRIC PEARLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paediatric-pearls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Assess the family’s sophistication with the Internet at the time of diagnosis; there is a tremendous amount of information available and families may need help interpreting it all. In addition, they can be overwhelmed by the complications of diabetes so soon after diagnosis.</li>
<li>Anticipatory guidance with regard to parenting skills is important; encourage parents to avoid</li>
</ul>
<p>157</p>
<p>12 Gastrointestinal and endocrine problems</p>
<p>making diabetes a point of conflict.</p>
<ul>
<li>There is a link between diabetes control and the later development of complications. Intensive management and tight maintenance of blood glucose can significantly reduce the risk of diabetic retinopathy, nephropathy and neuropathy. However, a balance must be found to ensure that the young person is not traumatised by the pressure.</li>
<li>Without an index of suspicion, the diagnosis of Type 1 DM is occasionally missed and a child may instead be treated for chest infection, UTI or candidiasis. The likelihood of a child in general practice presenting with DM, while uncommon, is not rare; be alert for this possibility to assure a diagnosis is not overlooked. Likewise, an increasing number of young people are developing Type 2 Diabetes; consider this possibility and make use of surgery-based screening tools (urine dipsticks, fingerprick glucose).</li>
<li>There is usually a period of remission following initial stabilisation of blood glucose after diagnosis. This is referred to as the 'honeymoon period' and is a reflection of residual <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-cell insulin production. While this period usually lasts weeks to months, it can persist for longer. Insulin doses need to be reduced accordingly and families need to be warned of this possibility as they</li>
</ul>
<p>may think the diagnosis was incorrect and 'is going away'.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The goals of glucose control are (1) to feel well; (2) to maintain pre-prandial blood glucose levels <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex-error" title="ParseError: KaTeX parse error: Expected 'EOF', got '&amp;' at position 1: &amp;̲lt; 10\mathrm{m…" style="color: rgb(204, 0, 0);">&amp;lt; 10\mathrm{mmol} / \mathrm{l}</span></span>; (3) to avoid hypoglycaemic episodes; (4) to promote normal growth and development; and (5) to attain a reasonable non-restrictive lifestyle while maintaining positive psychosocial and emotional development.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The National Service Framework (NSF) for diabetes has been published. The framework includes recommendations on diagnosis, management and follow-up of diabetes. The NSF is likely to have a big impact on diabetes in general, although the extent that it will affect paediatrics remains to be seen.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Internet diabetes resources:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Diabetes UK: <a href="http://www.diabetes.org.uk" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.diabetes.org.uk</a> (email: <a href="mailto:balance@diabetes.org.uk" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">balance@diabetes.org.uk</a>)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Juvenile Diabetes Foundation: <a href="http://www.jdf.irg.uk" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.jdf.irg.uk</a></p>
</li>

</li>

</li>
</ul>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="12-7-delayed-sexual-development-delayed-puberty">12.7 DELAYED SEXUAL DEVELOPMENT (DELAYED PUBERTY)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-7-delayed-sexual-development-delayed-puberty" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Angela Casey</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>'Normal' puberty is difficult to define as there is great variation with regard to the timing and rate of pubertal changes. Influencing factors include social, genetic, environmental, nutritional and gender-related factors.</li>
<li>Among girls, puberty usually begins between the ages of 8 and 13 years, whereas pubertal changes for boys occur slightly later (9-14 years of age).</li>
</ul>
<p>Delayed puberty in females is defined as the absence of initial pubertal changes (i.e. Tanner stage 2) after 14 years of age or an interval of greater than 5 years between the initiation of breast growth and menarche. Amongst males, delayed puberty is the absence of initial pubertal changes after 14.5 years of age or a gap of greater than 5 years between the start of genital growth and its completion (i.e. Tanner stage 5).</p>
<ul>
<li>Note that the appearance of axillary or pubic hair without concomitant breast or genital growth is not necessarily indicative of the start of pubertal changes. It is termed premature adrenarche and often reflects maturation of the adrenal gland.</li>
<li>Delayed puberty is one of the most common reasons for growth clinic referral, which is seen more often in boys than in girls (due to differences</li>
</ul>
<p>12.7 Delayed sexual development (delayed puberty)</p>
<p>in the sensitivity of the hypothalamo-pituitary-gonadal axis).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology">PATHOPHYSIOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Puberty describes the process by which a child's body matures into adulthood. Following a period of steady growth in childhood, puberty is distinguished by rapid and dramatic body changes. These include (1) the development of secondary sexual characteristics; (2) the achievement of fertility; and (3) an adolescent growth spurt that is completed by the fusion of the long bone epiphyses and attainment of final adult height. It is important to note that while there can be wide variation in the timing and rate of pubertal changes, they occur in a predictable sequence and well-documented pattern (see Tanner staging, Figs 12.1–12.3).</li>
<li>The onset of puberty is activated by an increase in gonadotrophin-releasing hormone (GnRH) from the hypothalamus to the pituitary gland, which subsequently secretes the pituitary gonatrophins, luteinising hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH). These hormones initiate egg production in the ovaries and sperm production in the testes and are responsible for the secretion of the additional sex hormones (testosterone, oestrogen and progesterone).</li>
<li>Note that a delay in the onset or progression of sexual development can be caused by numerous factors, each with their own specific pathophysiology.</li>
<li>Figure 12.4 outlines the endocrine glands and their specific hormones.</li>
</ul>

<p>Table 12.19 Differential Diagnoses of Delayed Puberty</p>

evidence of appropriate nutrition; linear growth of at least 3.7 cm/year; normal physical examination (including genital anatomy, sense of smell and upper and lower body proportions); normal diagnostics (urinalysis, full blood count, C-reactive protein or erythrocyte sedimentation rate); <div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="history">HISTORY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Growth record (see also Sec. 12.9).</li>
<li>Review of systems, including enquiries regarding chronic illness or medication use.</li>
<li>History of genital irradiation, surgery, infection or trauma.</li>
<li>Nutrition and eating habits (both malnutrition and anorexia nervosa can delay puberty).</li>
<li>Exercise/activity.</li>
<li>Family or school stressors, including marked deprivation. Note that extreme psychological stress can delay puberty and growth.</li>
<li>Age of puberty for parents and/or family history of delayed puberty or growth (especially among older siblings and parents).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physical-examination">PHYSICAL EXAMINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>General appearance of the child (see also Sec. 12.9), including overall assessment of health, nutritional status and body proportions.</li>
<li>Accurate height and weight measurement (with plotting of height and weight).</li>
<li>Assessment of thyroid.</li>
<li>Tanner staging of sexual maturity: depending on the child’s age there should be early breast bud appearance in females (Tanner stage 2) and testicular volume of at least 4 ml in boys (Tanner stage 2). The Prader orchidometer is a useful tool for assessing testicular development. Each testicle should be manually palpated and its size compared to the Prader bead closest in size.</li>
<li>General physical examination to rule out a potential disorder outside the genital/reproductive system that could contribute to the lack of development (evidence of cardiac, pulmonary, liver, renal or neurological problems).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="differential-diagnoses">DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differential-diagnoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>See Table 12.19.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Additional diagnostics: consider basic diagnostics to rule out other illness (urinalysis, full blood count, erythrocyte</li>
</ul>
<p>12.7 Delayed sexual development (delayed puberty)</p>
<p>sedimentation rate or C-reactive protein, urea and electrolytes). A bone age X-ray of the left wrist is helpful as it can compare chronological age with physiological age. Chromosomal and hormonal analyses are considered in cases of suspected gonadal failure and often performed in specialty care. Pelvic ultrasound may also be considered if there is suspicion of absent gonads or underdevelopment.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Pharmacotherapeutics: the use of medications in delayed puberty is related to the degree of stress experienced by the child/family and the aetiology of the delay. Low-dose oxandrolone (anabolic steroid) can be used to stimulate the pubertal growth spurt in boys with CDPG, whereas testosterone is used when there is concern over delayed secondary sexual characteristics. Girls with CDPG can be prescribed a low-dose oestrogen (ethinyloestradiol) to stimulate breast development for 6–12 months. It should be noted that hormonal or steroid therapy is a decision that requires careful consideration and is likely to only be taken within the context of specialty consultation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Behavioural interventions:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Ongoing support is required for the adolescent and the family.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Children with an underlying pathology will require additional interventions specific to their illness (gluten-free diet in coeliac disease, treatment of anorexia nervosa, etc.).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Reassure the adolescent and family regarding the self-limiting nature of CDPG; they will require support and practical advice with issues such as identity cards for proof of age.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Patient education:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Discuss honestly with the adolescent the expected course the puberty delay will (likely) take and the aetiology behind the delay. Adolescence is a time of great upheaval (even when its course runs as expected), so that for those with an unanticipated delay there is potential for extreme stress.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In cases of CDPG, remind patients and their families that puberty and growth will occur, especially as other</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>causes for the delay have been investigated/ruled out. Reassure them that follow-up will check that no abnormality was missed and that they will experience growth and sexual maturation.</p>
<ul>
<li>Provide patients and their families with anticipatory guidance regarding unwanted effects of hormonal treatment in CDPG (secondary sexual characteristics, acne, mood swings).</li>
<li>The Child Growth Foundation, 2 Mayfield Avenue, London W4 1PW is a potential resource for practical advice on topics such as identity cards, bullying, clothing shops, etc.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="follow-up">FOLLOW-UP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#follow-up" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Follow-up is largely determined by the treatment course. If watchful waiting is planned, follow-up in 3–6 months is advisable.</li>
<li>If pubertal changes have not started in girls over 14 years of age and boys over 15 years of age, specialist referral is indicated.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="medical-consult-specialist-referral">MEDICAL CONSULT/ SPECIALIST REFERRAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-consult-specialist-referral" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Any child with a delay in pubertal development (clear-cut constitutional delay excepted).</li>
<li>Any child in whom the aetiology of the delay is unclear.</li>
<li>Any child or family experiencing significant stress related to the delayed puberty.</li>
<li>Any child in whom hormone or steroid treatment is being considered.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="paediatric-pearls">PAEDIATRIC PEARLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paediatric-pearls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Faulty measuring techniques or poorly calibrated measuring equipment often result in mistakes on the child’s growth chart; careful attention must be paid to measurement technique and equipment.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Treat the child according to his/her age not size; it is important not to ‘baby’.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Children with delayed pubertal development are at risk of bullying; address this issue in the assessment and anticipatory guidance with the child and family.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Excluding chronic illness and constitutional delay, Turner’s syndrome is one of the more common causes of maturational delay (see also Sec. 12.9).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In eliciting information with regard to pubertal development of family members, it is useful to enquire about mother’s age at menarche, older sisters’ age at menarche, age at which father started to shave and whether father (or mother) were much shorter than their classmates as a teenager.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is helpful to consider the following in the evaluation of pubertal delay:
(1) evidence of any disorder that may be responsible for the growth failure (e.g. undiagnosed chronic illness);
(2) the extent to which skeletal maturation has progressed; and
(3) evidence of disruption of gonadal or hypothalamic-pituitary function.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bibliography">BIBLIOGRAPHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bibliography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
