lateral hip film with cleft in femoral head. Bone scan shows decrease uptake, whereas magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) will show avascular necrosis (even if radiographs are normal)</td></tr><tr><td>Septic arthritis</td><td>Usually affects children &lt;10 years of ageSudden onset of significant hip pain accompanied by fever and ill/toxic appearance; leg is often held in flexed abduction with decreased ROM (child often refuses to straighten)Laboratory values with signs of marked inflammation and acute infection; blood cultures considered to isolate organism (positive in 20% of cases) but joint fluid aspiration with better yield (positive in 80% of cases)Radiological findings reveal increased joint space (secondary to infection) although may be normal in early presentation; bone scan usually positive</td></tr><tr><td>Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE)</td><td>Most common in overweight adolescent males (9-16 years of age) with acute or chronic limpPain may vary from mild and persistent 'chronic SCFE' to sudden onset of severe pain (acute SCFE); pain may radiate to hip, groin or thighLoss of internal hip rotation (most pronounced with hip in extension); if insidious onset examination may reveal shortening of affected leg and thigh atrophyLaboratory evidence not helpfulRadiographic studies (anteroposterior and lateral or frog-legged positions) show slipped capital femoral epiphysis over neck of femur</td></tr><tr><td>Transient tenosynovitis (irritable hip or toxic synovitis)</td><td>Most common cause of limp and hip pain in children; usually benign and self-limiting (some children go on to develop Perthes' disease); diagnosis of exclusionAffects children &lt;10 years of age (usually 3-7 years old) and more common in malesModerate-to-marked pain of sudden onset with history of preceding viral illness; usually unilateral (right hip more commonly affected) but can be bilateralChild usually appears well but may have low-grade temperature elevationDecreased ROM (internal rotation and abduction) and child often prefers to hold in flexed, externally rotated positionLaboratory findings provide evidence of mild inflammationRadiological studies often normal but may show mild joint effusion</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>13 Musculoskeletal problems, neurological problems and trauma</p>
<ul>
<li>Age-specific history:</li>
<li>Infants: lack of spontaneous movement (i.e. lying still), rigidity, cry, dislike of handling.</li>
<li>Toddler/Pre-schooler: increased crying, upset, tantrums and requests to be 'carried'.</li>
<li>School-age/adolescents: able to articulate much of history (including location of pain).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physical-examination">PHYSICAL EXAMINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>General appearance of the child (well-appearing, toxic-looking, etc.): height, weight and vital signs.</li>
<li>Routine head-to-abdomen assessment: look for signs of systemic illness (rashes, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, etc.).</li>
<li>Musculoskeletal: careful assessment that begins with observation of the child while non-weight bearing (observe the child's gait last if hip is painful). It is important to assess pain and degree of movement of the joint although it is vital that early contacts with the child are not painful. It is often helpful to assess the child's baseline level of pain tolerance by touching a non-painful area and asking the child if that hurts. Palpate all joints for redness, tenderness, swelling, pain and limitation of movement.</li>
<li>Spine: examine carefully for any curvature, tufts or dimples.</li>
<li>Hips: assess the range of motion (ROM) of both hips, including hip flexion, extension, abduction (with hips extended and flexed), adduction (while hips are extended) and internal and external rotation of hips (with hips extended and flexed). Position the infant/child on his back for the examination (see Theophilopoulos &amp; Barrett, 1998 for details). Leg lengths can be determined by measuring from the anterior iliac crest to the medial malleolus (while supine and standing), in addition to comparing bony and surface landmarks. Infants and small children pose a greater assessment challenge and observational skills are even more paramount. Watch for spontaneous movement, response to palpation and passive ROM of</li>
</ul>
<p>joints/muscles (as above). Assessment of infants &lt;4 months of age should include evaluation for developmental dysplasia of the hip (Ortolani and Barlow manoeuvres), which may reveal limited abduction with flexed hips examination (see Theophilopoulos &amp; Barrett, 1998 for details).</p>
<ul>
<li>Gait: observe for symmetry, speed, stability of pelvis (including balancing on each leg separately, i.e. Trendelenburg's sign) and balance (while barefoot, undressed and from the front, back and side of the child). There are three types of gait disturbances. (1) Antalgic gait is painful gait that increases with stress of walking as the child tries to get weight off the affected side quickly. It is seen not only with painful hips but also with painful knees, toes and ankles. (2) Trendelenburg gait is caused by hip problems such as dislocation, dysplasia and inflammation etc. The child tilts over the affected hip with each stride in order to maintain his centre of gravity. (3) Ataxic gait is caused by lack of neurological coordination, which creates a wide-based, unsteady gait (i.e. a child with cerebral palsy or neuromuscular disease).</li>
<li>Neurological: examine muscle strength and tone for equality (comparing sides); assess deep tendon reflexes and sensation. Note any suspicion of spasticity.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="differential-diagnoses">DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differential-diagnoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>See Table 13.2.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Management of hip pain and limp is aetiology-specific but is likely to include specialist consultation and potential hospital admission (with all but the most self-limiting aetiologies). Consequently, additional diagnostics and pharmacotherapeutics are largely setting-dependent (i.e. primary or acute care) and may be completed as part of the initial work-up or during hospital admission.</p>
<ul>
<li>Additional diagnostics: Blood work—full blood count (FBC), erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP)—should</li>
</ul>
<p>all be considered to separate the infectious from the non-infectious hip. In addition, blood cultures, blood cell morphology and/or rheumatological studies may be helpful in pinpointing the diagnosis. Radiographic studies include anteroposterior (AP) views of the hip and lateral views of the pelvis. The frog-leg position is especially helpful in AP views and in the diagnosis of slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE), Perthes' disease, hip subluxations, dislocations and some fractures. Ultrasound evaluation is especially helpful with infants under 4 months old (as the femur head is not ossified and is poorly seen on radiographs). Ultrasound is also helpful in identification of joint effusions (toxic synovitis or septic hip joint). Consider bone scan to localise an area of infection (osteomyelitis) or areas of poor uptake (Perthes' disease). Computed tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and hip joint aspiration are all reserved for specialist intervention.</p>
<ul>
<li>Pharmacotherapeutics: aetiology-specific and may include non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and antibiotics.</li>
<li>Behavioural interventions: aetiology-specific but often include rest and physiotherapy at some point.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="patient-education">Patient education:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#patient-education" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>It is important that parents (and children) understand the cause of the problem and their role in its resolution.</li>
<li>Review with the family all diagnostics, medications, behavioural interventions, follow-up care and other professionals likely to be involved in care.</li>
<li>After discharge (from general practice or the ward), it is vital that families are advised about the signs and symptoms that necessitate immediate evaluation and are provided with contact information in order to do this (names, phone numbers, etc.).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="follow-up">FOLLOW-UP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#follow-up" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Aetiology-specific: all admissions are likely to be followed up in an</li>
</ul>
<p>13.2 Lacerations</p>
<p>orthopaedic clinic 2 weeks after discharge.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="medical-consult-specialist-referral">MEDICAL CONSULT/ SPECIALIST REFERRAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-consult-specialist-referral" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Any child with a painful, swollen joint, refusal to bear weight or complaints of hip pain/limp.</li>
<li>Any child with a toxic appearance.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="paediatric-pearls">PAEDIATRIC PEARLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paediatric-pearls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The history and physical examination findings are the basis for consultation and referral; do not postpone consultation in a child with a limp or hip pain while awaiting blood results.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Carefully inspect all joints; repeat of assessments of the child are important to monitor progress (pain, limitation of movement, onset of fever, etc.) and include re-accessing specialist consultation if the situation changes.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Painful joints can get better with no cause found; however, more serious aetiologies need to be ruled out, especially the possibility of septic arthritis, which can lead to death or permanent disability if the diagnosis is missed.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A history that is inconsistent with injury, examination and/or diagnostic findings should prompt the suspicion of non-accidental injury (NAI).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If there is pain in the knee, always look at the hip.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Complaints of hip pain and limp are not expected findings in children; evaluate them carefully.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bibliography">BIBLIOGRAPHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bibliography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="13-2-lacerations">13.2 LACERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#13-2-lacerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Melanie Hutton</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A laceration is a tear in the tissue caused by trauma. It can be classified as a simple laceration (no tissue loss, deeper injury or imbedded debris) or a complicated laceration (rupture of skin caused by blunt force with irregular borders and tearing of tissues). Examples of each include knife/glass cuts (simple) or a laceration after a fall or motor vehicle accident (complicated). It is useful to consider lacerations with regard to (1) the degree of tissue loss; (2) the extent of contamination; and (3) the depth of the wound.</li>
<li>Other types of skin wounds include:</li>
<li>abrasion: skin is scraped off due to direct contact with a rough surface</li>
<li>contusion: an area of bruising due to blunt force, without a break in the skin</li>
<li>penetrating injury: a wound with a fine pathway, caused by a sharp object; it is of variable depth and is often not visible to the naked eye.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology">PATHOPHYSIOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Lacerations are a break in the dermal and epidermal integrity that possibly involve the deeper structures of fascia, muscle, tendons and/or nerves. As such it is important to consider the location of the laceration within the context of its involvement with other structures.</li>
<li>The location of the laceration and the circumstances that resulted in its occurrence have implications for the likelihood of subsequent bacterial infection. For example, the concentration of normal skin flora in the axilla, perineum, anorectal areas and nail beds are far higher than on the trunk or extremities. Other factors that play a part in the likelihood of wound infection include the vascularity and anatomy of the area, time elapsed before care is received and the implantation of particulate matter in the wound.</li>
<li>The goals of wound management are achievement of optimal closure in the area; restoration of function; prevention of infection and adequate cosmetic result.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="history">HISTORY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Time of injury and time elapsed since injury (important in determining closure and tetanus prophylaxis).</li>
<li>Witnessed accident.</li>
<li>Mechanism of injury and what caused the laceration (what happened to cause trauma and what caused the laceration? knife, glass, fall, etc.).</li>
<li>Likelihood of foreign body in wound.</li>
<li>Associated injuries: e.g. head, bony involvement.</li>
<li>Loss of consciousness (see Sec. 13.5).</li>
</ul>
<p>13 Musculoskeletal problems, neurological problems and trauma</p>
<ul>
<li>Tetanus status (ensure that the child has a full immunisation history and is therefore tetanus immune).</li>
<li>Allergies to antibiotics and/or anaesthetics.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physical-examination">PHYSICAL EXAMINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Location and size of wound should be accurately documented (type, length and depth of wound); these are best demonstrated by the use of a drawing or diagram.</li>
<li>Indication of bony injury is important to establish as compound fractures can be overlooked if focus is on the wound alone. If a fracture is suspected, then the limb should be X-rayed.</li>
<li>Indication of vascular, tendon and/or nerve injury is easily missed. Therefore, it is imperative that adequate perfusion, along with tendon and nerve and function are tested in the wound area and distal to every limb wound.</li>
<li>Determination of foreign body presence/absence is vital. If a foreign body is visible, it should only be removed (in the absence of consultation) if there is no risk of further tissue damage.</li>
<li>Determination of infection risk and consideration of the need for antibiotics. Assess wound for the likelihood of contamination.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="differential-diagnoses">DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differential-diagnoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Although the child may present with a laceration, it is vital to ensure that there are no other underlying problems. It is therefore essential to rule out bony injury and other structural damage in addition to consideration of child protection issues.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Additional diagnostics: depends on location, size and type of wound. The laceration may require an X-ray if there is bony tenderness and/or to rule out foreign body; note that not all wound debris is radio-opaque. If a foreign body is suspected in the hand and/or foot, the area may need to be explored (see indications for referral). If antibiotics are to be given, the wound should be swabbed prior to discharge.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pharmacotherapeutics: Adequate pain relief should be given (see Sec. 13.3). For most types of lacerations, paracetamol is usually adequate for pain relief; however, each individual's level of pain should be measured and analgesia given accordingly. Debridement and/or probing will require local anaesthetic. Consideration should be given regarding the need for antibiotics; however, it should be noted that they are not always necessary. Adequate cleansing and good surgical technique (see Behavioural interventions) are mainstays in preventing wound infection. Wounds that may benefit from prophylactic cover include those associated with fractures, dirty wounds, deep penetrating wounds and those that result from a human or animal bite. If it is determined that an antibiotic is required, choice of preparation is dictated by the organism most likely to infect the wound.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Behavioural interventions: centre around wound cleansing, debridement and closure.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cleansing: normal saline (irrigation or on a swab) is typically used until the wound is clean.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Debridement: remove dried blood, wound debris and devitalised tissue; trim ragged edges if suturing after local anaesthetic given.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Closure: depends on the location, size and type of wound. The age of the child should also be taken into consideration. There are many types of wound closure agents available (see Table 13.3).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Patient education: for all children this includes age-appropriate safety counselling. Details of wound care at home, signs and symptoms of wound infection, activity restrictions, bathing and follow-up should be discussed, but these are largely dependent on wound and type of closure used (Table 13.4). Written</p>
</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>Table 13.3 Wound Closure Options</th><th></th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Type of closure</td><td>Advantages</td><td>Disadvantages</td></tr><tr><td>Adhesive strips</td><td>• Commonly used for simple, incised wounds</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Easy to apply (for the most part)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Less traumatic than other types of closure</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Easy for parents to remove at home</td><td>• Not suitable over joints</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Are difficult to apply to scalp</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Require a dry field in order to adhere</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Tissue adhesives</td><td>• Widely used for closure of minor wounds (often in lieu of sutures)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Reduces trauma associated with sutures</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Eliminates need for local anaesthetic</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Less time consuming and, if used on scalp wound, no need for hair to be shaved</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• With skilled application, produces excellent cosmetic results</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• As glue forms protective seal, no need for dressing</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Considered to be ideal medium for closure of cutaneous wounds</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Novelty factor is useful: ‘You have been glued back together’</td><td>• Not useful for wounds where there is risk of foreign body or if wound caused by bite</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Debate exists on the use of tissue adhesives for facial wounds. Often they are used only on wounds that are above the eyebrow. However, there are variations in practice</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Sutures</td><td>• Closure of choice over joints</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Wounds with involvement of deeper structures</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Deep scalp wounds</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Wounds through lip margin</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Wounds through eyebrow</td><td>• Involves some sort of anaesthesia (local and/or general) possible sedation</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Can be traumatic for child</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Requires follow-up for suture removal</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Likely to involve greater time and expense</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Staples</td><td>• Not commonly used in paediatrics</td><td>• As for sutures</td></tr></tbody></table>

<p>Table 13.4 Patient Education</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Type of closure</th><th>Important information for child and carer</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Adhesive strips</td><td>• A dry dressing may be applied over the adhesive strips to prevent the child from removing the strips</td></tr><tr><td>• Both dressing and strips need to stay dry for 3–5 days</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• If either become wet, they need to be re-applied (send family home with a few extra)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Length of time strips should be in place dependent on location of wound; normally 3–5 days (useful to tell carer to allow strips to fall off on their own after this time)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Follow-up not usually required; however, consider re-attendance for removal/inspection of wound site</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Tissue adhesives</td><td>• Follow-up not usually required; however, consider re-attendance for inspection of wound site if increased risk of infection</td></tr><tr><td>• Important to stress with carer and child that wound needs to stay dry for 5 days</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Remind child not to ‘pick’ at wound; scab will fall off on its own (usually in about 10 days)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Sutures</td><td>• If dissolvable, then no follow-up necessary</td></tr><tr><td>• Scalp sutures removed in 5–7 days</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Facial sutures removed in 3–5 days</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Hand sutures removed in 8–10 days</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Arm sutures removed in 7–10 days</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Leg sutures removed in 10–14 days</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Foot sutures removed in 10–14 days</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Staples</td><td>• Removal times as for sutures</td></tr><tr><td>• Removal requires use of dedicated forceps</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>instructions to accompany discharge should be used and should include a contact phone number for potential questions/concerns.</p>
<p><strong>FOLLOW-UP</strong></p>
<p>• Dependent on type of wound closure (see Table 13.3).</p>
<p><strong>MEDICAL CONSULT/SPECIALIST REFERRAL</strong></p>
<p>• Any child with a wound(s) that is accompanied by a suspicion of a fracture and/or foreign body following X-ray.
• Any child with large, complicated wounds and/or those that would require general anaesthetic/sedation.
• Any child in whom the circumstances surrounding the injury are suspicious (i.e. child protection issues).</p>
<p><strong>PAEDIATRIC PEARLS</strong></p>
<p>• Mechanism of injury is vital to establish extent of injury.
• If there is any doubt of foreign body, always X-ray.
• If crushing injury suspected, X-ray to exclude compound fracture.
• Antibiotics are no substitute for meticulous wound cleaning.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="13-3-pain-assessment-and-management">13.3 PAIN ASSESSMENT AND MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#13-3-pain-assessment-and-management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Anita Flynn and Sara Higginson</p>
<p><strong>INTRODUCTION</strong></p>
<p>• Pain is a common complaint in childhood. The most common sources are from everyday incidents that occur during play. Few of these incidents result in significant injury and the pain associated with them is typically of short duration, with the majority of episodes managed successfully at home.
• Some diseases or disorders (e.g. cancer, arthritis, sickle cell disease, etc.) have pain as a predominant symptom of their illness. Similarly, recurrent pain (such as that experienced with migraines and recurrent abdominal pain) is common in children and frequently seen in primary care.
• Acute paediatric trauma (e.g. burns, fractures, etc.) will require analgesic intervention and it is likely that the nurse practitioner (NP) working in the acute setting will likewise encounter these children.
• Therefore, a priority for the NP (in all settings) is to accurately assess and manage pain in children, while also differentiating conditions that are benign and self-limiting from those that represent more significant pathology (and thus require medical consultation and referral). This is especially true for children whose pain is a presenting symptom (e.g. appendicitis, testicular torsion, etc.) and it is the NP that makes the initial assessment.</p>
<p><strong>PATHOPHYSIOLOGY</strong></p>
<p>• There are many kinds of pain, with each type possessing its own physiology.</p>
<p>13 Musculoskeletal problems, neurological problems and trauma</p>
<p>Table 13.5 Classification of Pain</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Classification type</th><th>Type of pain</th><th>Characteristics</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Temporal</td><td>Acute pain</td><td>• Refers to immediate, sudden pain which is caused by actual illness or injury</td></tr><tr><td>• Resolves when healing has taken place</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Recurrent acute (e.g. migraine)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Chronic acute (e.g. cancer or burn pain)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Chronic non-malignant (e.g. back pain)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Chronic pain (three types)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Clinical</td><td>Mild</td><td>• Minor, slight, subtle pain</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Moderate</td><td>• Medium, average, modest pain</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Severe</td><td>• Intense, great, relentless</td></tr><tr><td>Neurophysiologic</td><td>Somatic</td><td>• Sharp, achy, well-localised and consistent with lesion (e.g. postoperative pain, appendicitis, arthritis)</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Visceral</td><td>• Diffuse, dull, deep, poorly localised, crampy often accompanied by nausea and vomiting, diaphoresis and referral to other areas (e.g. intestinal obstruction, perforation)</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Neuropathic</td><td>• Burning, radiating or stabbing sensation, abnormal central sensitisation (e.g. nerve injury or irritation, phantom limb pain)</td></tr><tr><td>Psychogenic</td><td></td><td>• May present as any of the above</td></tr><tr><td>• Important to recognise</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul>
<li>For the most part, however, pain results from the stimulation of pain receptors located throughout the body. These impulses are subsequently conveyed, via the nervous system, to the brain for interpretation.</li>
<li>Nerves that carry pain impulses can be categorised according to (1) what kind of message they carry; (2) their size; and (3) the conduction rate of the fibres.</li>
<li>Sharp pain (i.e. somatic pain) is conveyed by thick, myelinated fibres with relatively fast conduction.</li>
<li>Dull pain (i.e. visceral pain) is conveyed by unmyelinated, slow conduction fibres.</li>
<li>Other sensations (e.g. warmth, touch, etc.) are conveyed by A beta fibres.</li>
<li>It is important to classify pain, as it has implications for management (i.e. types of interventions used). Table 13.5 outlines the different ways pain can be classified.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="history">HISTORY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The pain history is largely influenced by the child’s age and developmental level as well as his capacity to communicate. Involvement of parents/carers is important as they can provide information on their child’s usual pain-coping strategies, effective pain relief measures and interpretation of symptoms.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If pain is not the presenting complaint, it is important to obtain an episodic history (see Ch. 4) in order to place the child’s pain within the context of his presenting symptomatology.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Location of the pain: it is important for the child to identify the painful area (if possible) and this information should be specifically documented: e.g. ‘left temporal headache’ rather than ‘headache’.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Onset, frequency and duration of pain.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Intensity and distribution.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Child and family’s perception of the pain’s aetiology (e.g. ‘Where do you think the pain is coming from?’).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Does the pain interfere with eating, drinking, sleeping and/or breathing?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Does the pain hinder the child when walking, sitting, running?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Does the pain stop the child from going to school, school activities or play?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Does the child complain of pain on Saturdays and Sundays (i.e. days he does not have to attend school)?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Does the pain make the child cry and/or awaken from a sound sleep?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Exacerbating and relieving factors (including pain management strategies tried thus far and the child’s response).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Associated symptoms (nausea, vomiting, rashes, fever, diarrhoea, etc.).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Previous experiences with pain.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Family and sociocultural factors, including parental attitudes and sibling experiences with pain.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physical-examination">PHYSICAL EXAMINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>If the aetiology of the pain is not readily apparent (or if the pain is a symptom of the illness) it is important to examine the child from head to toe. This is especially significant when the source of the pain is unknown and the pain is of acute onset.</li>
<li>Pain assessment is an essential component of the physical examination. It is important that a validated pain tool is used and that the assessment is (1) age and/or developmentally appropriate and (2) the child/family’s social circumstances and cultural background are considered. The tool should be used in tandem with the child’s self-report of pain, the parent’s perspective and the NP’s assessment of the pain. Table 13.6 outlines age-appropriate pain assessment.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Successful management of pain depends on identification of the source and aetiology of the pain; aggravating and relieving factors; the severity of the pain (which impacts treatment choice); and the individual needs of the child. Consequently, it is likely that a number of interventions (e.g. pharmacological, psychological, emotional and behavioural) will be utilised (and individualised) in order to provide adequate relief. The sum effect of a combination of interventions is likely to be greater than any one intervention alone.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Additional diagnostics: specific to the aetiology of the pain.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pharmacotherapeutics: see Tables 13.7 and 13.8 and Fig. 13.1.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Behavioural interventions: see Table 13.9.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Patient education:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>be sure that the patient understands the pain assessment tool</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>explain to the child that he should not be afraid to tell someone about the pain and that it is very important to do so.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>13.3 Pain assessment and management</p>
<p>Table 13.6 Age-Appropriate Pain Assessment</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Age</th><th>Rationale</th><th>Comments and tools</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Neonates and infants</td><td>• Behaviour and physiological values are interpreted together</td><td>• Observation of facial expression, body position and movement, crying, blood pressure, heart rate, skin colour, oxygen saturation and respiratory rate</td></tr><tr><td>• Neonates may cry intermittently or continuously and/or be inconsolable when they have pain</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• CRIES scale (Krechel &amp; Bildner, 1995)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Postoperative Pain Score (Attia, 1987)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Pain Assessment Tool (Hodgkinson, 1995)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Pain Rating Scale (Joyce, 1994)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Pre-verbal children</td><td>• A behavioural scale (e.g. one in which pain is identified according to the child's actions) should be used</td><td>• Observation of irritability, crying, aggressiveness (biting, kicking, hitting) grimacing and loss of interest in play or eating</td></tr><tr><td>• Note that the absence of behavioural cues (above) does not exclude pain</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Unlike adults who likely decrease their activity when in pain, toddlers typically become restless and overly active (behaviours that may not be recognised as a response to pain)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Memory, physical restraint, parent separation and lack of preparation influence the intensity of the behavioural response</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Pain Rating Scale (Joyce, 1994)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Young children (3–7 years of age)</td><td>• Behavioural and self-report scales can be used. Specific tool used will depend on child's age and cognitive level</td><td>• Child may be restless, fretful, irritable and reluctant to move painful area</td></tr><tr><td>• Most 3 year olds will be able to differentiate the presence or absence of pain and will point to where their pain is located (roughly)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• A 3 year old can usually indicate pain intensity in broad categories ('none, some, a lot')</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• The FACES scale is widely used. However, younger children may think that they have to choose the 'happy' face rather than the face that relates to their own pain experience. Likewise, children may indicate a particular 'face' as a rating of how they are feeling (e.g. sad, happy, tearful, etc.) rather than their degree of pain</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• FACES Pain Rating Scale (Wong et al., 1999)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Poker Chip Tool (Hester, 1998)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Older children and adolescents</td><td>• Able to use visual and colour analogue scales and self-report measures</td><td>• In older children, behaviour may bear no relation to the intensity of pain</td></tr><tr><td>• Adolescent Pediatric Pain Tool (Savedra, 1993)</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Table 13.7 Pharmacotherapeutic Management of Pain</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Class</th><th>Name(s)</th><th>Use and comments</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Non-opioid analgesic</td><td>• Paracetamol</td><td>• Effective for relief of mild pain (sore throat, ear ache, sprains, abdominal pain)</td></tr><tr><td>• Available as an oral suspension or tablets</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• May be given rectally if nausea or vomiting present, but absorption is less reliable</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)</td><td>• Ibuprofen</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Diclofenac</td><td>• Ibuprofen is available as an oral suspension or tablets</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Diclofenac is available as a tablet or suppository</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• NSAIDs effective for control of pain from inflammation in soft tissues, joints and musculoskeletal trauma. Also useful for postoperative pain</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Use NSAIDs with caution in asthmatics</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Avoid use in children with history of gastrointestinal bleeding and among children with renal impairment (only with careful monitoring)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• May interfere with platelet function and, therefore, may be unsuitable for children with thrombocytopenia and those at risk of haemorrhage from other causes</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>• Entonox (nitrous oxide + oxygen mixture)</td><td>• Potent analgesic which depends on self-administration and cooperation of child for its successful use</td></tr><tr><td>• Quick-acting, with an equally rapid offset when administration ceases</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Ideal for short-term use and pain of short duration (dressing changes, suturing wounds, applying traction, etc.)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Should not be used with any condition where air is trapped within body and where its expansion might be dangerous (e.g. head injuries with impaired consciousness, air embolism, maxillofacial injuries and gross abdominal distension)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Opioid analgesic</td><td>• Codeine</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Morphine</td><td>• Codeine used to relieve moderate or severe pain (e.g. skeletal trauma, burns, postoperative pain). Available in tablet, liquid and rectal forms</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Morphine is the standard opioid for the relief of severe pain in children. Available for oral, rectal and parenteral administration</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Topical anaesthetic</td><td>• Lidocaine (Emla cream)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Ametop (tetracaine gel)</td><td>• Useful in alleviating pain and distress associated with needle insertion and other minor procedures</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Emla must be applied under an occlusive dressing for a minimum of 50 min before the procedure</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

<p>IM = intramuscular; IV = intravenous; NSAIDs = non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs; PCA = patient-controlled analgesia. QDS = four times a day; SC = subcutaneous; SR = sustained release.</p>
<p>13.3 Pain assessment and management</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251224-5f5cc0bc.jpeg" alt="img-38.jpeg"></p>
<p>The cause of pain must be considered when analgesics are prescribed</p>
<p>Do not use more than one NSAID at a time (i.e. diclofenac or ibuprofen).</p>
<p>Do not use more than one opioid at a time (i.e. codeine or morphine).</p>
<p>Do not use NSAIDs in:</p>
<p>Patients with poor renal function or renal failure.
Patients with gastric duodenal ulceration.
Patients with coagulation disorders or who are actively bleeding during or after surgery.
Patients on anticoagulants.</p>
<ul>
<li>Moderate or severe asthmatics who require regular prophylactic bronchodilator therapy. They may be given with caution to mild asthmatics.
Patients on methotrexate.</li>
</ul>
<p>Regular codeine is an alternative analgesic where NSAIDs are contra-indicated.</p>
<p>When morphine is started, continued use of regular paracetamol and a NSAID can have an 'opioid-sparing' effect.</p>
<p>Please see analgesic pain guidelines for dosage information.</p>
<p>To be used in conjunction with the Clinical Practice Guidelines "The Recognition &amp; Assessment of Acute Pain in Children" recommendations (RCN) 1999.</p>
<p>Figure 13.1 Acute Pain Ladder: infants and children. NSAID = non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug; im = intramuscularly; iv = intravenously; po = orally; pr = rectally; PRN = when required; sc = subcutaneously.</p>
<p>Table 13.9 Behavioural Interventions for Pain Management</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Intervention</th><th>Rationale and comments</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Information and preparation</td><td>• The experience of pain can be made worse by fear of what the pain will be like</td></tr><tr><td>• Information giving and preparation are very effective ways to help children cope with painful procedures</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• The type and amount of information will depend on the child's developmental level</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• The procedure should be discussed with the parent in order to determine what information has been given to the child</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• The length of the procedure and the sensation that will be felt should be explained truthfully to the child</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Suggestions on how the child can help during the procedure should also be included</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Relaxation</td><td>• A variety of techniques can be taught to both the parent and the child (e.g. distraction, imagery, play, deep breathing, and positive self-talk)</td></tr><tr><td>• Play therapy is used to reduce a child's anxiety and help prepare them for threatening events. Note, however, that some children may not be able to play with needles or other equipment before a procedure or examination</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• The actual type of play should be considered carefully and based on an assessment of the child's developmental and stress levels</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Distraction</td><td>• Distraction is useful during times of acute distress. However, it needs to be tailored to the child's developmental level. The more interactive the activity, the more it will hold the child's interest and enthusiasm</td></tr><tr><td>• Infants can be distracted with stroking, nursery rhymes or use of a dummy</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Toddlers can blow bubbles while the adult encourages them to blow away painful feelings (with the bubbles)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Children who are able to count can look through a book to count the number of times a certain object appears</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Older children can be distracted using games, puzzles or computer games. They can also be taught imagery techniques</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Positive self-talk</td><td>• Involves the use of statements such as 'I can do this' throughout the procedure</td></tr><tr><td>Use of choice and/or control</td><td>• Effective coping strategy for pain</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>13 Musculoskeletal problems, neurological problems and trauma</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="follow-up">FOLLOW-UP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#follow-up" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Not usually required if pain resolves with supportive care.</li>
<li>Return visit or phone call if parental anxiety high or pain has not settled.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="medical-consult-specialist-referral">MEDICAL CONSULT/SPECIALIST REFERRAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-consult-specialist-referral" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Any child with prolonged crying and/or inadequate control of pain.</li>
<li>Any child in whom the pain history is inappropriate.</li>
<li>Any child whose pain becomes worse despite appropriate initial management.</li>
<li>Any child in whom the cause of the pain is beyond the NP's scope of practice.</li>
<li>Any child who experiences intense pain, particularly if it is of sudden onset, and/or accompanied with altered vital signs (e.g. hypotension, tachycardia, tachypnoea or fever).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="paediatric-pearls">PAEDIATRIC PEARLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paediatric-pearls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Always take note of a mother who reports that ‘her baby’s cry has changed or is different’.</li>
<li>Just because a child is not crying does not mean he is pain-free.</li>
<li>Some children may deny they have pain in order to avoid having treatment or being admitted to the hospital.</li>
<li>Tell children the truth about pain.</li>
<li>Focusing on the child’s pain without accounting for his cultural background and environment may lead to incorrect conclusion and management.</li>
<li>Marked pain that awakens a child from a sound sleep is worrying and will likely require some sort of evaluation.</li>
<li>Principles of pain management are summarised in the acronym <strong>QUEST</strong>: Question the child; Use pain rating scales; Evaluate behaviour and physiological changes; Secure parental involvement; Take cause of pain into account; Take action and evaluate results.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bibliography">BIBLIOGRAPHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bibliography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
